urn:contentItem:4P85-12T0-TXN5-R2JF-00000-00Forest minister offers to quit over smoke pall1997-10-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESInternational NewsPg. 8Forest minister offers to quit over smoke pall* INDONESIALOUISE WILLIAMS Herald Correspondent in Jakarta, and agencies

Indonesia's Forestry Minister, Mr Djamaludin Suryohadikusumo, has offered to resign over the deadly smoke haze blanketing south-east Asia, as new fires in Indonesia's east threaten the tourist island of Bali.

Speaking at the opening of Parliament yesterday, Mr Djamaludin said he was prepared to take responsibility for the fires and step down.

New blazes were reported in several areas of Java and on Lombok, across a narrow strait from Bali, which draws almost a third of all Indonesia's tourists.

Meteorologists interpreting weather patterns for the Indonesian Government's fire response centre said strong westerly winds across much of the country would shift smoke-clouds from Lombok to Bali. The capital, Jakarta, is likely to be seriously smoke-affected by fires in central Java within one or two days.

Haze levels in Jakarta increased dramatically yesterday as smoke from at least three mountain fires moved across the city and the skyline disappeared beneath the smog.

A major forest fire was raging near tribal settlements in Malaysia's central Pahang State. Estimates of the area affected ranged from 200 to 2,000 hectares, far smaller than fires in neighbouring Indonesia, but efforts to douse the blaze were hampered by the drought.

Indonesian forest fires affecting up to 800,000 hectares have generated a thick smoky haze which has blanketed Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore and parts of the Philippines and Thailand.

Indonesian officials appealed to villagers not to shoot tigers and monkeys fleeing fires in national parks around Mount Tumpeng, Mount Merbabu and Mount Malabar in Java.

The Health Minister, Mr Sujudi, said: "I think the haze has now reached a dangerous level in terms of breathing difficulty. This situation is endangering people's health."

Experts at the fire response centre said critical smoke conditions, with visibility of less than 100 metres, continued to affect many areas of Sumatra and Kalimantan. Smoke from fires in Irian Jaya had now moved westwards, causing the closure of the airport in Ambon.

At least five people have died from respiratory problems linked to the haze, 236 people perished last week when a Garuda Airbus crashed in thick smoke, and in Irian Jaya 295 people have died of starvation and cholera due to the drought. Smoke from forest fires in Irian Jaya has prevented air drops of emergency supplies to the hardest-hit mountain villages.

The new fire in the Mount Rinjani national park on the island of Lombok is particularly worrying for Indonesia's tourist industry as many tour groups had been redirected to Lombok and Bali as airports closed in the worst-affected areas of Kalimantan and Sumatra.

The Antara newsagency said hundreds of hectares of the park were on fire. Indonesia's eastern islands are more vulnerable than other parts of the country because the monsoon rains normally arrive later than in the west. Meteorologists said some rain had fallen in northern Sumatra and wind patterns were easing conditions for Singapore and Malaysia, but sufficient rain to douse the fires was unlikely to fall until late October or November.

Yesterday was the deadline for 176 companies to prove they had not deliberately lit forest fires for clearing purposes. Officials said three companies had already been prosecuted.

Illus: No smoke without fire . . . an Indonesian farmer burns off undergrowth in Sintang, 1,000 kilometres north-east of Jakarta, where farmers are clearing the land for spring planting. Photograph by REUTER/JASON ELLISON Map: HAZE SPREADS

urn:contentItem:53XY-VT51-JD3N-52HR-00000-00Drought, rain, now fire risk2011-10-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 28Drought, rain, now fire riskMEGAN NEIL

AFTER the drought came the rain. And after that may well come the fires.

Last summer's heavy rains have transformed large parts of the middle of Australia, with sparse desert replaced by waist or even shoulder-high grass in places.

It might look spectacular, but it also means Australia faces the prospect of huge fires burning for months across its centre.

Experts say the season could be a repeat of the summer of 1974-75, when fires throughout central Australia razed 117 million hectares 15 per cent of the continent.

Millions of hectares could burn, bushfire expert Phil Cheney said.

All it takes is a lightning strike to set the grass alight, and once a wildfire takes hold it's very difficult to put out.

``They will be very difficult to contain,'' said Mr Cheney, the former head of the CSIRO's bushfire research unit.

``It's likely to burn for months.

``It will be in the tens of millions of hectares.''

Heavy rain through Australia's centre has sparked prolific grass growth. It's now curing, or drying out, after recent drier weather.

The thick band of grass extends from the Indian Ocean in the west to the Pacific Ocean in southern Queensland and the Great Dividing Range in NSW.

``Essentially we've got a fuel bed that stretches from Sydney to Carnarvon, it goes right across the nation,'' the assistant chief operations officer (country) at Western Australia's Fire & Emergency Services Authority, Chris Arnol, said.

The Bushfire Cooperative Research Centre (CRC) warns of the potential for above-normal bushfire activity across the middle of Australia, with grass fires posing the biggest risk this season.

``We need to be particularly vigilant this year because grass fires start very easily, particularly once the grass is what's termed cured,'' Bushfire CRC deputy CEO and research director Richard Thornton said.

``They can start very easily, they travel very rapidly and are very difficult to warn about.''

Bushfire expert and former CSIRO principal research scientist David Packham believes huge grass fires are almost a certainty in the centre of Australia, if not this year then next year.

``The centre, as everybody knows, has had heaps of rain, there's heaps of growth and they are going to have heaps of fires,'' Mr Packham said.

``I would expect massive fires in the centre.''

Several fires have already broken out in central Australia, which doesn't have a fire season every year.

``Central Australia is a slightly unusual event. This is probably a one-in-30-year event in central Australia,'' Bushfires Northern Territory director Steve Sutton said.

``Central Australia is likely to continue with fires right through until the autumn, and we will have fires for most of that time,'' he said.

Mr Sutton said Central Australia's variable winds could fan fire fronts spread over as much as 70km.

Grass fires can develop into quite significant fires in a matter of minutes, ACT Rural Fire Service chief officer Andrew Stark warned.

Days of low humidity and strong winds bring an increased risk of bad grass fires, bringing trees down on power lines.

``So many times right across Australia whenever you see one grass fire occurring in an area often you get a number of grass fires, and that'll be the challenge,'' Mr Stark said.

Experts say the general trend is that if there's a serious grass season, it's usually a mild forest fire season.

But as Victoria knows only too well after the Black Saturday bushfires, the bush can be just as volatile.

``With the right weather conditions coming together dry, hot, windy conditions you're going to get a bushfire risk, you're going to get a grass fire risk under those conditions,'' NSW Rural Fire Brigade Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons said.

In Western Australia, 80 per cent of the state faces the potential for above-average bushfire activity, much of it in grassland and pastoral areas in more isolated locations.

But Mr Arnol said a key issue remained the forested ``urban interface'' area in the southwest corner despite the forecast of normal bushfire activity there.

``A normal activity in our lower southwest still means that we will be facing the potential for significant fires coastal, heathland and forest,'' he said.

While the soil is moist in forested areas, it will only take a run of very hot days to quickly dry out the forests.

``There's still a big risk,'' Dr Thornton said.

``You should never be complacent of fire, particularly in Victoria or in NSW or any of those really hot places because forest fires are always a possibility.

``But this year particularly, grass fires will be a bigger issue than they have been in the past.''

Dr Thornton says the Bushfire CRC's reports are not a prediction that there will be fires but that there is a greater likelihood of fires.

There are no crystal balls to say how the season will actually pan out, South Australian Country Fire Service manager operations services Rob Sandford said.

And no-one can control the weather.

``If we get hot, really dry, windy weather, that will increase the risk because of the fuel loads right across the state and right across the nation,'' Mr Sandford said.

Outback station owners, who've already been through tough times with the drought, will be in the frontline if there are major fires across the centre, Mr Packham said.

But he said many were probably ``on their knees'' and not in a position to buy graders and to have sufficient people around to deal with the fires.

``The fires are fast-moving. These people know how to deal with them, it's just that they haven't got the resources,'' Mr Packham said.

``They need government assistance . . . to have sufficient resources to be able to deal with them.''

Fire authorities have been talking about the risks this fire season, but the concern is that memories have faded since the last bad grass fire season, and for some reason the community thinks a grass fire isn't as bad as a bushfire.

``A lot of people say it's only a grass fire. It can travel very, very rapidly, it can change direction very rapidly and can catch people by surprise,'' Dr Thornton said.

Mr Sandford said everyone needed a bushfire action plan even if they thought they didn't live in a bushfire-prone area, saying people who lived in the suburbs around Australia would at some stage drive through a fire zone.

``People that live there need one, but everyone needs one to ensure their best chances of survival,'' he said.

``History shows that bushfires are a huge threat in the community and tragically people do die when these events occur.''

--AAP

urn:contentItem:7V1G-0250-YB64-4000-00000-00Man on arson death charge2009-02-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Man on arson death chargeAlmost 2000 houses confirmed destroyedDEWI COOKE and JOHN SILVESTER, with MIKI PERKINS, DAVID ROOD, JASON DOWLING

A WEEK after Australia's worst peacetime disaster, police have arrested a suspected arsonist and pinpointed "ground zero" - the spot where someone lit the blaze that killed around 100 people at Marysville.

The first breakthrough in the huge investigation was made public yesterday when a 39-year-old Latrobe Valley man was charged with intentionally lighting the Churchill bushfire that killed up to 21people.

Angry onlookers beat on the door of a prison van outside the Morwell court as the accused, whose identity was suppressed by court order, was taken to Melbourne.

He has been charged with arson causing death and deliberately lighting a bushfire. Both counts relate to fires started at Churchill last Saturday.

The man was also charged with possessing child pornography.

Police sources revealed last night that he had been under surveillance for days and had been arrested quietly on Thursday before neighbours suspected he was a target.

"They want to hang him," a Gippsland policeman said.

Police and prison officials decided to move the man to Melbourne for his own safety. He was in protective custody last night and will appear in the Melbourne Magistrates Court on Monday.

"There are prisoners who have lost relatives in the fires," a Corrections Victoria source said.

Assistant Commissioner Dannye Moloney said: "We have a very emotive environment out there. People are pointing fingers. People are jumping to conclusions. Rumours and innuendoes are being spread."

In other developments:

- Former Supreme Court judge Bernard Teague will head the royal commission on the fires. It is scheduled to deliver an interim report before the end of the year and a final report by July 2010.

- Families of those who died in the fires will be given a $10,000 bereavement grant from the $100million so far raised by the bushfire appeal. The grant is the first allocation from the Victorian Bushfire Appeal Fund, which will be administered by a panel headed by former Victorian governor John Landy.

- A group of forest fire experts accused Environment Minister Gavin Jennings of trying to deceive the public over fire-reduction burning.

- Hundreds of tradesmen and planners have offered help to rebuild more than 1800 homes destroyed in the fires, leaving 7000 people homeless.

- The first six of up to 20 Indonesian forensic police will arrive in Melbourne tomorrow to help identify bodies of fire victims, a task that could take six months.

- The Department of Sustainability and Environment's chief fire officer, Ewan Waller, said authorities expected to be battling the major fires for at least another two weeks.

Premier John Brumby declined to comment on yesterday's arrest, but said arson was an unspeakable and heinous crime.

The charge of arson causing death carries a maximum penalty of 25 years' jail, while intentionally lighting a bushfire has a penalty of up to 15 years.

It is understood police found child pornography images on computer files belonging to the suspected Gippsland arsonist on Thursday afternoon. He was arrested around 4pm and held overnight for his own safety while investigators searched his house.

He was not present at his remand hearing in the Morwell Magistrates Court yesterday and did not apply for bail.

His legal aid lawyer said the man was in a "fragile mental state".

Two of the accused man's supporters in court during the remand hearing later told journalists to "back off". As police escorted a van carrying the accused out of the court complex, locals hurled abuse and struck the van.

Meanwhile, investigators confirmed that the fire that wiped out the town of Marysville and nearby Narbethong, killing up to 100 people, began around 2.30pm last Saturday near the abandoned Murrindindi sawmill, south of Yea.

Forensic examination indicates the fire was deliberately lit. Police appealed for anyone who visited a popular swimming and camping spot near the mill site in Wilhelmina Falls Road on Saturday to contact them urgently.

Detective Superintendent Paul Hollowood, of the Phoenix taskforce, said: "We believe the mill site is ground zero ... This was not an attempt to burn down the mill but a deliberate attempt to create a bushfire on a massive scale."

After touring the razed towns of Marysville and Kinglake, Major-General John Cantwell, the man in charge of leading Victoria's bushfire recovery effort, said yesterday the destruction ranked "alongside some of the worst I've seen in combat". General Cantwell has requested more troops be sent to the Kinglake area to reinforce basic services as people begin to return. More than 300 soldiers should be on the ground by the end of the weekend.

Mr Brumby said Marysville, Strathewen and Middle Kinglake primary schools would be among the first structures rebuilt in fire-ravaged towns.

Every family affected by the bushfires will be allocated a case manager to assist with issues such as insurance, rebuilding and managing estates.

Police Deputy Commissioner Kieran Walshe warned there was a risk of "copycat" arsonists starting fires following the heavy reporting of Victoria's bushfires. With MIKI PERKINS, DAVID ROOD, JASON DOWLING

PHOTO: An angry local yells abuse as an alleged arsonist is driven from the Morwell police station yesterday afternoon. PICTURE: PAT SCALA

urn:contentItem:5WK2-MJ31-F031-X002-00000-00Bringing them back2019-07-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:00ZLexisNexisScience Show11:19 AM AESTBringing them back

Robyn Williams: Imagine: you're sitting in the giant concert hall in Brisbane and it's packed. We're at the World Science Festival, and on stage, as the lights come up, is what looks like a large Tasmanian tiger. And it's moving. The audience is hushed as it watches, because the tiger is supposed to be extinct. Then they realise it's a giant marionette. This is The Science Show, on Bringing Them Back.

So you've seen a living Tasmanian tiger. He actually did a poo backstage. Bringing Them Back, the de-extinction debate. And in blunt terms we are losing nature before our very eyes, whole ecosystems gone with largely unknown consequences. The much talked about sixth extinction. Is it the one caused by humanity? Tragically the world has lost many of its animal species the last two centuries, and there is no sign of that trend easing. A recent World Wide Fund for Nature report states that since 1970, less than 50 years ago, human activity has wiped out 60% of Earth's wildlife, covering mammals, birds, fish...90% of fish gone. Reptiles and amphibians, not to mention the devastating loss of insects worldwide reported last month. It seems no place on Earth is immune and time is running out for conservation.

So what does modern conservation science look like, and should everything be on the table for consideration, including the option of reviving what has gone? With new genetic technologies we are not that far from the Jurassic Park idea of de-extinction becoming science fact. But will it ever be possible or practical to revive extinct species to save biodiversity and perhaps ourselves in the process? And if so, where do we start? And who decides what to save?

Our first guest is a leading expert on wildlife reproduction management from the Leibnitz Institute for Zoo and Wildlife Research in Berlin. Since 1997 his team have been working to rescue the northern white rhino from the brink of extinction, made harder by the recent loss of the species' last male. Welcome to the stage, Thomas Hildebrandt.

Next we welcome executive director of the Institute for Future Environments and a professor across the river at the Queensland University of Technology. Her two decades leading research into the science and policy of conservation has attracted numerous awards, including the Prime Minister's Prize for Life Scientist of the Year, and the Australian Academy of Science Nancy Millis Medal. Kerrie Wilson.

Hailing from the University of Melbourne, our next guest is an Associate Professor and ARC Future Fellow whose lab recently sequenced the genome of the extinct thylacine or Tasmanian tiger, the one you saw. In developing genetic tools to help conserve current marsupial species, their ultimate aim is to revive the iconic thylacine itself. Welcome Andrew Pask.

And our final guest is a senior research fellow at Griffith University's Environmental Futures Research Institute. Its work is international, to counter the illegal wildlife trade. Just back from Namibia, welcome Duan Biggs.

Well, there's the problem. Kerrie, I mentioned the sixth extinction. Are we in it, do you take it seriously?

Kerrie Wilson: Yes, we take it seriously. So 66 million years ago we had a similar extinction event, and about 25 years ago scientists started to think, you know, something is going on here, and we started taking note. They estimated about 25 years ago that we were losing species at around 10,000 times quicker than what we would in the background rate of species loss.

Robyn Williams: And in this circumstance should all avenues, all different techniques be open to science to try?

Kerrie Wilson: That's an interesting question. Every tool in your tool shed comes with a cost, and it comes with a benefit. And so we need to throw every tool at this question, but we also need to just unpack what do those tools look like and what will be the consequences associated with them.

Robyn Williams: And you'd like a debate, people discussing these things.

Kerrie Wilson: Yes, absolutely.

Robyn Williams: Thomas, during the extinction debate we are talking about saving things before they go away, disappear, and with rhinos you've just got a couple left. What're you going to do? You've got two females.

Thomas Hildebrandt: Yes, the northern white rhino is declared as a subspecies of the southern white rhino. It lives in central Africa and it was a very important landscape architect before it was declared in 2006 as extinct in the wild. Now there are only two females left, a mother and a daughter, Najin and Fatu. Both are infertile so actually that's the end of the story. Not fully because we have stored semen from four different males over the last 20 years, and we have fibroblast culture from 12 non-related individuals. So using the tool box of modern conservation technology we are capable of generating embryos from northern white rhinos by using the oocytes from these two females and the semen, which is cold preserved, and using surrogates mothers like southern white rhinos to produce northern white rhino offspring. We then use these two females to educate the offspring to be a northern white rhino, which is a very important element, the social education. We think this program is quite sound and we hope to be successful within the next three years with the first calf on the ground.

Robyn Williams: And how long does it take to educate the baby?

Thomas Hildebrandt: It has to live with the two remaining northern white rhinos to understand what it means to be a northern white rhino because a genome provides all of the morphology, all the physiology, but the knowledge, the social part is also very important and therefore it is a time pressing project because these two females, one is 18, one is 29, so time is running out.

Robyn Williams: You mentioned fibroblasts there, bits of tissue. What do you do with them?

Thomas Hildebrandt: Yes, fibroblasts are parts of the skin, you put them in cell culture and then they propagate, and when they propagate we call them fibroblasts. And in 2012 there was a Nobel Prize for transforming these cells into stem cells.

Robyn Williams: Stem cells, we can do anything, theoretically.

Thomas Hildebrandt: That needs quite a lot of research. Right now the mouse is the most advanced model. To transfer all this knowledge to a rhino or to an elephant or to a marsupial, that is quite a challenging task.

Robyn Williams: And apart from white rhinos, what sort of other collections have you got of these sperm and eggs and so on?

Thomas Hildebrandt: We have a comparable collection of biomaterial, like the frozen zoo in San Diego. So for us, even though Sudan died in March 2018, we declare him not as dead because we still have life elements from him, we have semen from him, we have fibroblasts from him, so there are all these blueprints to make a new Sudan is in our bank.

Robyn Williams: It's amazing, isn't it, the progress.

Andrew, we heard about the thylacine, the Tasmanian tiger. I think it was Mike Archer's voice we heard talking about the attempt they made a few years ago, at the Australian Museum, and at that stage we did a Catalyst program and my partner described it as trying to make some sentences out of alphabet soup, trying to stitch this stuff together. Is it still as hard as all that was back then?

Andrew Pask: We've actually rebuilt the entirely thylacine genome in my lab now, so we do have that complete blueprint of what it was to make a thylacine.

Robyn Williams: Astounding, isn't it. Where did you get the original DNA from?

Andrew Pask: This one actually came from one of the Museum Victoria specimens, so it was one of the very few pickled pouch young. So it was a little baby thylacine that was removed from its mum's pouch, the mum was shot as part of the bounty scheme that they had in Tasmania at the time. So they were offering £1 to bring pelts in, which was a huge amount of money back in the early 1900s, to bring in these specimens. And this mum had three babies in her pouch, and so they took each of them. But for some reason we still don't know, they would normally put these into formalin, which is actually very bad for the DNA, but these three miracle pups, we like to call them, went straight into ethanol and that actually preserved the DNA a lot better which meant we were able to get some really, really high quality long bits of DNA from these animals, which makes building that genome a lot easier, and we can be much more sure of the final genome that we have really representing what the thylacine DNA looks like.

Robyn Williams: And we've just seen a re-enactment on stage. Andrew, imagine you're looking at the offspring and they're alive. How would you feel?

Andrew Pask: Just blown away. I think it would be such an amazing thing if we could do that, to actually bring a species back, but particularly the thylacine. I think it's such an amazing marsupial species. It's completely unique. It was our only apex predator marsupial that lived into modern times. We don't have anything that sits at the top of the food chain like the thylacine does in any of our other marsupial species. It really was completely unique in every way, from its dog-like shape, the way it moved, its behaviour, right the way through to its hunting behaviours. It really was just an amazing animal that we unfortunately completely wiped from existence.

Robyn Williams: Yes, and there was a bounty on them and that was quite recently, one or two generations.

Andrew Pask: Yes, and they were aggressively hunted to extinction, as you could imagine, when there is that sort of price put on their head.

Robyn Williams: So Duan, you're working in Southern Africa, in Namibia, South Africa itself. What are the cultural feelings there about such creatures which still linger and which we want to preserve, how do local people react to what you're trying to do?

Duan Biggs: Yes, I think that's an important question and I think relevant, as Kerrie raised, de-extinction is one of the tools in the toolbox but there's a whole complex process of discussion and negotiation that needs to take place for it to be evaluated. And I was recently in Botswana, which is the country that sits between Namibia and South Africa, and there, as many of the audience here may have heard, there's been a recent furore because the government wants to bring back hunting of elephants included, and a lot in the international community are saying you cannot do that, that is wrong. Elephant hunting is morally wrong and you shouldn't do it. However, it's complex.

So in 2014 when hunting was banned there, the types of benefits that typically low income households and communities used to get from elephants disappeared, and also these people have to live with the costs of elephants. I'm not sure how many in the audience have lived with elephants but I have and they are great animals but if you are a small-scale farmer, they can be very damaging and they invoke a lot of fear. So now because of the hunting ban, people are not getting benefits and only living with the costs. And there was increasing antagonism towards these animals, and some of my colleagues in Botswana say increasing support for poaching activities of these animals because they were nuisance and only bringing costs.

So now Botswanan government is saying let's bring back hunting or talk about bringing back, and well managed hunting can support conservation of elephants and also support rural communities. However, many in the conservation sector internationally, animal welfare, animal rights groups are saying this is unacceptable. There are some big players calling for tourism boycotts of Botswana. So clearly in this complex issue, an animal we all love, like an elephant, we don't, as a conservation sector and as a society, have a good way of dealing with these issues, and it's going to be a similar challenge with de-extinction.

Robyn Williams: Duan, how much time have we got to solve that problem?

Duan Biggs: I think the sooner the better, there is urgency, because if you let problems like that lie, then you get a culture developing of antagonism towards wildlife. And there are places in Southern Africa where there is actually a culture of poaching evolves and that becomes the expected thing to do and that's not what we want to get to, so we need to move fast.

Robyn Williams: And you can get big money very quickly.

Duan Biggs: Yes exactly, and those are low, low income places. But to bring us back to de-extinction, there are discussions around should we bring back the woolly mammoth and thylacine. There are people that are going to bear costs, and where is their voice in the discussion? And these are considerations, together with the ones that Kerry raised, that need careful thought.

Robyn Williams: Andrew, we have a Twitter question; what would be the surrogate animal to bring back the Tasmanian tiger?

Andrew Pask: I think one of the nice things about marsupials is that they are born so small and then they complete their development in the mother's pouch. So you could actually use a variety of different marsupials to have that embryo be born from and transferred into a pouch of an eastern grey kangaroo or something that's very abundant. You'd have to work on something I guess that you have a lot of. But there's also really great artificial milk for rearing the marsupial pouch young from a very early age. They kind of need that first little few days in mum's pouch to get the good antibodies and things that come across from mum, but then after that you really can hand-rear them and that's done quite commonly for abandoned marsupials. So I think it's something that you could easily gestate in a largish type marsupial, have it go into the pouch, and then you could do that final stage of rearing with some of these artificial milks that we have.

Robyn Williams: Unlike a puppy, it's the size of a little worm.

Andrew Pask: Exactly, so it's a lot easier for mum to give birth, and a lot easier for us when you're trying to do these sorts of de-extinction experiments.

Robyn Williams: Getting to the next stage, some of the answers, let me just mention a book called How to Clone a Mammoth by Beth Shapiro who lives in the States, and she's against cloning the mammoth, for two reasons. One of them is she suggests that you couldn't necessarily make it effectively by handling the DNA that one or two mistakes and you've got all sorts of huge problems. But overall the problem is one of the environment. How do you solve the problem of where it will go?

Thomas Hildebrandt: There's a third aspect. To clone a mammoth you have to work with Asian elephants, and Asian elephants are CITES 1 animals and you are not allowed to do experiments on them. To modify an oocyte of Asian female is not allowed. So actually there is a legal aspect...

Robyn Williams: You can't have the surrogate.

Duan Biggs: Yes, and also not the oocyte donor because that would be the first aspect, you need an oocyte from an Asian elephant, which you modify with CRISPR-Cas, it's a gene editing technique, that is actually by law not allowed. And then the other experiment would be the embryo transfer into an Asian elephant. That would be also not allowed.

Robyn Williams: I've heard about artificial wombs. Is that serious, for an elephant or a mammoth?

Duan Biggs: No, the artificial womb is only for the last fifth of the pregnancy.

Robyn Williams: That's enough.

Duan Biggs: But what you do with the four-fifths before, the implantation? That is a totally different issue. So the artificial womb is developed for premature human babies to reduce the cost of having them in incubators, and that was shown in lambs very impressively, but it is the last part of the pregnancy. The implantation and the growing from the embryo to a foetus, nobody can do that artificially.

Robyn Williams: That's still a couple of months, isn't it.

Duan Biggs: That's more, the pregnancy length is 22 months.

Robyn Williams: Yes, but the last part, the last fifth.

Duan Biggs: The last part would be maybe three months...

Robyn Williams: In an artificial womb.Â

Duan Biggs: But then the 19 months, you have to use an Asian elephant, and that is not allowed. The number of Asian elephants is down to 30,000, it's a very fragile population. It's a totally different scenario to African elephants, and therefore I think it is very unrealistic that it will happen soon.

Robyn Williams: I see. So, woolly mammoths. Passenger pigeons, I think there were 3 billion of them at one stage. If we recreated them, where would they go? The gastric brooding frog. Do you remember we had that actually on the Nature of Australia series, and the little creature gave birth because...in the stomach, all those eggs, brooding there, and then you've got these tiny frogs coming out of the parent's mouth, 40 of them running off. The most extraordinary sight. And then the actual frog became, it seems, extinct in Queensland. So what would you choose, which creatures to pick, number one or number two?

Andrew Pask: The thylacine...

Robyn Williams: Yes, I thought you'd say that!

Andrew Pask: But I think the important thing here is the distinction between cloning as we know it and then de-extinction science as we are talking about here tonight. So the real big difference is that we can do animal cloning really well, we do this with sheep and cattle, tonnes of livestock species all the time, mice we are very proficient at it, humans if you believe the science last year, you can do all these sorts of things really robustly, but that's when you start off with a living cell. So you've already got that cell and all the chromosomes intact, and that's quite different to this process of de-extinction. You still need to have a living cell, that's something we still can't make as scientists. So what we have to do is start off with the template of another species and then really start to edit these differences onto that background genome.

So with the case of the mammoth you would take your Asian elephant DNA and then you would sequence your mammoth, find out where all the differences lie between their two genomes, and then you edit all of those differences onto your elephant background. So you're trying to turn your elephant DNA now into a mammoth DNA strand basically. Once you've got that, you've got your living cell now that is mammothised, and you can then inject that into an egg and then transfer that egg into a surrogate animal and then have it give birth to your extinct species.

But the thing that's really important for everybody to know and one of the things that Beth Shapiro is really against with the de-extinction debate, is what exactly is this animal going to look like that you bring back, how close to a real mammoth is that going to be, because we are engineering an elephant genome to look like a mammoth. But there's a lot of that space in the genome that we really don't understand that well still, and so there's a lot of work that still needs to be done in the background to really explore the genome more, start to understand more about how all those different changes are really profound and which ones really make a big difference, and then making the choice of going in and making those edits to recreate your extinct species.

Robyn Williams: Yes, but Andrew, Duan, I want a dodo.

Duan Biggs: Correct, yes, I do want a dodo as well...

Robyn Williams: What are you going to do for me?

Andrew Pask: Well, you've got to get your cell of a closely related bird species that's still alive, so some sort of pigeon species, yes, and then the DNA in bird feathers is actually really well preserved and very intact, there's hundreds of dodo specimens. One of the things that this de-extinction science is really showing is the value of museum collections in particular. We can go into these museum collections now and we can collect tiny parts of that tissue and then sequence the entire genome and we can learn so much just from looking at that DNA. It's really staggering, the amount of information you can get from just having that blueprint in hand, but then you can start to really think about going down this road of then editing a closely related animal's genome.

The nice thing about the mammoth is it really is quite closely related to Asian elephants, and so there's not that many changes that need to be made. The thylacine doesn't have a really close living relative, so the closest would be a numbat, but they eat ants. So it's not the best genome to start with. The Tasmanian devil is a little bit further away, but it is at least a carnivore, so that might be something that's a little better to start off with, but they are the kinds of questions that we are exploring. And by doing this kind of science we're going down and figuring out exactly how onerous these tasks might be.

Duan Biggs: Well, I think if you're asking me personally, as a birdwatcher and speaking selfishly I would love to see a dodo, but that's just me. If I'm speaking as a scientist and informing how we as society should think about this, one way is to start with the already existing IUCN Red List, World Conservation Union red list, and it's what the global conservation community uses. You start on the one end with the species that's of least concern, something that might be vulnerable, endangered, critically endangered, extinct in the wild like the northern white rhino, and then extinct. And I think what we are talking about here, we're saying how far away is the dodo, how expensive is it, how risky is it, versus, say, something that's more recently extinct like the thylacine.

Robyn Williams: Kerrie, this is exactly where you come in because that's what you got your prizes for, looking at the landscape, what it costs, what's feasible. How are you going to make that decision and about which creatures and how?

Kerrie Wilson: What I'd encourage the proponents of de-extinction to do is really sit back and go; what are you fundamentally trying to achieve here? So we've heard a couple of objectives being thrown around. I'm not getting a clear line on the objectives, I know that Duan just wants to get birdwatching, you've got your own objective. But fundamentally we want to bring a species back so that it can perform a role, an ecological role. What's the point of bringing back a species just for the sake of it? So the art and science of making a good decision is just being clear about what you're trying to achieve. And the trick to working out what we are trying to achieve is just keep asking why. Why do we want to do this? On average, if you ask why five times, you get to your fundamental objective.

Robyn Williams: Well, I like wolves and I like to bring them back to national parks and I like to do that not just to look at them but because I think that what they do, even though they hunt elk or moose or whatever, what they're doing is bringing back a balance to the landscape so that the plants and the trees which were being shredded by those ungulates are now not so much, and you've got the balance restored.

Kerrie Wilson: That's deeper ecology, we're going to bring back the species. That's understanding that that whole ecosystem...so there's part of making a good decision, you bring together that data, you bring together your model of your ecosystem, and then you start looking at your levers, you know, what activities could I take in order to get a better overall result for biodiversity in this extinction crisis that we are in. There are a range of activities that we could undertake. We could stop destroying the environment as it stands now, stop those damaging activities, through to we could work in the lab on these types of activities that we're talking about today. That sort of information all needs to be put on the table in order to make a good decision. Then the sweet spot is you can then start to look at what the trade-offs are, what are the opportunity costs associated with these things.

Robyn Williams: And can you experiment? Have you got time to experiment? Are people patient enough?

Kerrie Wilson: I would be really concerned about experimenting in this space, but there are consequences associated with reintroducing a species to an environment that it's been removed, around pathogens and disease spread, so experimentation in this space is costly, and it could potentially have flow-on effects for ecosystems.

Robyn Williams: Yes, I'm just thinking about the woolly mammoth, and if you look at the way the ice and glaciers are disappearing, where would they go if the permafrost is melting?

Thomas Hildebrandt: One of the arguments of the pro-mammoth faction is that mammoths actually have such wide feet that they compress the snow in Siberia, and compressed snow melts less than normal snow, and so to avoid global warming that would be one very simple argument. But I think the mammoth project, it's more a scientific exercise than it is actually a conservation project. You have a lot of species which are close to the brink of extinction, we should focus on them. We have species which played a very important key role in ecosystems which we don't save or the conservation efforts we do right now, like protecting a habitat. One is the Sumatran rhino, the northern white rhino is nearly gone, the Javan rhino belongs to this group. So there are key species which are really important for ecosystems, and I think we should focus on them and not on a scientific exercise.

Robyn Williams: Can I have one more wild idea? In Tasmania someone has suggested...a professor at the University of Tasmania, that because there is so much tinder in the forest and fires are all over the place, 85 fires in the winter in Tasmania, why not import elephants?

Duan Biggs: I think Kerrie's point of thinking what the objective is, if it's to reduce the risk of forest fire there might be less controversial and simpler ways of getting there than introducing elephants to Tasmania.

Robyn Williams: Let's have another question from Twitter. How is this going to help us in the long term, especially concerning climate change, as it's a big issue now? Well, you've mentioned one aspect of the theoretical woolly mammoth, but looking after the animals, will it make a serious difference?

Thomas Hildebrandt: I can't answer the climate change, but I can give you another example. Central Africa has a very complex ecosystem, and disturbing this ecosystem, we have seen that on the west coast of Africa HIV was born there, Ebola was born there. We don't know really what it means losing such an important landscape architect in this very important habitat. Maybe bats travel out of this region and they carry a lot of nasty germs which have really devastating effects on humankind. And so I think it is also the human health, the one-world concept that we should keep these ecosystems intact to protect ourselves against these kind of new emerging diseases.

Robyn Williams: I'll just give you an example of the scale of things that could happen. I broadcast actually research from Switzerland done by an international team, and that is they looked+ Â down from the sky and wondered how many trees there are on Earth, and the old-fashioned idea was 400 billion. And then they did not just from the sky but counting on the ground as well so that you could get a much more accurate figure, and it turned out to be there are 3 trillion. And there is room for another 1.2 trillion. There is room. In other words, if you planted these trees you would nearly solve the climate problem and you'd create far more complex ecosystem available. Does that turn you on?

Kerrie Wilson: Yep...

Robyn Williams: You could hardly say no.

Kerrie Wilson: We talked about the tools in the toolbox. Those tools are out there, they are ready for us to use in the climate change arena, and I think increasingly the public is aware of these impacts. We are ready to go with that now, so let's get them off the shelf and start deploying those tools.

Robyn Williams: Indeed.

Andrew Pask: I think one of the interesting things with the climate change is currently it's happening too fast for animals to evolve and to keep up with such a rapid increase in temperature that we are seeing globally. But this is, again, one of those things where the de-extinction science, one of the fringe benefits that is coming from it is it's really pushing science forward in terms of our ability to generate artificial eggs and sperm and we can very quickly generate lots of species diversity or other ways that we can actually go in and edit animal genomes to introduce diversity to those backgrounds where you have really struggling species, and it can actually help really push the evolution of species to occur faster or more rapidly so we can help them actually start to respond to changes like this that happen so quickly in our environment now.

Robyn Williams: Yes, in a minute we will look at the difference between these various toolboxes and the ecosystem one. However, I'd like now to take a moment to acknowledge the important work carried out by museums around the world, and in particular in this instance the Queensland Museum network. Beyond the important role of connecting the public face-to-face with objects of our own and lost cultures, there are many scientists working behind-the-scenes undertaking important research, carrying out conservation projects, preserving objects and animals, to not only capture this moment in time but also to ensure our future is diverse and bright. So let's take a look inside the cupboards, drawers and labs of the Queensland Museum.

Video audio: The Queensland Museum houses a large collection of fauna specimens that document the biodiversity of Queensland and beyond. When changes become too great and the species becomes extinct in the wild, museum collections are one of the few places to see and study them.

Paradise parrots lived in open woodland and forests with a grassy understory. The last confirmed sighting was in 1927.

The last known the thylacine from the wild was captured in 1933 and died three years later.

The burrowing bettong is a small macropod that once lived in much of the arid and semiarid regions of the continent. These old museum skins are the only evidence that this species occurred in Queensland.

The last specimen of the desert rat kangaroo was collected from 1935, with reports occurring during some wet seasons up to 1975.

The Bramble CayÂ melomys occurred only on this small cay in the Torres Strait. After drastic inundation by ocean destroying its vegetation, the species is now declared extinct.

Extinctions have always occurred, but as humans impose their needs and expand their wants on the environment, so too the impact extends on the other species we share this continent with. And for many this impact is becoming too great.

Robyn Williams: Queensland Museum. Last time I looked when I was president of the Australian Museum Trust, that's the Australian Museum in Sydney, I think more people went to museums than go to football matches. Is that still the case, do you know? Let's assume so. Cheers us up. But I saw a bettong there, not the one I was going to mention, the eastern bettong which I think was released around Canberra, and I think this rewilding, they did not survive.

Kerrie Wilson: I guess that's the risks associated with these types of activities. And one of the considerations that doesn't often get airplay around rewilding is the ongoing effort that needs to be put into place to manage and maintain those populations, monitor them and evaluate how those populations are tracking. That's that long-term costing that usually isn't accounted for in conservation programs for some odd reason. This isn't just a one-off activity, these are long-term programs, and those programs are often funded on three-year cycles, really short-term funding.

Robyn Williams: This third part of our discussion is really about playing God, who decides. And Andrew and Thomas, can you outline the de-extinction proposal that you are hoping to get approved for funding by the new Elon Musk. There he goes again, Elon Musk, he's in space, he's doing electric cars and he is also involved in the Foundation for Extinct Animal Revival, known as Elon's FEAR. What's going on there?

Andrew Pask: I think there's a great quote from Mike Archer, he was one of the first people to attempt to sequence the thylacine genome, and so he said we were playing God when we wiped them off the face of the Earth, and I'd like to think that we are playing the part of clever humans by trying to bring them back. And that's very much the tactic that I take. We have a social responsibility, we exterminated the thylacine, but if we get the technology and it does become cheap enough...I think right now it's really too expensive to try and think about doing these projects, but when the technology becomes cheaper and more efficient, as it undoubtedly will, I think it's a very real discussion then about bringing these animals back and reintroducing them to the environment.

I think this is one of the things that makes the thylacine such a great poster-child for de-extinction, is that the Tasmanian wilderness is very similar to how it was in 1936 when the last animal went extinct. The animals that ate it are still there, it still could move back into that food chain and that ecological niche and really have somewhere you could reintroduce such a species. The bigger question is what is that species going to look like, how much of a thylacine is that actually going to be? And that's something we've got to explore I think.

Robyn Williams: What is FEAR, that organisation?

Andrew Pask: I don't know, but I want their money so that we can do this. I think this should be their number one project.

Thomas Hildebrandt: I think we do not ideally fit into this scheme because we are working with species that are still alive or the biomaterial is still alive, and we use new technologies derived from regenerative medicine, like the stem cell technology, applying that to the conservation effort, and I think it's a little bit different approach, using advances, assisted reproduction, test-tube babies, surrogate mothers, and also stem cell technology to produce artificial gametes, which is a totally different field of research compared to the gene editing and the artificial making of extinct species. I think we are doing quite an important job by bringing back the key species which are on the top of any...

Robyn Williams: Yes, but who decides that? How does someone select a species?

Thomas Hildebrandt: I think there are quite sound studies on service, on function of the southern white rhino in the southern hemisphere of Africa, so the white rhino plays a very important role in this area, and the same you can expect from central Africa, from the northern white rhino, which lived in a totally different environment, and hundreds of species are dependent or indirectly dependent on that. Only the faeces of a rhino provides hundreds of insect species. So it has the? which gives pathways for little antelopes. So I think the rhino is a key element in the ecosystem, and taking that out you disturb the system quite a lot.

Robyn Williams: Yes, it's become iconic. But Kerrie, there are lots of non-iconic creatures which could be brought back and could be the basis for all sorts of things. What would you go for?

Kerrie Wilson: Yes, it's pretty compelling. I'm coming along in this conversation. These guys are starting to shift me in my original position around this. The thylacine argument is quite compelling. It's recent, it's not going to disrupt the ecosystem as it currently stands, it's going to play a really critical and important role. But here's the flip side. So you've been to the University of Tasmania display for these thylacine. It's great. The last time I was there I just stood there and watched people as they came in, and the reaction is really tangible. You can feel this 'oh geez, that's what we did, we had a bounty on these animals, we were getting out there and making a heyday associated with this species'. And part of the beauty, if I can say it, of watching that reaction is the educational program of 'don't do this again, stop this destruction of biodiversity'.

And so part of me thinks if we go down the line of bringing the thylacine back, we've lost that real impactful...in your generation, in the generation of your parents, you have destroyed this incredible species, look what you've done. And so I think that part plays a part in this in terms of who decides as well and what species do we tackle, because there's the ecological benefits that we've spent discussing but there's the broader socio-economic context associated with these questions as well, and every one of these decisions that we make and how we use our money for biodiversity conservation will have different impacts on how community engage in this issue as well.

Robyn Williams: It's interesting, do you remember the night parrot?

Kerrie Wilson: Yes.

Robyn Williams: We made a...well, my colleagues made one for the BBC about what seems to be the discovery of the night parrot, and it's gone around the world. You know, little birdies, we've got zillions of birdies, why should people care so much? And they do. It's very interesting. Has anyone asked them, why do they care about these things?

Kerrie Wilson: We do, and now we've got some really great data analytic tools in our toolbox to measure sentiment, to look at people's reactions to particular conservation issues, to trawl the internet, look at those Twitter feeds that are coming up here and the responses that people and the reactions that people are having to particular issues. So there's some really clever ways to measure sentiment around particular issues as well, and de-extinction would be I think a really great topic to throw out to the public and ask the question; should we do this? If so, what species? And my feeling around that question of what species is why wouldn't I just ask my two little boys, because we are spending this money to rectify the impacts that we've had for their future benefit. So like the climate change debate, you ask the people coming through schools now, and they're saying, come on, hurry up, move on with it, you should be solving this problem now, what are you guys doing? And so you think that's a really critical part of this. We think that we understand what our kids are going to want in the future but we really should be asking those voices and getting those voices.

Robyn Williams: There's a term we haven't used particularly and that's rewilding. In other words, putting animals back where they once were. How have those experiments gone? I mentioned the wolves back in the national parks, so far a mixed success. How has rewilding gone?

Thomas Hildebrandt: There are quite successful programs compared to the Australian one. There's the Californian condor, the black footed ferret, the Przewalski's horse, that's an ancestor of our horses...

Robyn Williams: The P-horse.

Thomas Hildebrandt: Yes, the P-Horse, the Przewalski's horse.

Robyn Williams: Say it again. Polish, is it?

Thomas Hildebrandt: Yes, it's a Polish term. If you pronounce it like it is written it would be Przewalski.

Robyn Williams: And is it true it was almost like one of the original horses way back?

Thomas Hildebrandt: A recent study actually showed that it is an escaped domestic horse. When humans started to domesticate horses early on, maybe 10,000 years ago, that is a clutch which escaped back to the wild, so it has some traits of a domestic horse. That is at least the opinion of some of the scientists.

Robyn Williams: And it's doing quite well in the wild now, is it?

Thomas Hildebrandt: Yes, it is, in Inner Mongolia and Mongolia, so there are different sites where it was reintroduced. In the beginning it was quite hard for them with the wolves, with the cold weather, but they are doing quite well now.

Robyn Williams: And you're listening to The Science Show on RN, and a panel at the World Science Festival in Brisbane, on Bringing Them Back, the possibilities of de-extinction.

Andrew, what is a Biobank?

Andrew Pask: This is where we can take tissue from preferably living animals and freeze down those cells and create sort of a frozen repository or a frozen zoo so that we can capture the diversity of a species in time and keep that frozen so that if we lose that from the current population, the hope is that we can reintroduce some of that diversity back in when those populations start to undergo a crash. I think this is something that has become really to the forefront now, we are facing this mass extinction, and people are getting really engaged now in growing these cells now, these fibroblasts that Thomas spoke about before, turning them into stem cells, freezing those stem cells down and having a proper tissue repository for those species.

I guess the big risk there is that people then don't become complacent about still not trying to aggressively conserve those species that are left, thinking that now we have a deep-freeze stockpile of those animals, so that if everything goes pear-shaped we can just bring them back again. It's still not the best thing to do, it's sort of our worst-case backup scenario, but it at least creates that tangible backup that we have, that we don't have to go down this route of de-extinction where we are editing some other species to look like the animal that went extinct, but instead we actually captured before that animal disappeared those living cells and froze them down and we can reanimate, thaw out those cells and reactivate them and make them active again. So it's a much preferable way of preserving that animal or that species than then trying to go down this road of de-extincting it and editing something else.

Robyn Williams: Thomas, what about your work with the pandas using your techniques?

Thomas Hildebrandt: Yes, the pandas, there are about 1,000 individuals in the wild...

Robyn Williams: They are pretty slow with sex though aren't they?

Thomas Hildebrandt: Yes, most of the pandas in captivity are produced by artificial insemination and that is one of the aspects, working with the Chinese colleagues, to include every panda so that we can conserve the genetic diversity of the individuals which are kept in captivity. The panda is not only the cutest mammal I think but it has also some very interesting biological traits. For example, it's the only carnivore we know which is a vegetarian. There is no other carnivore which lives a vegetarian life. It can eat cyanides which are occurring in the bamboo shoots, and it has the largest testicles in the bear family.

Robyn Williams: How come?

Thomas Hildebrandt: Yes, and not only do they have the largest testicles, they only have a descent of the testicles after 4 to 5 years, so that the male offspring can live with the father without being a competitor to the father, the sister has to leave. So I think to understand the panda testicular biology, maybe this was a new tool to recognise testicular tumour in humans much earlier. So you have to see the full function and the service evolution can provide us, not only see the cute black-and-white panda but to understand biology before we erase it from our planet is very important.

Robyn Williams: Well, the tricky question now to all of you, and that is what if we did nothing? Because money, expense, if there's a collapse of economies or it gets difficult, we get something like Brexit and Western Australia decides to go off on its own, and if I have my way we'd get run from Wellington which seems to be far more able to get things done. But all sorts of distractions, political and otherwise. What if we just said, okay, the creatures can cope on their own? What would happen, do you think?

Duan Biggs: Well, ultimately we would suffer as people because the joy that I've seen in people around the world from so many different cultures and places when I lead expeditions or tours or give courses, when people go out into nature, like, wow, I've walked past this forest my entire life, I and 50 years old, I didn't know about these birds and animals that lived in there, you've shown them to me, I'm going to go in there whenever I have spare time now because this is fantastic, this enriches my life, just by being here...

Robyn Williams: Aren't humans extraordinary because we have relationships with so many different species. I don't know one other animal that has so many species routinely around it.

Duan Biggs: Exactly, and certainly from a conservation perspective we have the capacity to really appreciate that, and I certainly see it as my responsibility, and I think it's all our responsibility to make sure that future generations have that opportunity as well. If I look back and I think, jeepers, the dodo, it's gone, how sad is that, that would have been wonderful to have experienced that, and I do not want future generations to feel that way about species that are around now, or even species that are recently extinct that we can actually bring back.

Kerrie Wilson: Biodiversity gives to us these non-tangible benefits, and I think that's the part of nature that as humans we are all inclined to really value. Personally I'm not a species kind of person, I don't go birdwatching and I don't spend hours of my life looking for that particular...

Robyn Williams: You're an ecologist.

Kerrie Wilson: I'm an ecologist. But more than that, I guess I'm a landscape person, so I like to take a good look across the landscape and look at the complexity that exists within a landscape. And if you start eroding the arms and the legs and the fingers and the toes of a human, and you do the same on the landscape, you start to lose that beauty and the complexity that is nature. We've lost enough.

Robyn Williams: Indeed. Another question here; what would Darwin make of the discussion?

Andrew Pask: I think he'd love this discussion. I think it gets to the heart of evolution and everything, we start to understand about how species live in a particular environment, which is what he was really fascinated with and he was certainly fascinated by the diversity of life. And I think everything we are all talking about up here we are in agreement with is really trying to preserve that biodiversity and not to lose any more of it and to capture what we have right now and potentially even be able to bring some of our lost biodiversity back in the future. I think that encapsulates everything that would make Darwin happy.

Robyn Williams: On the other hand, I think the implication in that question is, okay, red in tooth and claw, he didn't say that but somebody else did, that is competition, and you survive and the survival creature is better, so just leave it alone and it will grow up. It's a sort of capitalist market view. If you've not got enough, you die out.

Andrew Pask: I think competition between species is quite different to between humans and another species. I think we have a distinct unfair advantage when it comes to wiping these animals off the face of the Earth, which is a bit different to two nonhuman species competing for a particular ecological niche. So I think in that regard I would say this is quite a different question.

An interesting question for the de-extinction debate though, if we do recreate a species, you're only bringing back one animal or a couple of animals, so it's a very similar question of then how do you bring that diversity back. But our answer to that is if we can start to make those millions of edits that we need to to that genome to actually de-extinct an animal, really the easy part would be then engineering in that diversity that you would need to make them have a really robust immune system or be resistant to certain sorts of diseases or impacts from the environment. So certainly we have a good understanding of what those parts of the genomes look like from healthy groups of marsupials, and so you can easily engineer that back then into a thylacine that you recreate.

Robyn Williams: Yes, that engineering is really powerful stuff, that CRISPR.

Andrew Pask: Yes, so there's a whole session I think at the World Science Festival talking just about CRISPR, but it really is the thing that pushed this whole field forward, is this ability to very easily and reproducibly make those edits to the genome en masse. So that was really the roadblock to the extinction, was we could make edits one at a time, and you had to sequence all 3 billion base pairs to make sure you had your one edit in the right place and everything looked okay. But now we can do that on a much larger scale, still not large enough to make it really something that we could do tomorrow for a thylacine, but certainly that is getting much better all the time.

Robyn Williams: To end, I'd like you to play God again and choose an animal to bring back that has been extinct. I've already chosen the dodo. There's something about me and dodos that kind of go together, their sweet smiling faces, and you know, they were in Alice in Wonderland and various other wonderful stories from way back. So, Duan, what would you choose to bring back an extinct animal from way back that you'd like...?

Duan Biggs: Well, if you've chosen the dodo, I'll go with the elephant bird in Madagascar.

Robyn Williams: Describe it.

Duan Biggs: As I understand, it was a bird like an ostrich but much bigger, as tall as a giraffe and like a giraffe feeds off the trees at the top of the canopy, and the early settlers there didn't take too long to wipe them out. That would be fantastic if that could come back.

Robyn Williams: I'd quite like the moa as well from New Zealand.

Duan Biggs: Indeed, the moa, and with the Haast's eagle to go with it that used to feed on the moa chicks, that would be a nice ecosystem to have back intact.

Andrew Pask: Giant birds running around would be truly terrifying, it would be like a pack of velociraptors I reckon. I don't think you need to ask me this question surely, everybody knows what I'd say, it's the thylacine, it should definitely be the one we bring back.

Robyn Williams: After the thylacine, going back further?

Andrew Pask: I would say a mammoth, I would love to see a mammoth, I think they truly are...and again, another one of those species that really captures people's imaginations. I think just a magnificent beast, and to see it would be truly amazing.

Kerrie Wilson: I don't want to be asked this question.

Robyn Williams: Why not?

Kerrie Wilson: I'm not the person that should be asked this question. At the moment I want to get on the phone and ask my seven-year-old son, you know, what do you want to see come back?

Robyn Williams: T Rex.

Kerrie Wilson: Probably, it probably would be T Rex. No, that's not going to happen. For me it's not a question that I want to answer.

Thomas Hildebrandt: I stay with Kerrie. So if you don't accept the northern white rhino from my side then I don't want...

Robyn Williams: But it's still here. Just.

Thomas Hildebrandt: No, it's practically extinct. Two infertile females and no male on the planet, so I think if we don't act with the technology I described, they will be gone in 10 years time.

Robyn Williams: Well, another thought experiment, it just so happens that I have Denisovan genes, you have some Neanderthal genes, 2% of you is Neanderthal, I can see from here...

Thomas Hildebrandt: Thanks!

Robyn Williams: Now, the Denisovans, and you know about Svante Pääbo's work in Leipzig, he got some of the work out, and at Wollongong they've just looked again at Denisovans and we may have enough DNA at least to do something, from what you describe Andrew, would you bring back a Denisovan?

Andrew Pask: When you start talking about the hominins I think you start to move into very dicey territory. So I'd say I'm going to stick with the thylacine. I think we can leave Neanderthals and Denisovans where they are perhaps.

Robyn Williams: I think a Denisovan would be quite good in Canberra, don't you? Well, we've heard about the possibilities, the ecosystems, the understanding of how culture can be so important in bringing people back to understand the animals that surround them, how you can change how we live so that we can live with nature effectively and not in a way that sacrifices our well-being. Thomas has indicated that we can live for another 300 years so that we are invested in the future. But there are ways in which we can effectively make a huge difference, and it has all happened in the last 10 or 20 years, it's been a complete revolution. And I think the sensibilities about why we love these animals, the hushed tones when you actually saw the thylacine there seeming to be alive and seeming to be back with us, it's quite extraordinary. Would you please thank the panel? Thank you very much indeed.

Our panel at the World Science Festival in Brisbane was: Thomas Hildebrandt from the Leibnitz Institute in Berlin; Professor Kerrie Wilson, executive director Institute for Future Environments at QUT; Associate Professor Andrew Pask from the University of Melbourne; and Duan Biggs, senior research fellow, Griffith University in Brisbane.

Next week on The Science Show: the Moon, of course; data, how it could be worth billions of dollars for Australian industry; and the University of Tasmania, how it's uniting the state, or trying to. I shall talk to the university's new vice-chancellor, Professor Rufus Black.

Production by David Fisher. I'm Robyn Williams.

urn:contentItem:457Y-MFB0-0197-52B8-00000-00<published>1997-08-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FINANCE; Pg. 38</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>FARMERS PREPARE TO WEATHER EL NINO'S RETURN  / INDONESIA - A SPECIAL SURVEY</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>JAMES J. FOX</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ALL meteorological indications are that the southern hemisphere is entering another El Nino phase.</p><p nitf:lede="true">This prospect, after the three-year El Nino from 1991 through 1994, poses immense challenges to Australia and Indonesia.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> During an El Nino phase, the patterns of heaviest precipitation shift eastward depriving both countries of much-needed rain.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>Like Australia, Indonesia must live with the climactic consequences of this southern oscillation. El Nino's effects in Indonesia may not be as dramatic as those in Australia, but because it has an impact on a vastly larger population, the problems it poses are greater.</p><p> Despite Indonesia's monsoonal climate, El Nino sharply reduces rainfall throughout much of the country.</p><p>Indonesia experienced a marked decrease in its rainfall in 1982-83 and again, to a lesser degree, in 1987. This was followed by the long El Nino of the 1990s.</p><p> El Nino reduces rice yields and thereby significantly affects overall national production. Since 1987, this has put a damper on Indonesia's attempts to achieve ambitious rice increases in line with a growing population and rising consumption.</p><p> As the agricultural year progresses, there is a follow-on effect for secondary crops such as maize and soybean.</p><p> In the islands east of Bali, El Nino's impact is even greater. The irregularity of the monsoon is as much a factor in cropping success as is the quantity of rain the monsoon brings.</p><p> Dryland farmers from Lombok to Timor are forced into repeated planting of precious seed to catch elusive rains. On Sumba and Timor, during a long drought, feed for cattle and water buffalo becomes almost as scarce as it does in Australia.</p><p> In the dry season, and especially during a drought, these farmers are invariably forced to leave their land in search of other work, increasing the numbers of the unemployed.</p><p> In the mountains of Irian Jaya, El Nino can cause heavy frosts at higher altitudes, destroying root crops of sweet potato and taro.</p><p> El Nino has an equally serious effect on Indonesia's forests. During the severe El Nino of 1982-83, East Kalimantan experienced a 68 per cent decrease in dry season rains.</p><p> A disastrous combination of sharply reduced rainfall, heavy logging, the accumulation of logging residues and local fire-based shifting cultivation produced perhaps the worst forest fire in modern history. Uncontrolled fires burnt for months throughout Kalimantan, damaging an estimated area of 2.8 to 3.5 million hectares. This fire affected an area equal to Victoria and Tasmania.</p><p> El Nino phases are often followed by a sharp swing to heavy rain -a phase now referred to as La Nina. Its rains may offer many benefits, especially for crops, but these rains are generally associated with an increase in pests and diseases.</p><p> The long-term consequences of this, for a major maritime nation like Indonesia, are as yet unknown. Australia's response to El Nino has been to improve its meteorological forecasting capacity. This forecast data is shared with Indonesia under a memorandum of understanding signed in 1995. This co-operation focuses on climate monitoring and seasonal forecasting.</p><p>Indonesian farmers retain painful memories of past droughts, but have little idea what living with El Nino may eventually entail. The first task is to provide them with better seasonal forecasts and with some understanding of the cycle of nature to which they, too, must adapt.</p><p> Professor James Fox is head of the Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, Australian National University</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
