urn:contentItem:5WK2-MJ31-F031-X001-00000-00Bringing them back2019-07-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:00ZLexisNexisScience Show11:19 AM AESTBringing them back

Robyn Williams: Imagine: you're sitting in the giant concert hall in Brisbane and it's packed. We're at the World Science Festival, and on stage, as the lights come up, is what looks like a large Tasmanian tiger. And it's moving. The audience is hushed as it watches, because the tiger is supposed to be extinct. Then they realise it's a giant marionette. This is The Science Show, on Bringing Them Back.

So you've seen a living Tasmanian tiger. He actually did a poo backstage. Bringing Them Back, the de-extinction debate. And in blunt terms we are losing nature before our very eyes, whole ecosystems gone with largely unknown consequences. The much talked about sixth extinction. Is it the one caused by humanity? Tragically the world has lost many of its animal species the last two centuries, and there is no sign of that trend easing. A recent World Wide Fund for Nature report states that since 1970, less than 50 years ago, human activity has wiped out 60% of Earth's wildlife, covering mammals, birds, fish...90% of fish gone. Reptiles and amphibians, not to mention the devastating loss of insects worldwide reported last month. It seems no place on Earth is immune and time is running out for conservation.

So what does modern conservation science look like, and should everything be on the table for consideration, including the option of reviving what has gone? With new genetic technologies we are not that far from the Jurassic Park idea of de-extinction becoming science fact. But will it ever be possible or practical to revive extinct species to save biodiversity and perhaps ourselves in the process? And if so, where do we start? And who decides what to save?

Our first guest is a leading expert on wildlife reproduction management from the Leibnitz Institute for Zoo and Wildlife Research in Berlin. Since 1997 his team have been working to rescue the northern white rhino from the brink of extinction, made harder by the recent loss of the species' last male. Welcome to the stage, Thomas Hildebrandt.

Next we welcome executive director of the Institute for Future Environments and a professor across the river at the Queensland University of Technology. Her two decades leading research into the science and policy of conservation has attracted numerous awards, including the Prime Minister's Prize for Life Scientist of the Year, and the Australian Academy of Science Nancy Millis Medal. Kerrie Wilson.

Hailing from the University of Melbourne, our next guest is an Associate Professor and ARC Future Fellow whose lab recently sequenced the genome of the extinct thylacine or Tasmanian tiger, the one you saw. In developing genetic tools to help conserve current marsupial species, their ultimate aim is to revive the iconic thylacine itself. Welcome Andrew Pask.

And our final guest is a senior research fellow at Griffith University's Environmental Futures Research Institute. Its work is international, to counter the illegal wildlife trade. Just back from Namibia, welcome Duan Biggs.

Well, there's the problem. Kerrie, I mentioned the sixth extinction. Are we in it, do you take it seriously?

Kerrie Wilson: Yes, we take it seriously. So 66 million years ago we had a similar extinction event, and about 25 years ago scientists started to think, you know, something is going on here, and we started taking note. They estimated about 25 years ago that we were losing species at around 10,000 times quicker than what we would in the background rate of species loss.

Robyn Williams: And in this circumstance should all avenues, all different techniques be open to science to try?

Kerrie Wilson: That's an interesting question. Every tool in your tool shed comes with a cost, and it comes with a benefit. And so we need to throw every tool at this question, but we also need to just unpack what do those tools look like and what will be the consequences associated with them.

Robyn Williams: And you'd like a debate, people discussing these things.

Kerrie Wilson: Yes, absolutely.

Robyn Williams: Thomas, during the extinction debate we are talking about saving things before they go away, disappear, and with rhinos you've just got a couple left. What're you going to do? You've got two females.

Thomas Hildebrandt: Yes, the northern white rhino is declared as a subspecies of the southern white rhino. It lives in central Africa and it was a very important landscape architect before it was declared in 2006 as extinct in the wild. Now there are only two females left, a mother and a daughter, Najin and Fatu. Both are infertile so actually that's the end of the story. Not fully because we have stored semen from four different males over the last 20 years, and we have fibroblast culture from 12 non-related individuals. So using the tool box of modern conservation technology we are capable of generating embryos from northern white rhinos by using the oocytes from these two females and the semen, which is cold preserved, and using surrogates mothers like southern white rhinos to produce northern white rhino offspring. We then use these two females to educate the offspring to be a northern white rhino, which is a very important element, the social education. We think this program is quite sound and we hope to be successful within the next three years with the first calf on the ground.

Robyn Williams: And how long does it take to educate the baby?

Thomas Hildebrandt: It has to live with the two remaining northern white rhinos to understand what it means to be a northern white rhino because a genome provides all of the morphology, all the physiology, but the knowledge, the social part is also very important and therefore it is a time pressing project because these two females, one is 18, one is 29, so time is running out.

Robyn Williams: You mentioned fibroblasts there, bits of tissue. What do you do with them?

Thomas Hildebrandt: Yes, fibroblasts are parts of the skin, you put them in cell culture and then they propagate, and when they propagate we call them fibroblasts. And in 2012 there was a Nobel Prize for transforming these cells into stem cells.

Robyn Williams: Stem cells, we can do anything, theoretically.

Thomas Hildebrandt: That needs quite a lot of research. Right now the mouse is the most advanced model. To transfer all this knowledge to a rhino or to an elephant or to a marsupial, that is quite a challenging task.

Robyn Williams: And apart from white rhinos, what sort of other collections have you got of these sperm and eggs and so on?

Thomas Hildebrandt: We have a comparable collection of biomaterial, like the frozen zoo in San Diego. So for us, even though Sudan died in March 2018, we declare him not as dead because we still have life elements from him, we have semen from him, we have fibroblasts from him, so there are all these blueprints to make a new Sudan is in our bank.

Robyn Williams: It's amazing, isn't it, the progress.

Andrew, we heard about the thylacine, the Tasmanian tiger. I think it was Mike Archer's voice we heard talking about the attempt they made a few years ago, at the Australian Museum, and at that stage we did a Catalyst program and my partner described it as trying to make some sentences out of alphabet soup, trying to stitch this stuff together. Is it still as hard as all that was back then?

Andrew Pask: We've actually rebuilt the entirely thylacine genome in my lab now, so we do have that complete blueprint of what it was to make a thylacine.

Robyn Williams: Astounding, isn't it. Where did you get the original DNA from?

Andrew Pask: This one actually came from one of the Museum Victoria specimens, so it was one of the very few pickled pouch young. So it was a little baby thylacine that was removed from its mum's pouch, the mum was shot as part of the bounty scheme that they had in Tasmania at the time. So they were offering £1 to bring pelts in, which was a huge amount of money back in the early 1900s, to bring in these specimens. And this mum had three babies in her pouch, and so they took each of them. But for some reason we still don't know, they would normally put these into formalin, which is actually very bad for the DNA, but these three miracle pups, we like to call them, went straight into ethanol and that actually preserved the DNA a lot better which meant we were able to get some really, really high quality long bits of DNA from these animals, which makes building that genome a lot easier, and we can be much more sure of the final genome that we have really representing what the thylacine DNA looks like.

Robyn Williams: And we've just seen a re-enactment on stage. Andrew, imagine you're looking at the offspring and they're alive. How would you feel?

Andrew Pask: Just blown away. I think it would be such an amazing thing if we could do that, to actually bring a species back, but particularly the thylacine. I think it's such an amazing marsupial species. It's completely unique. It was our only apex predator marsupial that lived into modern times. We don't have anything that sits at the top of the food chain like the thylacine does in any of our other marsupial species. It really was completely unique in every way, from its dog-like shape, the way it moved, its behaviour, right the way through to its hunting behaviours. It really was just an amazing animal that we unfortunately completely wiped from existence.

Robyn Williams: Yes, and there was a bounty on them and that was quite recently, one or two generations.

Andrew Pask: Yes, and they were aggressively hunted to extinction, as you could imagine, when there is that sort of price put on their head.

Robyn Williams: So Duan, you're working in Southern Africa, in Namibia, South Africa itself. What are the cultural feelings there about such creatures which still linger and which we want to preserve, how do local people react to what you're trying to do?

Duan Biggs: Yes, I think that's an important question and I think relevant, as Kerrie raised, de-extinction is one of the tools in the toolbox but there's a whole complex process of discussion and negotiation that needs to take place for it to be evaluated. And I was recently in Botswana, which is the country that sits between Namibia and South Africa, and there, as many of the audience here may have heard, there's been a recent furore because the government wants to bring back hunting of elephants included, and a lot in the international community are saying you cannot do that, that is wrong. Elephant hunting is morally wrong and you shouldn't do it. However, it's complex.

So in 2014 when hunting was banned there, the types of benefits that typically low income households and communities used to get from elephants disappeared, and also these people have to live with the costs of elephants. I'm not sure how many in the audience have lived with elephants but I have and they are great animals but if you are a small-scale farmer, they can be very damaging and they invoke a lot of fear. So now because of the hunting ban, people are not getting benefits and only living with the costs. And there was increasing antagonism towards these animals, and some of my colleagues in Botswana say increasing support for poaching activities of these animals because they were nuisance and only bringing costs.

So now Botswanan government is saying let's bring back hunting or talk about bringing back, and well managed hunting can support conservation of elephants and also support rural communities. However, many in the conservation sector internationally, animal welfare, animal rights groups are saying this is unacceptable. There are some big players calling for tourism boycotts of Botswana. So clearly in this complex issue, an animal we all love, like an elephant, we don't, as a conservation sector and as a society, have a good way of dealing with these issues, and it's going to be a similar challenge with de-extinction.

Robyn Williams: Duan, how much time have we got to solve that problem?

Duan Biggs: I think the sooner the better, there is urgency, because if you let problems like that lie, then you get a culture developing of antagonism towards wildlife. And there are places in Southern Africa where there is actually a culture of poaching evolves and that becomes the expected thing to do and that's not what we want to get to, so we need to move fast.

Robyn Williams: And you can get big money very quickly.

Duan Biggs: Yes exactly, and those are low, low income places. But to bring us back to de-extinction, there are discussions around should we bring back the woolly mammoth and thylacine. There are people that are going to bear costs, and where is their voice in the discussion? And these are considerations, together with the ones that Kerry raised, that need careful thought.

Robyn Williams: Andrew, we have a Twitter question; what would be the surrogate animal to bring back the Tasmanian tiger?

Andrew Pask: I think one of the nice things about marsupials is that they are born so small and then they complete their development in the mother's pouch. So you could actually use a variety of different marsupials to have that embryo be born from and transferred into a pouch of an eastern grey kangaroo or something that's very abundant. You'd have to work on something I guess that you have a lot of. But there's also really great artificial milk for rearing the marsupial pouch young from a very early age. They kind of need that first little few days in mum's pouch to get the good antibodies and things that come across from mum, but then after that you really can hand-rear them and that's done quite commonly for abandoned marsupials. So I think it's something that you could easily gestate in a largish type marsupial, have it go into the pouch, and then you could do that final stage of rearing with some of these artificial milks that we have.

Robyn Williams: Unlike a puppy, it's the size of a little worm.

Andrew Pask: Exactly, so it's a lot easier for mum to give birth, and a lot easier for us when you're trying to do these sorts of de-extinction experiments.

Robyn Williams: Getting to the next stage, some of the answers, let me just mention a book called How to Clone a Mammoth by Beth Shapiro who lives in the States, and she's against cloning the mammoth, for two reasons. One of them is she suggests that you couldn't necessarily make it effectively by handling the DNA that one or two mistakes and you've got all sorts of huge problems. But overall the problem is one of the environment. How do you solve the problem of where it will go?

Thomas Hildebrandt: There's a third aspect. To clone a mammoth you have to work with Asian elephants, and Asian elephants are CITES 1 animals and you are not allowed to do experiments on them. To modify an oocyte of Asian female is not allowed. So actually there is a legal aspect...

Robyn Williams: You can't have the surrogate.

Duan Biggs: Yes, and also not the oocyte donor because that would be the first aspect, you need an oocyte from an Asian elephant, which you modify with CRISPR-Cas, it's a gene editing technique, that is actually by law not allowed. And then the other experiment would be the embryo transfer into an Asian elephant. That would be also not allowed.

Robyn Williams: I've heard about artificial wombs. Is that serious, for an elephant or a mammoth?

Duan Biggs: No, the artificial womb is only for the last fifth of the pregnancy.

Robyn Williams: That's enough.

Robyn Williams: I see. So, woolly mammoths. Passenger pigeons, I think there were 3 billion of them at one stage. If we recreated them, where would they go? The gastric brooding frog. Andrew Pask: But I think the important thing here is the distinction between cloning as we know it and then de-extinction science as we are talking about here tonight. So the real big difference is that we can do animal cloning really well, we do this with sheep and cattle, tonnes of livestock species all the time, mice we are very proficient at it, humans if you believe the science last year, you can do all these sorts of things really robustly, but that's when you start off with a living cell. So you've already got that cell and all the chromosomes intact, and that's quite different to this process of de-extinction. You still need to have a living cell, that's something we still can't make as scientists. So what we have to do is start off with the template of another species and then really start to edit these differences onto that background genome.

So with the case of the mammoth you would take your Asian elephant DNA and then you would sequence your mammoth, find out where all the differences lie between their two genomes, and then you edit all of those differences onto your elephant background. So you're trying to turn your elephant DNA now into a mammoth DNA strand basically. Once you've got that, you've got your living cell now that is mammothised, and you can then inject that into an egg and then transfer that egg into a surrogate animal and then have it give birth to your extinct species.

But the thing that's really important for everybody to know and one of the things that Beth Shapiro is really against with the de-extinction debate, is what exactly is this animal going to look like that you bring back, how close to a real mammoth is that going to be, because we are engineering an elephant genome to look like a mammoth. But there's a lot of that space in the genome that we really don't understand that well still, and so there's a lot of work that still needs to be done in the background to really explore the genome more, start to understand more about how all those different changes are really profound and which ones really make a big difference, and then making the choice of going in and making those edits to recreate your extinct species.

Robyn Williams: Yes, but Andrew, Duan, I want a dodo.

Duan Biggs: Correct, yes, I do want a dodo as well...

Robyn Williams: What are you going to do for me?

Andrew Pask: Well, you've got to get your cell of a closely related bird species that's still alive, so some sort of pigeon species, yes, and then the DNA in bird feathers is actually really well preserved and very intact, there's hundreds of dodo specimens. One of the things that this de-extinction science is really showing is the value of museum collections in particular. We can go into these museum collections now and we can collect tiny parts of that tissue and then sequence the entire genome and we can learn so much just from looking at that DNA. It's really staggering, the amount of information you can get from just having that blueprint in hand, but then you can start to really think about going down this road of then editing a closely related animal's genome.

The nice thing about the mammoth is it really is quite closely related to Asian elephants, and so there's not that many changes that need to be made. The thylacine doesn't have a really close living relative, so the closest would be a numbat, but they eat ants. So it's not the best genome to start with. Duan Biggs: Well, I think if you're asking me personally, as a birdwatcher and speaking selfishly I would love to see a dodo, but that's just me. So the art and science of making a good decision is just being clear about what you're trying to achieve. And the trick to working out what we are trying to achieve is just keep asking why. Why do we want to do this? On average, if you ask why five times, you get to your fundamental objective.

Robyn Williams: Well, I like wolves and I like to bring them back to national parks and I like to do that not just to look at them but because I think that what they do, even though they hunt elk or moose or whatever, what they're doing is bringing back a balance to the landscape so that the plants and the trees which were being shredded by those ungulates are now not so much, and you've got the balance restored.

Kerrie Wilson: That's deeper ecology, we're going to bring back the species. Robyn Williams: And can you experiment? Have you got time to experiment? Are people patient enough?

Kerrie Wilson: I would be really concerned about experimenting in this space, but there are consequences associated with reintroducing a species to an environment that it's been removed, around pathogens and disease spread, so experimentation in this space is costly, and it could potentially have flow-on effects for ecosystems.

Robyn Williams: Yes, I'm just thinking about the woolly mammoth, and if you look at the way the ice and glaciers are disappearing, where would they go if the permafrost is melting?

Video audio: The Queensland Museum houses a large collection of fauna specimens that document the biodiversity of Queensland and beyond. When changes become too great and the species becomes extinct in the wild, museum collections are one of the few places to see and study them.

Paradise parrots lived in open woodland and forests with a grassy understory. The last confirmed sighting was in 1927.

The last known the thylacine from the wild was captured in 1933 and died three years later.

The burrowing bettong is a small macropod that once lived in much of the arid and semiarid regions of the continent. These old museum skins are the only evidence that this species occurred in Queensland.

The last specimen of the desert rat kangaroo was collected from 1935, with reports occurring during some wet seasons up to 1975.

The Bramble CayÂ melomys occurred only on this small cay in the Torres Strait. After drastic inundation by ocean destroying its vegetation, the species is now declared extinct.

Extinctions have always occurred, but as humans impose their needs and expand their wants on the environment, so too the impact extends on the other species we share this continent with. And for many this impact is becoming too great.

That's that long-term costing that usually isn't accounted for in conservation programs for some odd reason. This isn't just a one-off activity, these are long-term programs, and those programs are often funded on three-year cycles, really short-term funding.

Robyn Williams: And you're listening to The Science Show on RN, and a panel at the World Science Festival in Brisbane, on Bringing Them Back, the possibilities of de-extinction.

Andrew, what is a Biobank?

Andrew Pask: This is where we can take tissue from preferably living animals and freeze down those cells and create sort of a frozen repository or a frozen zoo so that we can capture the diversity of a species in time and keep that frozen so that if we lose that from the current population, the hope is that we can reintroduce some of that diversity back in when those populations start to undergo a crash. I think this is something that has become really to the forefront now, we are facing this mass extinction, and people are getting really engaged now in growing these cells now, these fibroblasts that Thomas spoke about before, turning them into stem cells, freezing those stem cells down and having a proper tissue repository for those species.

I guess the big risk there is that people then don't become complacent about still not trying to aggressively conserve those species that are left, thinking that now we have a deep-freeze stockpile of those animals, so that if everything goes pear-shaped we can just bring them back again. It's still not the best thing to do, it's sort of our worst-case backup scenario, but it at least creates that tangible backup that we have, that we don't have to go down this route of de-extinction where we are editing some other species to look like the animal that went extinct, but instead we actually captured before that animal disappeared those living cells and froze them down and we can reanimate, thaw out those cells and reactivate them and make them active again. So it's a much preferable way of preserving that animal or that species than then trying to go down this road of de-extincting it and editing something else.

Robyn Williams: Thomas, what about your work with the pandas using your techniques?

Thomas Hildebrandt: Yes, the pandas, there are about 1,000 individuals in the wild...

Thomas Hildebrandt: Yes, most of the pandas in captivity are produced by artificial insemination and that is one of the aspects, working with the Chinese colleagues, to include every panda so that we can conserve the genetic diversity of the individuals which are kept in captivity. The panda is not only the cutest mammal I think but it has also some very interesting biological traits. For example, it's the only carnivore we know which is a vegetarian. Thomas Hildebrandt: Yes, and not only do they have the largest testicles, they only have a descent of the testicles after 4 to 5 years, so that the male offspring can live with the father without being a competitor to the father, the sister has to leave. Robyn Williams: Indeed. Another question here; what would Darwin make of the discussion?

And I think everything we are all talking about up here we are in agreement with is really trying to preserve that biodiversity and not to lose any more of it and to capture what we have right now and potentially even be able to bring some of our lost biodiversity back in the future. I think that encapsulates everything that would make Darwin happy.

Robyn Williams: On the other hand, I think the implication in that question is, okay, red in tooth and claw, he didn't say that but somebody else did, that is competition, and you survive and the survival creature is better, so just leave it alone and it will grow up. Andrew Pask: I think competition between species is quite different to between humans and another species. I think we have a distinct unfair advantage when it comes to wiping these animals off the face of the Earth, which is a bit different to two nonhuman species competing for a particular ecological niche. So I think in that regard I would say this is quite a different question.

An interesting question for the de-extinction debate though, if we do recreate a species, you're only bringing back one animal or a couple of animals, so it's a very similar question of then how do you bring that diversity back. But our answer to that is if we can start to make those millions of edits that we need to to that genome to actually de-extinct an animal, really the easy part would be then engineering in that diversity that you would need to make them have a really robust immune system or be resistant to certain sorts of diseases or impacts from the environment. So certainly we have a good understanding of what those parts of the genomes look like from healthy groups of marsupials, and so you can easily engineer that back then into a thylacine that you recreate.

Robyn Williams: Yes, that engineering is really powerful stuff, that CRISPR.

So that was really the roadblock to the extinction, was we could make edits one at a time, and you had to sequence all 3 billion base pairs to make sure you had your one edit in the right place and everything looked okay. But now we can do that on a much larger scale, still not large enough to make it really something that we could do tomorrow for a thylacine, but certainly that is getting much better all the time.

Robyn Williams: Why not?

Kerrie Wilson: I'm not the person that should be asked this question. At the moment I want to get on the phone and ask my seven-year-old son, you know, what do you want to see come back?

Robyn Williams: T Rex.

Kerrie Wilson: Probably, it probably would be T Rex. No, that's not going to happen. For me it's not a question that I want to answer.

Thomas Hildebrandt: I stay with Kerrie. So if you don't accept the northern white rhino from my side then I don't want...

Robyn Williams: But it's still here. Just.

Thomas Hildebrandt: No, it's practically extinct. Two infertile females and no male on the planet, so I think if we don't act with the technology I described, they will be gone in 10 years time.

Robyn Williams: Well, another thought experiment, it just so happens that I have Denisovan genes, you have some Neanderthal genes, 2% of you is Neanderthal, I can see from here...

Thomas Hildebrandt: Thanks!

Robyn Williams: Now, the Denisovans, and you know about Svante Pääbo's work in Leipzig, he got some of the work out, and at Wollongong they've just looked again at Denisovans and we may have enough DNA at least to do something, from what you describe Andrew, would you bring back a Denisovan?

Andrew Pask: When you start talking about the hominins I think you start to move into very dicey territory. So I'd say I'm going to stick with the thylacine. I think we can leave Neanderthals and Denisovans where they are perhaps.

Robyn Williams: I think a Denisovan would be quite good in Canberra, don't you? Well, we've heard about the possibilities, the ecosystems, the understanding of how culture can be so important in bringing people back to understand the animals that surround them, how you can change how we live so that we can live with nature effectively and not in a way that sacrifices our well-being. Thomas has indicated that we can live for another 300 years so that we are invested in the future. But there are ways in which we can effectively make a huge difference, and it has all happened in the last 10 or 20 years, it's been a complete revolution. And I think the sensibilities about why we love these animals, the hushed tones when you actually saw the thylacine there seeming to be alive and seeming to be back with us, it's quite extraordinary. Would you please thank the panel? Thank you very much indeed.

Our panel at the World Science Festival in Brisbane was: Thomas Hildebrandt from the Leibnitz Institute in Berlin; Professor Kerrie Wilson, executive director Institute for Future Environments at QUT; Associate Professor Andrew Pask from the University of Melbourne; and Duan Biggs, senior research fellow, Griffith University in Brisbane.

Next week on The Science Show: the Moon, of course; data, how it could be worth billions of dollars for Australian industry; and the University of Tasmania, how it's uniting the state, or trying to. I shall talk to the university's new vice-chancellor, Professor Rufus Black.

Production by David Fisher. I'm Robyn Williams.

urn:contentItem:7V00-KWB1-2RG6-Y029-00000-00Firefighters struggle to contain Gippsland fire2009-02-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisAM8:09 AM AESTABCSimon LauderFirefighters struggle to contain Gippsland fire

TONY EASTLEY: In the Gippsland region, a fire which has claimed at least 17 lives is still burning, and even with favourable conditions firefighters are having trouble containing it.

AM's Simon Lauder is at the Incident Control Centre at Traralgon, which is just north of the fire.

And Simon joins us now. Good morning, Simon.

How are people there coping with the dreadful effects of these fires?

SIMON LAUDER: Traralgon and all of the many smaller communities in the Strzelecki Ranges in south, I've got to say, are doing it really tough, Tony.

The deaths in the fire have really shaken up the whole community. It's still really hard for people to talk about it because there's a sense that the crisis is now. There could be more deaths that we don't know about and of course the fire still burns. So for many, especially those in charge of controlling this emergency, it's a matter of deliberately postponing that grief and shock.

I met people at the relief centre who also didn't know yet if they had a home to go back to and some of those who do know their properties are destroyed have told me that there's a sense of denial. On the upside though, I met a woman who was elated because she found her friend's mother alive and well and she just had to go and find her friend and break the news to her.

TONY EASTLEY: Here in Wallan this morning it's been reasonable cool and of course there's been some light rain in parts of Victoria. What's the situation where you are?

SIMON LAUDER: Indeed it was quite chilly and there was bit of rain but the fire still threatens small communities between Churchill and Yarram and the rough and steep terrain of the Strzelecki Ranges is making it really hard to even get to the fire, yet alone contain it and there are several uncontrolled parts of the fire where there are no containment lines.

So putting those in when the weather's cool is the big challenge for the CFA at this stage, it's keeping their fighters very busy, even in the downtimes, especially in the downtime really. And whether or not people in those threatened communities need to stay or go, is something the need to decide. And the Country Fire Authority incident controller Barry Foss says it's a matter which also deserves more consideration in the future.

I spoke to Barry Foss a short time ago.

BARRY FOSS: The fire services have adopted particular philosophies over the years and that's come with the experiences such as Ash Wednesday, there's a lot of research being completed in relation to how the community should deal with it and how the fire services should operate. It will be a matter for future research as to whether those strategies are still appropriate in this day and age but that's a matter for the future. At this point in time we've still got a lot of work to do in controlling these fires.

SIMON LAUDER: And those strategies, are you referring there to whether people should stay or should they go?

That's correct I mean, we still maintain that the chance of property survival is to stay and protect your property if certainly you've prepared, and that's important, if you've prepared your property appropriately and you fit and able to do it, both physically and mentally, and I suppose this goes back to the point of whether people should decide to stay or go. If you are prepared, we're recommending that you do stay.

Are you concerned that the news will get worse in terms of the human toll?

Yeah look, there's a reasonable area of this fire that we haven't really had the opportunity to get personnel in because of the safety issues and today we're going to progress that and, you know, we're hoping that the toll doesn't rise but there's an expectation that it will.

TONY EASTLEY: Incident controller at the Churchill fire, Barry Foss.

Well our reporter Simon Lauder is on the line. Simon, is there any chance this Churchill fire will break out somehow?

SIMON LAUDER: There certainly is. It's 40,000 hectares and much of it is uncontained and as I mentioned and in the words of one officer here at the Control Centre, fire tends to pillar around a bit some times, but when the wind picks up, the game changes. It's really at the mercy of the wind. Some have still got a bit to run and indeed there are hotter temperatures expected later this week.

And if the fire starts heading north, it will, in its path will be the Loy Yang power generator and Traralgon is also to the north of the fire at the moment. Elsewhere in Gippsland, the Bunyip Forest fire is still burning in the direction of the Neerim junction, north of Warragul. In other parts of the state, the CFA is also worried about fires at Beechworth and the Murrindindi fire.

TONY EASTLEY: The fires tormenting people who have already lost so much. AM's Simon Lauder, thank you.

Simon at the Incident Control Centre at Traralgon.

urn:contentItem:53MX-SFC1-F09W-8218-00000-00Political stand-off only deepens industry 'crisis'2011-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisNEWS REVIEWViews OpinionPg. 16Political stand-off only deepens industry 'crisis'LENORE TAYLOR

The manufacturing "crisis", like everything else in Australian politics now, is unhappily wedged between Labor's weakness and the Coalition's populism. Steel industry job losses this week were just the start of the real world pain in the non-mining economy. Labor has tried to prepare for this crunch, but its general ineptitude left its biggest effort - the mining tax - hopelessly compromised and the rest largely unnoticed. A Labor government traditionally would be thinking about spending some money on the problem about now, beyond the $30 million for affected regions and a bringing forward of $100 million of steel industry assistance announced this week.

Not a bailout. And not spending in the misguided belief that it could substitute for long-term policies to keep Australian industry efficient and productive. But a 45 per cent appreciation of the currency over just two years is an almighty short-term shock for exporters to try to absorb, and no one thinks this is the end of the fallout. Some kind of targeted short-term investment allowance or tax break that might help manufacturing survive, or some kind of broader structural adjustment effort, would not seem unreasonable. Well, it would not seem unreasonable in normal political circumstances. But this is a government under siege. And the international economic uncertainty has already put a question mark over its promise to return the budget to surplus next year, a promise Labor made the benchmark of its economic credibility. The Treasurer, Wayne Swan, told a meeting of Labor backbenchers that the cabinet was "prepared to use the tax system" to help manufacturers. He mentioned the tax summit. A special cabinet taskforce has been set up to look at all policy options. But with the Prime Minister, Julia Gillard, already signalling more spending cuts to meet the surplus promise, the cabinet has to consider the financial cost and the political cost of returning another deficit. If Labor was faring a bit better politically, that decision might not be so hard. But its political capital is deeply, deeply in deficit. So far it has been left talking about industry "advocates" and global centres of excellence, and pointing to stuff it has already done, such as training programs and tougher anti-dumping rules announced in June. Which is all very well but it sounds about as effective as a water pistol against a raging forest fire. The manufacturing unions are not so constrained. They want the government to push harder for miners to use more local product, reasoning that the $430 billion in the investment pipeline should translate into quite a bit of local work. And they say miners should be forced to come up with local "participation plans" before their projects are approved. And the Coalition is speaking the unionists' language. The opposition's industry spokeswoman, Sophie Mirabella, says local companies are sick and tired of being told that anything a government might do amounts to protectionism. "We need to reframe the economic debate," she says. "People are sick of being told there is a level playing field internationally. People are sick of being told it is protectionist if you acknowledge the reality that there is not. "Subsidised foreign goods are distorting our markets ... we could do much more in terms of anti-dumping, we could do more in terms of getting major projects to use local content without breaching our international obligations, we could do more in terms of government purchasing ... and if that brings on the inevitable hysterical screams that we are being protectionist, we need to show that's just false, we need to shift the debate." She is preparing to do just that with policy announcements over the next couple of weeks. In other words, the Coalition is preparing to continue its raid on Labor's blue-collared heartland by outflanking the "party of the workers" from the left. But despite the fighting words, there are still a few things cruelling the credibility of the Coalition's new blue-collar pitch. For one, it is still promising a $500 million cut to existing automotive grants, which carmakers say would lead to the close of existing operations. Mirabella said she was in "detailed discussions" with the auto industry. But since the Coalition's razor gang is already looking for $70 billion in savings, Tony Abbott has not got much financial leeway either. And the Coalition is still promising to vote against the revised mining profits tax and scrap the programs to be funded from it. Despite BHP's $22 billion profit, the Coalition says the miners are paying "more than enough tax". For Labor, the tragedy of their predicament is that they did see this "manufacturing crisis" coming. Swan explained his original $99 billion (over 10 years) resource super profits tax in May last year, on the basis that the mining boom would make it very difficult for the "non-mining parts of the economy to retain workers and investment as they are drawn to the mining sector". "You may have heard of the 'Dutch disease' where the exploitation of natural gas in the 1970s is supposed to have 'hollowed out' the Dutch economy," he said in a speech to economists. If we had not heard of "Dutch disease" then, we sure have now. But of course, the Rudd government's remedy - the resource super profits tax - was smashed by a $22 million advertising campaign by angry miners, after Labor reneged on promises to consult on the details. And Rudd's prime ministership, already weakened by the backflip on the emissions trading scheme, was smashed, too. Julia Gillard quickly negotiated a compromise with just the three biggest miners, which raised only $38.5 billion over 10 years, meaning the proposed company tax cut supposed to help the non-mining parts of the economy had to be cut from 2 per cent to 1 per cent. And even that $38.5 billion relies on new, higher, but unpublished estimates of the volume and value of the minerals being exported. The Coalition, the Greens and the smaller miners strongly suspect the tax take from the major mining companies will be not much more than what they were paying before. And so our hollow political debate rolls on. The compromised versus the uncompromising. As the Treasury secretary, Martin Parkinson, said this week, the economy is facing bigger problems than it has for generations. But the government is scraping to find the political capital to meet the challenge and the opposition is driven by whatever will help it blast its way to power.

xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 185</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Security's just routine</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BY GEOFFREY NEWMAN</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">REMEMBER the part in Bambi where the tiny fawn loses her mother in a forest fire?</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The portrayal of the deer's death in the animated classic may seem innocuous these days compared with the violence to which children are exposed on television and in movies.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But the shock of seeing Bambi lose her mother seemed to hit a nerve.</p><p>"That has often been cited as an overwhelming example of the hidden horrors in the otherwise inoffensive Disney G-grade material," says Dr Peter Birrell, senior lecturer in psychology at the University of NSW.</p><p> "People allude to it so often that it obviously had an impact at the time."  It's just one example, Dr Birrell says, of the anxieties to which children are particularly vulnerable.</p><p> "Young children, when they reach a certain age and become aware of the possibility of loss, often tend to exaggerate the fragility of that (maternal) bond," he says.</p><p> "There are children in the six to nine bracket who think their parents are going to keel over tomorrow or disappear out the door."  Dr Birrell says such anxieties show that children live in a world where their security is easily threatened.</p><p> David and Alison Pryke of Chatswood have moved three times in the last 12 months and are acutely aware that Adrian, 7 and Juliet, 5 need a supportive environment.</p><p> "The kids didn't like leaving their first house but have settled in well here," says David.</p><p> After the first move, Juliet began asking where her mum and dad would be after they put her to bed.</p><p> David notes that the question has become part of Juliet's nightly ritual.</p><p> This, says Dr Birrell, is quite common in children.</p><p> "Young children will carry out ritualistic acts such as counting telegraph posts and not walking on cracks in the pavement in ways that suggest obsessive thinking," he says.</p><p> Often it arises from a fear that if they don't carry out these acts, something bad will happen to someone they care about.</p><p> This obsession with habit and routine is a way of dealing with a child's fear of disorder and while it would be considered pathological in adults, it is a normal part of a child's emotional development, says Dr Birrell.</p><p> "In spite of their alleged claims of boredom, the vast majority of children need a very ordered existence."</p><p> Order implies predictability which translates into a feeling of security.</p><p> David and Alison couldn't agree more.</p><p> "I think routine gives kids security. Our kids are really into routine," says David.</p><p> Both parents work full time but do their best to make sure their kids eat, bathe and go to bed at the same time each night.</p><p> "Our kids have their parameters; they know where they fit into things in family and day to day life," says David.</p><p> Dr Birrell fears that as children are exposed to more violence through film and television, parents will lose the security battle.</p><p> "I think a lot of children, well before they are adolescents, view the world essentially as a frightening, disturbing and unpredictable place," says Dr Birrell.</p><p> "When people talk about a loss of childhood, there is something in this notion."   </p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:53JS-GB41-F0JP-W463-00000-00Our produce comes first before NZ's2011-08-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 25Our produce comes first before NZ's

BY NOW your readers will be aware of the fire blight disease and the disastrous consequences that would follow should it arrive in our orchards on apple imports from NZ.

Pears are particularly vulnerable, and this industry would be virtually wiped out, leading to large scale unemployment and economic ruin for many other businesses as well.

Time is running short to influence the Government and Biosecurity Australia to protect Australian fruit.

Send numerous emails to Senator Joe Ludwig, Minister for Agriculture, at joe.ludwig@maff.gov.au

The priority should be to protect Australia's food supplies, not New Zealand's trade ambitions.

Margaret North,

Kialla

Orange imports closed factories

ON reading of the problems of SPC Ardmona and its battle with imports and the high dollar, let's go a decade or so back and you will find citrus (oranges) were the first to go from imports of juice concentrate.

At least six juice factories gone and now the Berry one in the MIA is the last large one left.

Both political parties are the same free-trade-at-all-cost and it doesn't seem to worry the Canberra bureaucrats as industry after industry goes. Where next?

Name and address supplied

Fire risk from forest logging

SHAUN Ratcliff, from the Victorian Association of Forest Industries, claims forests that have evolved over millions of years, containing trees and other plants that are many hundreds of years old, can be regenerated in the space of only 60 or so years (WT, July 13).

The fact is that each time a forest area is logged and ``regenerated'' according to forestry methods, it becomes less like a forest and more like a plantation, with gradual loss of biodiversity.

Forest logging increases forest fire risk, opening up the forest canopy and allowing sun and wind to penetrate thereby drying out the dense forest understorey.

The drying slash that is left after logging, containing the heads, branches and bark of logged trees, usually remains in the logged forest area for months before a regeneration burn is done, presenting a serious fire hazard.

So-called regeneration burning further dries out forest areas by killing understorey regrowth.

This results in a uniform, comparatively dry and thick regrowth of mainly eucalypt species, providing perfect fuel for a fire.

Stephen Chenery,

Anglesea

Rabbits to feed world hunger

IN response to Frank Raeburn's letter, ``How to feed a crowded planet'' (WT August 10), perhaps the answer to this pressing question is the humble rabbit.

With rabbits, low-quality fibrous vegetation can be converted to a higher-quality human food. This form of livestock farming could hold the key to feeding the world's hungry.

Countries with a shortage of high-quality grains and plant protein source, could benefit from the humble rabbit.

The advantages of rabbits over other livestock is significant.

In some countries, abundant inexpensive labour could also hold the key to the building of rabbit farms and the management of them.

Other positives are the sheer number of offspring a female rabbit can produce in a lifetime and how quickly young are developed from the time of a mating.

As much as so many farmers hate rabbits, the fact remains that the humble rabbit has almost unlimited potential.

Wayne Glennie,

Clunes

Wasteful water practices

I AM a 65-year-old self-employed farmer from Woodswell on South Australia's Coorong who spent 37 years irrigation farming on the north shore of Lake Alexandrina.

Although not now involved in using Murray Water, I feel qualified to make a few points.

1. South Australian irrigators have not had new allocations of Murray Water since December 1967 (some authorities say 1969). That is, no expansion except by buying water from interstate.

2. An extensive drainage scheme from as far south as Naracoote and Edenhope has been installed, and is discharging water into the Southern Coorong Lagoon at Salt Creek to help freshen the water.

3. Many of your correspondents seem to suggest that we (in SA) return to pre-1940. Do they also suggest to do that all the way up to the top of the river's system?

4. I suggest that wasteful and questionable practices are evident in the whole system, and that if we work together we can improve it, rather than being petty and abusive.

Lance Chaplin,

Tintinara, SA

Buyback scheme cost-effective

IT is frustrating to constantly see the Murray-Darling water buyback program portrayed as a pact with the devil while infrastructure modernisation is held up as a knight in shining armour. Both have their place in ensuring a long-term future for irrigation communities.

The best outcomes for rivers and communities are achieved when irrigation modernisation and water buyback work together to create high-value, highly efficient irrigation in the areas where it is most suitable and to provide transitional assistance for communities where it is not.

Selling water to the Government is actually popular with farmers. Every tender in the southern basin has been oversubscribed and most people are only selling a portion of their entitlement and remaining in irrigation.

The water buyback program is a highly cost-effective way of returning water to rivers and gives farmers an injection of cash to increase business flexibility, retire debt and stay in their communities.

If only groups like the National Irrigators Council would support these farmers and the option they have chosen, rather than making out that the only beneficiaries of buyback are the banks.

Juliet Le Feuvre,

Environment Victoria

Murray flows first-rate

I WOULD hope that common sense and logic prevails in the whole water debate of the Murray Darling Basin assessment.

Surely with the excellent flows of the last 18 months, plus the coming snow melt, would mean that there is ample time, to properly assess the flow needs, not just jump at shadows to tick environmental boxes.

The loss of any further agricultural production in this country will be a grave error of federal or state judgment.

Murray Roberts,

Strathmore, Vic

Missed chance with census

GIVEN the Gillard Government is so desperate to reduce its carbon footprint, why haven't they encouraged people to do the census electronically rather than by paper?

Think of all the trees cut down to make a paper form for all households.

What the Government should have done was take out ads on prime-time television well before hand to encourage people to register to do it electronically.

Then once the numbers were crunched, only print enough forms for those who did not register for lodging electrically.

Alan Barron,

Grovedale, Vic

urn:contentItem:7XD8-0XJ0-YB64-401F-00000-00A world without YouTube? It's unimaginable2009-12-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisINSIGHTPg. 25A world without YouTube? It's unimaginableCultureSteve Johnson

The video-sharing site has become huge in an astoundingly short time, writes Steve Johnson.

IT SEEMS inevitable and permanent now, as much a fixture in the global mind as McDonald's or bottled water.

But YouTube, it is easy to forget, did not exist when the decade opened.

It didn't exist in 2001 or 2002. There was no YouTube in 2003 or 2004, either.

Not until "Me at the zoo," a video of co-founder Jawed Karim standing in front of elephants at the zoo in San Diego, USA, was posted in April 2005, was there, really, a YouTube.

Yet despite being around for fewer than half of the past 10 years, the video-sharing service is the decade's most influential popular-culture force on the internet.

From Karim talking about the elephants' trunks in the still-available 19-second clip, it has spearheaded the availability of video on the Web, everything from golf tournaments, live, to episodes of popular sitcoms.

These developments threaten traditional delivery systems. YouTube became the clearing-house for the short, shared, "viral" videos that were a key to making internet culture into mainstream culture, and started to play a role in politics, especially in the 2008 US presidential campaign.

It developed as a kind of chaotic library, a reference resource for people seeking video of musical artists, old cigarette commercials or a news sensation. And it has championed the decade's DIY aesthetic: Skip the professionals, was YouTube's implicit message. Shoot your own video. Upload it here, fast and easy.

And, in the end, it doesn't matter so much if your backyard trampoline-stunt footage (ouch!) isn't great art; what matters is the validation it seems to get by being hosted on an external site.

With YouTube, if you wanted your friends to watch what you made, you didn't have to drag them into your living room and plug the camcorder into the TV.

You just sent them a link, and they watched it at the same website that has professional material by TV stars. The site echoed similar revolutions in writing, as blogs came to prominence, and in photography, as people shared photos on sites such as Flickr. But with YouTube, it was even more so, because the bar to getting videos shown in public had been higher.

Professional creators of content tried to fight YouTube for a while, policing their copyrights zealously and seeking takedowns whenever possible. But eventually, they decided they'd rather switch than fight. Deals were struck, and providers who didn't form their own YouTube channels to show highlights offered the equivalent of YouTube clips and more on their own sites or on professional aggregators, led by iTunes, from Apple, by Netflix, and by Hulu, a project of General Electric Co, News Corp and, later, Disney.

YouTube created the expectation that video would be available online, on demand, freed of network schedule or DVD. It got so big, so fast that Google was moved to buy the service for $US1.65 billion in late 2006, an admission that Google's own stab at a video-upload site, Google Videos, had lost.

It was quite a climb for the service that began with a clip of the zoo. Karim, Steve Chen and Chad Hurley had met while working at PayPal, the money-transfer service. Chen was a graduate of the Illinois Mathematics and Science Academy and, like Karim, had studied computer science.

But even as YouTube has become a ubiquitous brand, virtually the synonym for web-based video, it hasn't yet proved it can translate its enormous traffic into revenue. The site has struggled to integrate advertising in a way that won't alienate customers, who value its instant accessibility and lack of clutter.

And indeed, Hulu, which might be termed a professional version of YouTube, has announced that it will, next year, begin charging.

But the battle of getting people to pay for content on the web, or of getting content to pay for itself through ads, is a â€” possibly the â€” question of the next decade.

NOUGHTIES' 5 KEY WEB MOMENTS

1 2000: The (first) internet bubble bursts. Lots of people made a lot of money, lots of people lost a lot. But the collapseâ€™s effect, similar to a forest fire, cleared the way for a lot of new growth and a more mature, more reality-based web.

2 2001: The first iPod is introduced. Appleâ€™s portable player of music in digital-file format would pave the way for music sales on the internet (iTunes), challenging the share-with-everyonebut- the-creators model of Napster. iPods also, of course, would lead to the iPhone, which puts the world wide web of mobile entertainment, plus a phone, in peopleâ€™s pockets.

3 2001: Wikipedia begins. What Wikipedia proved was the potential to harvest the web for massive, non-professional collaboration, a lesson that political campaigns would soon take to heart.

4 2003: MySpace is launched. It would grow within three years to become the most popular social-networking service in the United States. In addition to paving the way for Facebookâ€™s growth in more recent years, MySpace demonstrated that many people absolutely wanted to have personal web pages and conduct social lives online. The service also became an effective vehicle for music promotion.

5 2006: Twitter is created. The site gives everyone from bored journalists to bored celebrities a place to jot and share their micro thought bursts.

While itâ€™s too soon to know the ultimate impact, the growth curve has been phenomenal.

ILLUSTRATION: ROBIN COWCHER

urn:contentItem:4P8H-NVB0-TXN5-S1D7-00000-00Elephants on a rampage guided back home1994-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 6Elephants on a rampage guided back homeJOHN RETTIE

A herd of about 50 wild elephants, driven from their natural habitat a week ago by a forest fire and the pressure of human encroachment, turned away last night from Calcutta, where local authorities had feared they could wreak death and destruction.

The elephants' rampage is the most dramatic incident yet in the unequal battle between man and wild animals for "lebensraum" in this country of 885 million people.

The animals fled their forest in West Bengal's neighboring state of Bihar a week ago. After blundering through fields, villages and small towns, confused, hungry and often angry as farmers attacked them with stones, spears and arrows, the elephants were at last diverted back towards their forest.

Six people were trampled to death by the animals during the first few days of their rampage. One man was crushed, according to the daily `Telegraph' of Calcutta, when he tried to ram a hot iron rod into the anus of one of the elephants.

A `Telegraph' reporter, Debashish Bhattacharyya, said: "The elders in the herd bore the torment with patience and trumpeted only occasionally to chase people away ... While the behavior of the elephants was restrained, the conduct of local people and state administration officials was beastly."

But in the past few days, a saner mood seems to have prevailed among the populace. Yesterday in Calcutta, Hindu priests began praying to appease Ganesh, the elephant god.

The villagers, instead of persecuting the animals, beat drums, waved torches and formed a human chain to turn them back to their forest sanctuary.

Trains were held up as the herd wandered back and forth across the railway line, and there were long traffic delays on the roads as lorries were parked to block the herd's path.

The elephants suffered casualties too. One of the two calves in the herd got stuck in a bog, where the best efforts of accompanying bull elephants to extract it were of no avail. West Bengal forestry officials later extricated it, but failed to reunite it with the herd.

They took the elephant calf to the zoo.

Only 100 kilometres away _ two days' trample for a herd of elephants _ Calcutta was alive with rumors and gossip on New Year's Eve. Bets were taken on whether the herd would swim across the city's last line of defence, the Hooghly river, and which political party they would support if they reached the state capital.

Local papers advised their readers on the do's and don'ts of running into a wild elephant. Never walk in front of it _ a fairly obvious counsel _ and do not make eye contact. Happily, it seems, the 10 million inhabitants of Calcutta will not need to heed this advice.

But for the elephants the long-term outlook is grim. The destruction of their habitat and familiar trails by mining and the encroachment of agriculture leaves India's estimated 20,000 elephants with ever diminishing living space. -- Guardian

Photo A farmer keeps his distance as the herd of elephants walk past fields as they head for home

urn:contentItem:459J-DXV0-0197-T0X9-00000-00<published>1996-05-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">It's tough on the election trail FROM food poisoning to frostbite, campaigning has taken a heavy toll on Ecuador's presidential candidates, sharply restricting the activities of four of the nine candidates. One has been in bed for 11 days with a foot infection, another suffered frostbite to his face campaigning in a mountainous region, one cannot do walk-abouts after injuring a hand and foot in a fall and one developed intestinal and bronchial infections after accepting some home-made food.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Stick with one Italy: president ITALIAN President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro has insisted the country's unity be maintained after powerful party leader Umberto Bossi called for the secession of the rich north. Bossi, whose Northern League made a strong showing in last month's elections, touched off a storm with a speech to his party's self-styled "parliament of the north" in Bagnolo San Vito.</p><p>China quake deaths stable THE death toll from China's latest earthquake remained at 18 but might go higher as 280 were still in a serious condition, a spokesman for the Baotou Seismology Bureau said yesterday. The quake, at 6.4 on the Richter scale, shook a mountainous valley in the northern region of Inner Mongolia on Friday.</p><p>A fire too fast A FOREST fire in northern New Mexico erupted yesterday, forcing 2000 residents to evacuate and engulfing several houses. No injuries were reported. Ignited by burning trash, the blaze burnt 1620 hectares of the Carson National Forest, forcing evacuations from Red River, La Lama and Questa and engulfing half a dozen houses in La Lama.</p><p>Firefighters fought it from the air because it was moving too quickly for ground crews.</p><p>Phoney smokes blast Gulf state NINE pre-dawn explosions set off by booby-trapped cigarette packets hit foreign and other firms in Bahrain yesterday, causing millions of dollars in damage but no injuries, a government official said.</p><p>Ecstasy claims another victim A BRITISH police chief's daughter died at an all-night party hours after taking the drug ecstasy at a club, it was claimed. Claire Pierce, 20, daughter of Superintendent Roy Pierce, was found dead at the home of Simon Wright, near the town of Mansfield, early yesterday.</p><p>Wright, 20, said he was told Claire had taken tablets in a nightclub in nearby Derby.</p><p>NZ flies into a spin about fruit NEW Zealand agriculture prepared for a crisis after the discovery of a further 14 Mediterranean fruit-flies in Auckland yesterday. Ministry of Agriculture officials have begun spraying poison bait in a three-kilometre circle around the Mt Roskill suburb where they were found. Two were found last week. The Mediterranean fruit-fly is one of the most damaging species for commercial orchards.</p><p>Not quite what program intended AN orang-utan called Indra left Auckland zoo officials red-faced when she climbed a ladder inadvertently left in her cage and went out to meet the people. Her five minutes of freedom sparked an emergency at the zoo and hundreds of visitors were warned to shelter in the nearest secure building as Indra took a stroll with her baby Isim. The ladder had been used in a behavioural enrichment program designed to keep the intelligent apes stimulated.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:45H3-SM80-015H-90PM-00000-00<published>2002-04-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>LETTERS TO THE EDITOR</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Selling our 'huge smoke towers'</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "Eco" is short for "ecological" which, if truthfully showing nature's powers, warts and all, can greatly enhance the "eco" of "economic" tourism.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Fifty years of careful research has proved our tall forests' ecological dependence on fire for the soil heating vital for their regeneration and rapid growth.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Starting 20 years later, Californian fire researchers also found fire to be vital for the healthy maintenance of their giant redwood stands.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The vital heating we need only occurs with dry soils which eliminates spring burning, and has always made safe burning difficult. Since about 1960 we have, through trial and error, learnt to burn when the measured fuel moisture in the uncut forest is 18 per cent plus, while that in felled slash is 10 to 14 per cent.</p><p>This critical difference occurs for only a few days after the first rains of autumn. If the measured wind, temperature and relative humidity conditions and the four-day forecast are all okay the forest fire manager must take every opportunity to burn before the onset of heavier rains.</p><p> This year these vital conditions coincided with Easter and upset many people.</p><p> This is understandable given the catcalls of "barbaric" and "Third World practice" and the utter failure of the Greens to praise and explain Tasmania's magnificent record in fire ecology research, forest regeneration and reserved forests.</p><p> A true ecotourist program would make a feature of these huge smoke towers coming from such tightly contained patches of forest.</p><p> It would tell every tourist how we learnt to harness nature's most powerful ecological weapon to produce clean, green and vigorous forests.</p><p>Tony Mount</p><p>Forest fire ecologist</p><p>Taroona</p><p>Anti-social</p><p>behaviour</p><p>I find it incredible that in the 21st century ForestryTasmania has the arrogance to believe it has some God-given right to pollute, regardless of the effects on the rest of the community.</p><p> Evan Rolley says it (burning) has to be done when the weather is suitable (The Mercury, April 2).</p><p> Who says it has to be done? Not the people who look from the top of Mt Wellington into a yellow smog; not the tourist operators, having to apologise for the condition of our much-touted "purest air in the world"; not even those well-qualified foresters who contend that burning is not a necessary requirement for successful regeneration.</p><p> This is as if a chemical firm had said that it needed to flush its tanks of toxic residues into the Derwent River, and this could only be done when the tide was right.</p><p> No one would tolerate such a statement from any organisation, so why does the Department of the Environment condone and/or turn a blind eye to the actions of ForestryTasmania in so many areas of interest to the larger community? Ordinary citizens face stringent action if they light backyard bonfires or run smoky woodheaters, yet ForestryTasmania remains mysteriously immune.</p><p> May we hope to see an effective sanction against this body and its anti-social behaviour?</p><p>Ian Milne</p><p>Seven Mile Beach</p><p>Road space</p><p>I noticed that a Hobart City Council alderman is pushing a "sustainability in transport" initiative this week. I will be on my bicycle commuting to my job and endorsing such sentiments, as I have done since the early seventies.</p><p> I have also been a driver of cars, trucks and buses since 1968.</p><p> I think I understand what it takes to negotiate our increasingly adversarial road system.</p><p> However, in the past two weeks I have had physical contact with three vehicles as they have moved into my road space. I have tried to push them away. They are that close! A blue Toyota driven by a young woman pulled out of the right lane into my path in Regent St. A large truck drove past me and then moved over on to me in Macquarie St, and on Easter Sunday a yellow Corolla drove at speed into my space. He had obviously left his turn into Molle St too late.</p><p> I am all for sustainable transport until it kills me.</p><p>Raymond Arnold</p><p>Mt Nelson</p><p>Ferries</p><p>Responding to C. F. Tate (Letters, March 26), I recall a trip on the Nairana on my way to Darwin during World War II. May I suggest that we forget the indigenous and the governor-general for the time being and give favourable consideration to naming the two new ferries Rosny and Derwent in memory of the vessels plying our magnificent river years ago.</p><p>David Tregear</p><p>West Moonah</p><p>Sunnies</p><p>Regarding the letter by Egon Strodl (March 28), it is all very well to criticise people for wearing sunglasses, but has it ever occurred to him that some people have bad eyes and can't stand bright lights?</p><p> Sometimes it can still be a bit glary, whether the sun is out or not. I have to wear them on doctor's orders. Don't be so quick to knock people with sunnies just because you have the good fortune of good eyesight.</p><p>J. Lear</p><p>Kingston</p><p>Queen Mother</p><p>Your excellent editorial (April 2) on the death of the Queen Mother said it all. It was the end of an era and for the first time in my life I observed people from across the Australian political spectrum -- whether constitutional monarchists or republicans -- and whether young or old paying tribute to a wonderful person.</p><p> What a pity that one or two mean-spirited republicans couldn't resist using the death of the Queen Mother to push their own self-centred barrow.</p><p>Michael Hodgman</p><p>Hobart</p><p> I commend Graeme Phillips on his Taste article (March 27) regarding the proposed Liquor and Accommodation Act amendments. I agree with nearly all of his sentiments and strongly oppose the reforms to the Licensing Board.</p><p> I make these observations as a person with extensive experience and understanding of the hospitality industry. I deliver responsible serving of alcohol courses within Tasmania. I am the sole deliverer of these courses to industry and have been since the program's inception in 1995.</p><p> I have previously been the holder of five hotel licences, the first being in 1975 when I was 21. I have owned, managed, operated and held liquor licences for hotels, restaurants, function centres, bottle shops, liquor stores and liquor merchants.</p><p> According to AHA state director Daniel Leesong's letter (April 1) the restructuring of the Licensing Board (to seven members) to include legislated industry representation is a safeguard to ensure that there will be board members with relevant industry knowledge and experience.</p><p> Yet in the next paragraph he goes on to say, "The current Tasmanian Licensing Board has two of three members that have had hospitality industry experience" (the third by provision of the current Act is required to be a legal practitioner). So, as the famous saying goes, if the wheel of the wagon ain't broke, don't fix it. As Graeme Phillips pointed out, there's no tourism or wine industry representatives in this proposal, but maybe Paul Lennon feels they don't contribute to the hospitality industry, or is that just the AHA's view?</p><p> The key word used by Mr Leesong is "safeguard" but his analysis as to who is being protected is flawed as the proposed amendments would only safeguard the existing players.</p><p> Furthermore, he asserts "the introduction of a need to show sound commercial principles are underpinning an application ensures that orderly development of the industry is maintained".</p><p> So now a board consisting of persons representing vested interests will make decisions on whether or not a proposal is "sound" before granting a licence. Some points: *  Will the board members be qualified to make such a judgment? *  All rejections based on the above will end up being appealed in court (in fact, all decisions of the re-structured board would end up in court as it would have a stated vested and anti-competitive interest); *  The Act specifically directs the board to maintain the "orderly development of the industry", so how does removing this direct reference under the proposed amendments and stacking the new board achieve this? *  Surely the most obvious arbiter of sound commercial principle is the market place.</p><p> Mr Leeson says: "In addition, the Licensing Board will still be required to take into account the best interests of the community as a whole when granting liquor licences".</p><p> The amendments do not mention the word "community" once. The Act infers the board members represent the interests of the community. Will the new, stacked board look out for community interest or their own interest? If the Licensing Board in 1987 was of the proposed composition the Hotel Grand Chancellor would never have been granted a licence.</p><p> He then applauds the Bacon Government for "honouring its commitment to the hotel sector". Pity this commitment will potentially harm the rest of the state in the process. Just think -- poker machines!</p><p> What gross hypocrisy to introduce a Bill freeing up shop trading hours and shutting down tourism development in the same session.</p><p>Colin Corney</p><p>Hobart</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
