urn:contentItem:4NPJ-9KH0-TXDB-C21B-00000-00Pressure to reduce tropical deforestation2007-05-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisPM6:27 PM AESTABCAshley HallPressure to reduce tropical deforestation

MARK COLVIN: A new scientific study of the effects of deforestation is likely to ramp up the pressure on tropical nations to stop letting so many forests be slashed and burned.

The CSIRO research, published in the journal Science has found that tropical deforestation accounts for nearly 20 per cent of the carbon emissions attributed to human activity.

And it says a 50 per cent reduction in deforestation by 2050 would have a huge positive effect. It could prevent 50 billion tonnes of carbon from being released into the atmosphere.

Ashley Hall has more.

(sound of forest fire)

ASHLEY HALL: In 2005, illegal logging in Indonesia and the subsequent fires were blamed for a plume of smoke that swept across South-East Asia, cutting visibility and causing breathing problems in neighbouring countries.

But it's not just the smoke that's a problem. The slashing and burning of tropical rainforests is also considered a prime factor in climate change.

Dr Pep Canadell, the Executive Director of the Global Carbon Project and CSIRO Marine and Atmospheric Research says deforestation is to blame for about one and a half billion tonnes of carbon dioxide being released into the atmosphere every year for the past 15 years.

PEP CANADELL: We have a huge reservoir of carbon. We go there, we cut it, we burn it, and it goes into the atmosphere. But in addition to that, we make disappear a piece of forest that is taking and cleaning a lot of the carbon in the atmosphere. So it's almost a double loss.

ASHLEY HALL: So this is a devastating impact?

PEP CANADELL: It is. And actually the calculations we are doing is that the net effect of all this deforestation, it's basically almost an increase of 20 per cent additional emissions from human activity going into the atmosphere and feeding into climate change.

ASHLEY HALL: Greenpeace's Forest Campaigner, Tiy Chung, says tropical rainforests are vanishing at an alarming rate.

TIY CHUNG: In PNG, 60 per cent of its large ancient intact forests have already been destroyed, and Greenpeace estimates that over 90 per cent of logging in PNG is illegal.

Between August 2000 and 2005, the Amazon lost 2.8 million hectares of forest.

Indonesia was confirmed, a couple of weeks ago, as a Guinness World Record holder for destroying its forests at the fastest rate, and the Democratic Republic of Congo risks losing up to 40 per cent of its forests by 2050.

ASHLEY HALL: Greenpeace says aside from logging, forests are cleared to make way for agricultural land.

In the Amazon, it's cleared to produce soya.

In Indonesia, the Solomons and Papua New Guinea, land is cleared to produce pulp and paper, as well as palm oil.

And palm oil is produced to service the increase in demand for biofuels brought about by the EU's decision to move towards 20 per cent biofuel use.

Greenpeace's Tiy Chung says that target was ill-conceived.

TIY CHUNG: You know, you can't just say something like we're going to go 20 per cent into biofuels without also looking at how that's going to be produced.

ASHLEY HALL: The International Tropical Timber Organisation is holding its 42nd meeting this week in Port Moresby. At a similar meeting in 1990, it set a target called Objective 2000. The plan was to ensure that trade in tropical timber came only from sustainable forests by 2000.

But in last year's assessment, the ITTO found less than five per cent of tropical forests were being managed sustainably.

The PNG Prime Minister, Sir Michael Somare, hinted at the reason when he opened the meeting - economic growth. It would be illogical, he said, to expect developing countries to grow without using their forest resources.

But Dr Pep Canadell says it would take a relatively small effort to reduce the carbon emissions from deforestation.

PEP CANADELL: If you slow down deforestation of the next, you know, 100 years by 50 per cent, you can be looking at a savings of about 500 million tonnes of carbon into the atmosphere every single year.

ASHLEY HALL: And he says many of the affected nations have already asked to be included in a global carbon emissions trading scheme. The proposal would allow some countries to be rewarded with carbon credits in exchange for reducing deforestation.

In March, the Federal Government announced $197 million to help fight deforestation in the tropics.

Federal Environment Minister Malcolm Turnbull.

MALCOLM TURNBULL: What we are seeking to do is to bring deforestation and addressing deforestation to the top of the climate change agenda. It is something that we can do now. As I said in my speech at the Press Club recently, we have to be committed to early action.

MARK COLVIN: The Federal Environment Minister Malcolm Turnbull, ending Ashley Hall's report.

urn:contentItem:4P85-12J0-TXN5-R31K-00000-00Movies1996-05-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisTHE GUIDEPg. 25MoviesDoug Anderson

GREASE (1978)

On Seven at 8.30 pm

THE vast audience of people who went to high school during the 1950s has grown another decade older since this heavily pomaded shower of chronic nostalgia first slid onto the screen. Or is it two? Students at Rydell High include John Travolta, since reborn as a megastar, and our own Lady of the Pompadours, Olivia Newton-Thing, who talks to (or for) the animals on Nine. A lot of left-over bits from West Side Story, Rebel Without A Clue and The Acne Monster Meets Dobie Gillis are bonded together with a sticky substance and enlivened by a lot of superannuated stars such as Frankie Avalon, Ed Byrnes and the repulsive Sid Caesar. The result? Suck it and see or, if time is short, try this handy hint from our culinary adviser, Dr Vladimir Jacuzzi. He recommends dipping a beach umbrella in golden syrup and swallowing it with a splash of Mouton Ron Casey, J Curve Series Commemorative port. Mmnnn!

SATURDAY NIGHT FEVER (1977)

On Seven at 10.50 pm

A lot has changed in the past 19 years. Just as well, too! Tony Manero, in the person of John Travolta, adopts the poses that made him famous in this marshmallow fable of a hardware clerk striving for immortality in an ice-cream suit. Hectic dance routines and melting moments abound as he dances his socks off. More of a nut sundae than a film, but it did HUGE business at the box office and, given Travolta's newfound status as a re-invented, re-born and "respectable" character actor, is possibly worth a re-visit.

MEDICINE MAN (1992)

On Nine at 8.30 pm

DEEP in the fetid rainforests of Brazil, Dr Sean Connery is working on a cure for cancer. Och Jock!! Eureka! He finds it and damn and blast! promptly loses it. Ah well, back to the drawing board. Meanwhile the board of directors at the university sponsoring his research think Dr Campbell has had a fair go and no longer warrants further grants. There have been some very promising results from a Dr Hammond of the Jurassic Park Looney Theme Park Laboratory. So they instruct biochemist Lorraine Bracco (PhD in Street Smarts and a Masters in Up Yer Face New York Attitood), to hop on a jet and do a Stanley/Livingstone routine - "Telegram, Doc. Bad news, I'm afraid." But when she realises how close Campbell is to the crucial breakthrough in recreating the magic formula, she pitches in. No such magic arises between them, alas, as they fight off filthy entrepreneurs who want to bulldoze the rainforest where the crucial ingredients are located and erect another vertical griller factory. A fabulous forest fire revs things up but the yarn lacks the potency, the characters and the kind of fusion necessary to shove it into overdrive. It dies with the brakes on and Bracco isn't about to roll over and beg for it like a James Bond bimbette. Different casting might have helped but I suspect otherwise.

JACQUELINE (1956)

On ABC at 1 pm

A GROG-SODDEN Belfast shipwright suffers from vertigo but is put back on an even keel (sorry) by his tiny child. Fabulous.

Illus: John Travolta ... stars in a shower of chronic nostalgia.

urn:contentItem:44K8-CTN0-0197-93VN-00000-00<published>2000-07-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 24</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>A nuclear opportunity</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Graeme O'Neill</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">STARGAZERS could be in for more than they bargained for in tonight's total eclipse of the moon.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> They could see a meteorite slamming into the lunar surface with a force many times greater than that of a nuclear bomb.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> And that would be our saving grace. Late June is high-season for meteorites, but there is no guarantee one would hit the moon -- it could skirt by and crash into Earth with enough force to destroy civilisation as we know it, if not wipe out human life.</p><p>The chances are slim, but whatever happens, observers are assured of a great view, as long as there is no cloud.</p><p> It is safe to look at the moon at any time, and particularly so when it is in full shadow.</p><p> But those viewing the eclipse away from the light pollution of the cities will be dazzled in another respect.</p><p> With Earth casting a shadow over the brightest and largest object in the night sky, the Milky Way will blaze with light, creating a spectacular backdrop to the spectacle of the eclipse.</p><p> Conditions will be ideal for meteorite-spotting, as will the timing. Records show the moon in June can be an extremely dangerous place.</p><p> At this time of year, the moon, and the Earth, are exposed to a dangerous phenomenon that could damage observers' eyes and even threaten life.</p><p> Over the past 1000 years, the latter half of June has seen some of the most destructive meteor strikes on Earth and on the moon.</p><p> This is a result of the Earth moving through the Taurid meteor stream, a trail of debris left by an extinct comet.</p><p> The 150 metre to 200 metre diameter chunk of ice and dust that exploded with the force of an H-bomb about 8km above Siberia on June 30, 1908, flattened trees over an area of 2000 sq km.</p><p> It also left a descent trail as bright as the sun, dazzling observers as far to the east as China.</p><p> On June 18, 1178, "four wise men" stargazing on a warm, cloudless night in the English town of Canterbury were terrified by the spectacle of fire erupting from the half-moon.</p><p> Over the next few hours, they saw the moon change from its normal yellow-white to dull red, as a cloud of vaporised gas, rock and debris from a major impact spread across its surface.</p><p> Astronauts on the first Apollo mission to examine the back of the moon -- which is perpetually hidden from the Earth -- photographed a huge, apparently recent crater on the dark side, behind its north pole.</p><p> The crater, since named Giordano Bruno, was probably produced by a comet fragment 2km to 3km in diameter.</p><p> Had it hit the Earth it could have destroyed all human life on the planet -- only sheer chance prevented it doing so.</p><p> However, recent research suggests a storm of smaller fragments produced a tidal wave which devastated Pacific Rim countries after crashing into the ocean.</p><p> One of those fragments may have exploded over the Tapanui region of New Zealand's South Island.</p><p> Maori legends, that may date to the 1178 impact, have it that part of the moon broke off and crashed to Earth, setting fire to the forests and killing huge numbers of moas, the giant flightless birds that once inhabited New Zealand.</p><p> Recent geological surveys of the Tapanui region identified several young impact craters, and extensive deposits of charcoal which would indicate a major forest fire.</p><p> In 1973, a seismometer left on the lunar surface by one of the Apollo missions recorded the vibrations of a major meteor shower -- again in late June.</p><p> The odds against eclipse-watchers witnessing a lunar impact tonight are long, but not astronomically so.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:48FT-6YW0-015G-S0TP-00000-00<published>2003-04-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>SPORT; Pg. 75</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>'ERE WE GO</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>ANGUS MORRISON</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ANGUS MORRISON reports from London on the Premier League</p><p nitf:lede="true">Tottenham looking Keane as mustard</p><p nitf:lede="true">MATCH OF THE ROUND</p><p nitf:lede="true">Tottenham Hotspur v Man United</p><p nitf:lede="true">THE banana skin for Ferguson and his men as they try to stay a step ahead of the Gunners in the race for the title.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Spurs have had a typically under-performing season, with Glenn Hoddle blaming everything from injuries to the weather to the hair length of the cheerleaders (okay, I made the last one up). But they've struck a bit of form lately, and it's largely down to the return from injury of Robbie Keane.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> If he sniffs out an early goal, the pressure will go right back on United. Anything less than a win here and Arsenal's game in hand takes on title-clinching proportions.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>And we don't want that.</p><p>oALEX Ferguson's terrific record is surpassed only by his ego. With reports about David Beckham moving to Real Madrid for $98 million in the off-season reaching the deafening stage, Fergie made his feelings clear. He dumped him.</p><p> With Becks on the bench in the Champions League quarter-final, Ronaldo slotted a hat-trick to put Real through. Fergie put Beckham on in the 70th minute and he scored twice to win the game 4-3.</p><p> The way Becks farewelled the Old Trafford crowd indicates that where there's smoke, there's a forest fire. But why would a team pay $98m for Beckham when they already have Raul, Figo, Zidane and Ronaldo?</p><p>THE DRAW</p><p>LAST NIGHT</p><p>B Wanderers v Arsenal; Birmingham City v Middlesbrough; West Bromwich Albion v Liverpool; Charlton Athletic v Southampton; Chelsea v Fulham; Everton v Aston Villa; Leeds Utd v Blackburn Rovers; Sunderland v Newcastle Utd</p><p>TONIGHT</p><p>Manchester City v West Ham (11pm); Tottenham v Manchester Utd (1.05am Mon)</p><p>A touch of crass</p><p>FRENCH striker Pascal Nouma has been given the sack after putting his hand down his shorts and moving it about vigorously to celebrate a goal.</p><p> Nouma's gesture came after he scored for Besiktas against Fenerbahce in a Turkish league match. The incident was captured by TV cameras and beamed around Turkey, prompting widespread outrage.</p><p> Nouma attempted to justify his actions by saying "it was a private moment of joy" but it didn't save his job. It could be said his bosses had been warned by previous incidents, including hitting a journalist at a nightclub and urinating on the training pitch.</p><p> The impromptu game of pocket billiards was the final straw.</p><p> oARSENAL are keeping a close eye on Australian Scott Chipperfield. The 27-year-old Basel player scored in the Aussies' 3-1 win over England in February and is impressing Gunners scouts.</p><p>Bending truth about Becks</p><p>MORE on David Beckham's attempts to make it in the US of A.</p><p> The American release of the movie Bend It Like Beckham (a semi-okay flick that doesn't actually have Becks in it, but does star the completely lovely Keira Knightley) prompted the following helpful information from a leading film reviewer.</p><p> The Beckham in the title of this movie actually exists.</p><p> He is a star player who can kick the ball so it bends past the goalkeeper and into the net.</p><p> And the clincher is: he plays for Manhattan United.</p><p>LIP SERVICE</p><p>"Alex Ferguson loves the game and will die on the United bench, I am sure of that."</p><p> Eric Cantona on his former boss.</p><p>No date was given.</p><p>"We are not a team of girls."</p><p> Real manager Vicente del Bosque.</p><p>Who was the idiot who suggested that?</p><p>"Fergie, Fergie, sign him up!"</p><p>Manchester United fans when Real star</p><p>Ronaldo was substituted on Wednesday night.</p><p>Take healthy option, Glenn</p><p>GIVEN West Ham's ability to lose winnable matches and play lousy football, manager Glenn Roeder's stroke is not unexpected. Roeder remains in a stable condition in hospital. The bad news is a full recovery would encourage him to go back for more, which would kill him.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:44KK-YFD0-0197-F2FX-00000-00<published>2000-03-25T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>MAGAZINE; Pg. W16</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Salute to real people</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Noel Mengel</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">IT had been a long time since a song stopped me in my tracks like Cold Missouri Waters.</p><p nitf:lede="true">It might be hard to explain why to those who haven't heard it, since on one level it's a simple enough folksong in the tradition of, say, The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald. But when I first heard it performed by the American group Cry Cry Cry I immediately read the CD sleeve to discover who had married this haunting melody to such an affecting story -- the tale of 13 firefighters killed in a forest fire in Montana in 1949 told from the point of view of one who escaped (barely) with his life.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The story song is seldom heard in the charts these days -- unless you call Madonna's ritual disembowelment of American Pie a story song -- but a tune as powerful as Cold Missouri Waters made me realise how undervalued stories of real people have become in a celebrity-obsessed world.</p><p>As it turns out, the author, Canadian singer and songwriter James Keelaghan, right, had been thinking much the same thing as he was growing up and then studying history at university. The first time he heard Cry Cry Cry's version of his song it stopped him in his tracks, too.</p><p>Keelaghan says: "When I first heard their version</p><p>I was driving in my car --</p><p>I put it into the CD player but had to pull over because I was bawling like a baby. I thought then that I had started to accomplish what I had set out to do. Now people all over North America are covering the song, retelling the story."</p><p>What he had set out to do was to keep the story alive, giving a voice in song to the ordinary people who are usually forgotten when the generation that knew them passes on.</p><p>"It is always the people that attracted me," says Keelaghan, who is back in Australia for a tour that brings him to Brisbane tomorrow night. "The real problem when I studied history is that people come away thinking it's about generals and prime ministers. I have a radically different view, so I promised myself I would try to take ordinary people and give them a measure of fame."</p><p>Songs like that one and Kiri's Piano, about the forced internment of Japanese Canadians during World War II, have won Keelaghan his reputation as one of his country's leading songwriters. But turmoil in his personal life meant his muse took a different turn on his latest album, Road (Hightone).</p><p>"I hadn't written personal stuff before but because of things I was going through, my divorce and my father nearly dying from a heart attack, I thought if I don't write about it now there won't be a chance at all."</p><p>He does it beautifully on songs like Ring and Your Secret, although there is still room for one classic new Keelaghan tale, Captain Torres, about the ship of that name caught in wild weather off the coast of Canada in 1989. Because of the severity of the storm the chances of survival were slim and the crew lined up in the radio room to phone home and say goodbye. There were no survivors.</p><p>"The story is not as well known as you would think in Canada because it was on the same night as a mass murder in Montreal when a man shot 15 women," Keelaghan says.</p><p>"The dichotomy is that one guy did something that night so horrendous all men got tarred with it, while 600 miles to the east, 29 men were doing what men normally do. Which, at the moment of crisis and death, is thinking about family."</p><p>James Keelaghan plays Souths Rugby Union Club, Frederick Street, Yeronga, Brisbane, tomorrow from 7.30pm.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:47YX-RWK0-015G-T1M3-00000-00<published>2003-02-21T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>OPINION; Pg. 20</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Lost in the smoke of ignorance</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Wilson Tuckey</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">WHILE I don't know the qualifications of your correspondent Gavan McFadzean as regards forest and/or wildfire management (Herald Sun, February 11), as a layman I must reject his claims on the grounds of logic.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> My only problem is where to start.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> McFadzean claims it is the truth that little is known scientifically about extremely hot fires. That is totally untrue.</p><p>The heat and intensity of any fire is directly related to the available fuel and oxygen. In the case of forest fire, the oxygen is virtually unlimited.</p><p> Scientific tables exist and are published. The fundamentals of a forest or furnace fire are the same.</p><p> The Australian eucalypt that another green spokesman referred to as fire retardant does not shed its bark or leaves until all moisture is extracted, thus creating ever increasing ground layers of highly combustible material that refuses to decompose.</p><p> Old growth trees shed the most.</p><p> The high wind in Canberra was a convection current, the result of the wildfire, not the cause of the fire.</p><p> Similarly, while drought conditions are a final contributor to wildfire, they are not the cause.</p><p> The cause is fuel levels further dehydrated by drought conditions.</p><p> Arsonists and careless smokers should be condemned but, like natural lightning, these ignitions cannot turn into a wildfire without high levels of combustible fuel at ground level.</p><p> Forest roads might provide access for the careless but they also provide primary access to firefighters to extinguish fires in their infancy -- however they are lit.</p><p> I am bemused by the Green network citing statistics as to how many forest fires begin outside national parks before becoming destructive wildfires inside the parks.</p><p> Surely it is the fact and reasons that the park burned that matter.</p><p> Controlled burning has nothing to do with simply working around urban areas.</p><p> It is the well-researched cool burn technology that the NSW State Forests Department continued to practise on a seven-year rotation throughout the entire 2.5 million hectares under management. Last year they suffered 2000ha of fires.</p><p> On the other hand, the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service reduced its activity to half a per cent of its management area and experienced 750,000ha of fires last year.</p><p> The assertion that ecological change arises from a frequent low-level burning pattern defies history.</p><p> The unique Australian eucalypt is the product of this process as practised by the Aborigines and well recorded by the early settlers. They described the forest in the 1790s as one of well-spaced large trees surrounded by clear grasslands, not the</p><p>impenetrable, fire-prone bush McFadzean would describe as pristine.</p><p> The native Australian plants are tolerant species, but nothing resists a wildfire.</p><p> It is the crown-burning wildfires that kill native trees and create the opportunity for the establishment of alternative exotic species and weeds.</p><p> The suggestion that a strong dense regrowth area of young eucalypts will burn more fiercely than a metre plus of absolutely dry ground matter in an old growth forest is ridiculous.</p><p> This suggests we could better ignite our lounge or camp fire with green sticks.</p><p> The same can be said of McFadzean's reference to the vulnerability of plantations.</p><p> There's clear evidence in my electorate of bush fires burning all the old growth bush, but expiring metres after entering the managed plantation forest.</p><p>Canberra's pine plantations experienced fires in recent years that started within their boundaries and were extinguished without the destruction experienced during the recent tragedy.</p><p> THE Canberra pine fires were ignited by the blowtorch of the super wildfires of the adjoining national parks that, to quote eyewitness accounts, were even burning the smoke particles as they roared into suburbia.</p><p> The 1939 Stretton Royal Commission in Victoria gave an identical description in its report.</p><p> There is plenty of science about the causes of fire, but less about the science of fire suppression.</p><p> The McFadzeans of this world do the community, the animals and trees no favours by attempting to confuse the issue to support their confused philosophy.</p><p> WILSON TUCKEY is federal Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:47N5-YF30-015G-T1CS-00000-00<published>2003-01-11T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 5</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Worst in 20 years;<br/>Country residents warned</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>PHILIP CULLEN and CHRISTINE CAULFIELD</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">HUNDREDS of weary firefighters are battling the biggest blazes to rage through the state in almost 20 years.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> And as both temperatures and the north wind rose, firefighters warned country Victorians to brace themselves.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> More than 15,000ha of parks and forests and 1000ha of private property have been destroyed by almost 100 fires across the north and southeast of the state this week.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Firefighters have fought more than 570 fires so far this summer, double the average for the past 20 years of 255 for the entire season.</p><p>About 226,000ha have been destroyed, eight times the 20-year average of 27,700.</p><p> About 700 Department of Sustainability and Environment firefighters and Country Fire Authority volunteers are still fighting 20 blazes burning out of control.</p><p> The state's 24 water-bombing planes, along with 160 specialised four-wheel drives and 33 bulldozers, have been brought in to help crews tackle the flames.</p><p> DSE spokesman Kevin Monk said the conditions were ripe for the the worst bushfire season in 20 years.</p><p> "Last year was one of the driest years on record, which means more fuel for the flames, more intensity and more uncontrollable," he said. "The last time we saw fires like this was back in 1985."</p><p> Fire was still raging yesterdayin the Mullundung State forest, north of Yarram in South Gippsland, and has already burned 7600ha of bushland, 900ha of grazing land and 180ha of private plantations.</p><p> At its worst, the fire's perimeter was 45km, but the blaze was expected to be contained last night.</p><p> More than 300 firefighters, with the help of 12 bulldozers and four water-bombers, were tackling the blaze.</p><p> Residents between Sale and Yarrum have reported seeing smoke from the forest fire.</p><p>Myrtleford residents, who are only 8km from a 120ha fire near Mt Buffalo, were also surrounded by smoke and had been put on alert.</p><p> Deputy police media director Kevin Loomes said there were still fires burning in the northeast, which had made it hazardous for bush walkers.</p><p> Those planning a walk are asked to contact Parks Victoria on 131 963.</p><p> DSE incident controller Peter Novotny said the state was experiencing the most severe fire conditions in several decades.</p><p> "There have been that many fires, it's a rare event. It's only once every . . . several decades, we have that type of event," he said.</p><p> "It's unseasonably dry and when there's an ignition it will burn with greater intensity than it would in a normal year."</p><p> Police believe an</p><p>arsonist tried to light a second fire at the Holey Plains National Park in Gippsland after firefighters brought the initial blaze under control late on Thursday.</p><p> Sparked by lightning strikes accompanying Tuesday's cool change, the first fire burned more than 400ha of bush and pine plantation and destroyed a gun club.</p><p> Last night, crews were working to extinguish it before the hot weather returned.</p><p> Grandridge Plantations regional co-ordinator Peter Marshall said up to 300ha of 20 to 25-year-old pine trees had been lost in the blaze at a cost of about $1 million.</p><p> He said it had been 10 years since the plantation had lost stock to fire.</p><p> DSE spokesman Mr Monk said firefighters were visiting homes that were most at risk, advising owners.</p><p> About 16 fires remained out of control in northeast Victoria; those causing most concern were in steep, inaccessible country to the south of the Murray River headwaters.</p><p> Crews established control lines between the towns of Cudgewa and Tintaldra.</p><p> CFA spokesman Peter Philp said no homes had been lost. He said 160 Corryong residents had attended a meeting yesterday to be fully briefed.</p><p> A police hotline, 1800 444 343, has been established to provide information to residents.</p><p>AT A GLANCE</p><p>Fire toll*</p><p>Out of control: 22</p><p>Contained: 30</p><p>Under control: 47</p><p>Since Tuesday</p><p>15,000ha of forest, and national and state parks have burned plus 1000ha of private land</p><p>So far this summer</p><p>More than 226,000ha have burned</p><p>The 20-year average for the whole of summer is 27,700ha</p><p>Source: Department of Natural</p><p>Resources and Environment</p><p>* Figures correct at 3.20pm yesterday</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:525Y-W701-F0JP-W4TN-00000-00OUT & ABOUT - SA, WA2011-02-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 14OUT & ABOUT - SA, WADAVID STRATTON, EVAN WILLIAMS, ROSEMARY NEILL, SEAN SENNETT, JOHN KINSELLA, RITA CLARKE, IAN CUTHBERTSON, ASHLEIGH WILSON

NEW RELEASES

Hereafter (M)

Clint Eastwood's new film, scripted by British writer Peter Morgan (The Queen) explores the afterlife, a tricky subject the accomplished director succeeds in making more fascinating than you may imagine. Three interlocking stories, set in three different parts of the world, finally converge and although there are rocky moments along the way, the result is amazingly satisfying.

DAVID STRATTON *** 1/2

127 Hours (MA15+)

Trapped in a Utah canyon in 2003 with a boulder pinning his arm and unable to call for help, Aron Ralston spent an agonising six days in his rocky prison before managing to free himself. Danny Boyle's film is more than an unsparing record of Ralston's ordeal; it is a life-affirming experience, with some dazzling filmcraft and a brave central performance from James Franco. Much of it is hard to watch, all of it hard to forget.

EVAN WILLIAMS ****

No Strings Attached (MA15+)

A bright and breezy rom-com, which deals more candidly than most with bodily parts and functions (no nudity though) and centres on a couple of charming performances from Natalie Portman and Ashton Kutcher as a couple who (at first) want sex without love. Unfortunately, if you've seen the trailer you've already seen the best jokes.

D.S.

SOUTH AUSTRALIA

STAGE

The Wau Wau Sisters

The New York-based Wau Wau Sisters (Tanya Gagne and Adrienne Truscott) are part of a new wave of burlesque performers -- most of them women -- who trade on sex and nudity while dismantling traditional notions of the demeaned stripper or prettily passive showgirl. They open their new show, The Wau Wau Sisters are as Naked as the Day They Were Born Again, at the Adelaide Fringe. The sisters' routines are a spicy stir-fry of kinky acrobatics and trapeze, satirical songs, comedy sketches and stripping. As its title implies, their latest show takes an emphatically minimalist approach to costuming.

ROSEMARY NEILL

The Spiegeltent. Garden of Unearthly Delights, East Terrace, Adelaide. Tonight, 11.30pm. Tickets: $30. Bookings: 1300 374 643. Until February 27.

LIVE MUSIC

The Lloyd Cole Small Ensemble

Singer-songwriter Lloyd Cole is touring Australia to promote his new studio album Broken Record. The Small Ensemble has Cole out front, with Mark Schwaber and Matt Cullen trading acoustic guitars, banjo and mandolin in support. Opening with No Blue Skies, Cole performs two sets and delves deep into his songbook. Highlights from his days with the Commotions include Perfect Skin, Are You Ready to be Heartbroken?, Forest Fire and Rattlesnakes. The older material sits well alongside recent compositions such as Writers Retreat! and favourites from the solo years such as Margo's Waltz, Like Lovers Do and the encore, Undressed. Cole's singing, buoyed by clever wordplay, is enriched throughout by a swell of acoustic instruments. Splendid.

SEAN SENNETT

The Gov. 59 Port Road, Hindmarsh. Tonight, 5pm. Tickets: $53.60. Bookings: 1300 438 849.

WESTERN AUSTRALIA

STAGE

Waltzing the Wilarra

Yirra Yaakin theatre company is innovative, energetic and politically charged, and David Milroy's new production is no exception. From the moment the spotlight finds vaudeville wise-cracker Old Toss (Ernie Dingo) with his sidekick Young Harry (Jessica Clarke), we are on a roller-coaster of irony, bitter social critique, affectionate humour and drama. Drawing on a club such as the Coolbaroo -- which arose in Australia after World War II, and where whites and Aborigines sang and danced together -- as a potential model for a possibly more genuine mode of reconciliation, the play weaves music theatre in a Brechtian strain with contemporary drama. Highlights are Ursula Yovich's soaring voice, Trevor Jamieson's sensitive rendering of his character Charlie, and Dingo's panto-dame slap-down of serving king and country.

JOHN KINSELLA

Subiaco Arts Centre. 180 Hamersley Rd, Subiaco. Tonight, 7.30pm. Tickets: $54.50. Bookings: (08) 9484 1133. Until March 6.

DANCE

Ballet at the Quarry

Even the pale moon seemed to brighten, stunned by the magnificent vitality of the WA Ballet dancers at the Quarry. Buoyed by Maria Callas's meticulous voice, their molten bodyline and precision made the complex seven-couple passage in Jiri Kylian's Un Ballo almost transcendental. Their strong classical technique and rhythmic fidelity in Uwe Scholz's Seventh Symphony, in which Jennifer Provins shone, added a wonderful layer of interpretation to Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony No 7. Although lone Australian choreographer David Jonathan's Saudade suffered from indistinct lighting, Ivan Cavallari's Chaplinesque duet Ombra Leggiera was amusingly captivating and crowned a compelling performance.

RITA CLARKE

Quarry Amphitheatre. Tonight, 8pm. Tickets: $49-$63. Bookings: 136 100. Until March 5.

EXHIBITIONS

The King's Speech and the Maj Connection

Thanks to Geoffrey Rush's BAFTA-winning and Oscar-nominated portrayal in The King's Speech, interest in Adelaide-born speech therapist Lionel Logue has never been greater. Now a small exhibition in Perth highlights a lesser known side of Logue: his days as a public speaker, producer and actor. Logue was known to recite Shakespeare and Dickens across Perth, and also devised, produced and acted in plays and musicals. The exhibition includes pictures of Nicholson's music shop, where Logue ran the School of the Spoken Word.

IAN CUTHBERTSON

DownStairs at the Maj. His Majesty's Theatre, 825 Hay St, Perth. Mon-Fri 10am-4pm. Free. Inquiries: (08) 9265 0900. Until March 31.

Images to Swoon for

HER real name is Caledonia Curry, but she's better known as Swoon. And for the past decade the Brooklyn artist has produced a body of work both intimate and grand in scale, using traditional printmaking techniques to reproduce images of street life in New York while unveiling larger-scale works designed to respond to local environments and communities. One of her more high-profile works was in 2008, when she led a flotilla of salvaged material down the Hudson River in Swimming Cities of Switchback Sea before sailing boats made from garbage into the Venice Biennale the following year. Swoon has now turned her attention to Melbourne, with her first solo exhibition to be opened at Metro Gallery tonight by Victorian Premier and Arts Minister Ted Baillieu. As part the exhibition, which runs until March 5, Swoon has created a 4m x 6m installation from timber and cardboard, inspired by the Indian city of Varanasi, inside the gallery. Later this week she will head to the Northern Territory to meet indigenous artists from the region and tour local communities.

ASHLEIGH WILSON

Edited by Ian Cuthbertson.

Full reviews of new films will appear in The Weekend Australian on Saturday.

urn:contentItem:3X77-C5X0-0048-T3V3-00000-00<published>1999-08-22T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>World News Highlights from AAP 07770 Aug 22</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>HIGHLIGHTS WORLD (ATTN EDITORS) EUR: Turkish quake death toll soars as hopes dwindle    ANKARA, Aug 21 DPA - Hopes dwindled today of finding any more<br/> survivors from Tuesday's earthquake in northwest Turkey, spawning fears that the final death toll could top 40,000. (QUAKE TURKEY SECOND DAYLEAD  sent at 03:05, 113 words.)<<br/> EUR: Mass graves for nameless dead of Turkey's quake    GOLCUK, Turkey, Aug 21 Reuters - Scores of nameless bodies are<br/> being buried in haste on the outskirts Golcuk, a town wrapped in the stench of death. (TURKEY QUAKE GRAVES  sent at 03:34, 302<br/> words.)< EUR: Buried four days, six people defy the odds    ISTANBUL, Aug 21 AP - Six people who had been buried alive in<br/> the rubble of Turkey's quake for four long, hot days were saved from their dark prisons today, rewarding the faith of relatives who kept vigil even after experts said the odds of surviving that long were slight. (QUAKE TURKEY RESCUE DAYLEAD  sent at 02:59, 730<br/> words.)< AFR: Algerian rebels slash throats of children    ALGIERS, Aug 21 Reuters - Muslim rebels stormed an isolated<br/> house and slashed the throats of 14 children attending a circumcision party last night, local residents said today. (ALGERIA VIOLENCE LEAD  sent at 05:41, 421 words.)<<br/> MID: Saudi Prince Faisal dies    RIYADH, Aug 21 AFP - Prince Faisal bin Fahd bin Abdelaziz,<br/> eldest son of King Fahd and head of the Arab Confederation of Sporting Games, died today at the age of 54, the Saudi royal cabinet said.</p><p>(SAUDI PRINCE DAYLEAD  sent at 05:14, 174 words.)<<br/> CAM: Hurricane warning in effect as Mexico    MEXICO CITY, Aug 21 AFP - A swirling sea-storm dubbed "Hurricane<br/> Bret" picked up strength early today as it approached the Gulf coast of northern Mexico and Texas, threatening to dump rain on nearby towns. (BRET DAYLEAD  sent at 03:31, 328 words.)<<br/> CIS: Yeltsin concerned over continued fighting in Dagestan    MOSCOW, Aug 21 DPA - Russian troops have failed to make any<br/> progress in their two-week battle against Islamic rebels in the Caucasus republic of Dagestan. (RUSSIA CAUCASUS  sent at 02:31, 311<br/> words.)< EUR: Anti-Milosevic opposition suffers setback    BELGRADE, Aug 21 AP - In a setback to efforts to unseat Slobodan<br/> Milosevic, an opposition leader denounced rivals in the movement and said his followers would boycott joint rallies aimed at forcing the Yugoslav president to step down. (YUGO DAYLEAD  sent at 02:46,<br/> 365 words.)< EUR: NATO warns Serbs to turn in arms or face arrest    PRISTINA, Yugoslavia, Aug 21 AP - After three Serb men were<br/> detained for alleged war crimes, NATO ordered Serbs in a southern Kosovo town to hand in weapons today or face arrest in a last-minute crackdown before Dutch troops turn security there over to the Russians. (KOSOVO DAYLEAD  sent at 02:51, 335 words.)<<br/> ASIA: Vajpayee, Gandhi take election campaign to south India    MADRAS, India, Aug 21 AP - Cheered by nearly 100,000 people,<br/> Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee today slammed Sonia Gandhi's party for linking a key ruling coalition partner to the assassination of her husband Rajiv Gandhi. (INDIA GANDHI  sent at<br/> 06:10, 351 words.)</p><p> ASIA: Thousands of government supporters march in Colombo    COLOMBO, Aug 21 AP - Tens of thousands of supporters of the<br/> governing People's Alliance marched through the streets of the Sri Lankan capital today, celebrating five years of President Chandrika Kumaratunga's rule. (SRILANKA RALLY DAYLEAD  sent at 02:48, 273<br/> words.)< EUR: Fire destroys 500 heactares near Madrid    MADRID, Aug 21 AP - After working a nonstop 26 hours,<br/> firefighters brought to control today a forest fire that that raged near Madrid forcing the evacuation of thousands of people, authorities said. (SPAIN ESCORIAL DAYLEAD  sent at 03:49, 163<br/> words.)<    AAP<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1999</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3X77-C5X0-0048-T3V3-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-26</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="658"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1999 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:49KH-97G0-01S8-D1X5-00000-00<published>1988-07-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BRIEFLY</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Police strike NEW DELHI, TUESDAY Indian troops today fired shots to disperse angry women trying to storm a police station in Ahmedabad in support of striking policemen in western Gujarat state.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The policemen went on strike after soldiers disarmed them to prevent a mutiny.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Cable TV LONDON At least six million people in Britain would be watching cable TV or receiving programs on their own satellite dishes within the next four years, media entrepreneur Rupert Murdoch said today.</p><p>Shuttle worry NEW YORK A crucial test firing of the US space shuttle Discovery's main engines at Cape Canaveral, Florida, was put on hold again today after technicians failed to meet a countdown deadline.</p><p> Park fire NEW YORK A 1093-hectare forest fire in Yellowstone National Park burned to within 13 kilometres of Old Faithful geyser in the United States' first national park. Altogether, fires in Yellowstone charred about 16,188 hectares of the 890,340-hectare park.</p><p> Boat disaster BEIJING Seventy-one people were missing, feared drowned, when a motor boat overturned yesterday in the Yangtze River after colliding with a barge.This was the second major boat accident in southwest China's Sichuan province in four days.</p><p> No threat to NZ WELLINGTON Political developments in the South Pacific pose no threat to New Zealand's security, Defence Minister Bob Tizard said in a report tabled in Parliament today.</p><p> Pilot killed BONN The pilot of an ultralight airplane was killed today after his craft apparently struck a West German Tornado jet fighter in flight near Eggebfelden, about 100 km east of Munich.</p><p> Rebels kill 2 COLOMBO Sinhalese Marxist guerrillas killed a local government official and the secretary of a ruling party politician in separate attacks in Sri Lanka, police said today.</p><p> Chemical leak AMSTERDAM About 250 tonnes of potentially lethal acrylonitryl have leaked into the North Sea from the 1597-tonne wrecked tanker, Anna Broere, according to Dutch salvage experts.</p><p> Locust plague BEIJING An unprecedented swarm of locusts has ravaged close to 3000 hectares of bamboo forest in central China, the official People's Daily said today.</p><p> Golden cheer VADUZ The tiny principality of Liechtenstein today marked the 50th anniversary of the coming to power of Prince Franz Josef II, Europe's longest-reigning head of state.</p><p> 'Shoot' warning NEW YORK Wadley Mayor B.A. Johnson has ordered police to "shoot to stop" anyone caught fighting in the city's park following a brawl last Sunday involving youths who used "big sticks with nails driven in them" as weapons.</p><p> And finally . . .</p><p> LONDON A man nearly blew himself to pieces when he gulped helium gas, in an effort to sound like Donald Duck.</p><p> He collapsed unconscious after his body swelled like a balloon and had to be rushed to hospital where he was treated for internal bruising.</p><p> A workmate said: "He looked huge. I reckon if you'd put a pin in him he would have popped." HERALD BUREAU, REUTER, AP, AFP, AAP, PA</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4S4K-5T70-TX5J-V1MR-00000-00Restrictions belie rivers' low flows2008-03-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 14Restrictions belie rivers' low flows

AS FROM March 21 all irrigators on the Yea and Murrindindi rivers have been notified that ``the diversion of water for irrigation, commercial or any purposes other than domestic and stock use'', has been banned.

The letter from Goulburn Murray Water advises ``that under a Stage 5 restriction it is necessary for GMW to carefully manage the remaining access to water, in an effort to provide for domestic and stock use and essential urban supplies''.

It seems strange then that the Yea township still remains on Stage 1 restrictions, although daily river flows are at less than 10 megalitres a day.

It is so obvious the Brumby Government wants travellers through our region to think we have plenty of water, while Melbourne is supposedly much drier and remains on Stage 3A.

Our State Government views the residents of Murrindindi as expendable. It matters not that our rivers are drying up, and the Eildon Weir is heading below 15 per cent this week.

All that matters is trying to deceive our city cousins into believing that we in the Upper Goulburn Catchment have plenty of water to send south.

Jan Beer, Plug the Pipe spokeswoman

CFA levy burns landowners

I WISH to comment on the current media campaign aimed at replacing our insurance-type levy system used to fund the Country Fire Authority, with claims that other states have dropped this method.

In these states new methods have proved a disaster with property owners' contributions escalating.

The problem with the existing insurance levy scheme is that it has been hijacked by the government and bureaucracy of the CFA to produce income for consolidated revenue and activities of the CFA that are government responsibilities such as community safety, community education, support for government agencies and bodies, and road accident services.

These services equate to an estimated 40 per cent of budget expenditure.

On information made available in the CFA 2007 annual report, the fire services levy contributed by the insurance system was $175.87 million, collected from an estimated total insurance pool for all risks of $436.38 million.

Added to the fire service levies paid to the State Government from the total pool are GST and stamp duty of $128.55 million, totalling $304.05 million. Out of this is the total CFA budget expense of $288.9 million, leaving a balance of $15.52 million surplus. How can this be justified?

A further example of inadequacies in the current system is where a property owner insures 1000 large round bales of hay for $100 each.

Insurance premiums would be about $259, then added to this are fire service levies and taxes of $208. If the bales catch fire, and large machinery is required to assist in their movement or suppression of the fire, the CFA demands the owner must pay for the cost of this machinery or his hay can burn.

A solution to our high insurance levies is not to scrap the system, but to remove the use of it as a ``taxing structure'' to fund other activities.

This would immediately reduce the levy. Existing levy and taxes of 87 cents on top of insurance premiums would be reduced to 52 cents.

Fire protection and prevention over the past decade has, by the lack of results achieved, raised community concerns in the aftermath of fires, creating real issues that the present centralised bureaucratic system has failed to address.

Alex Hopper, Winnindoo

A way to park a resource?

LINLEY Walker (WT, March 12) refers to ``huge scientific evidence for the need to establish new parks along the Murray''. I can't help but wonder what that evidence is.

VEAC's own discussion paper lists red gum forests that are ``in best ecological condition''.

Those named are all logged forests. Only Lindsay Island is a park, and it only became a park in recent years after salvage logging to remove all trees that could be sold.

National park's management of Lindsay Island has been to let it regenerate, just as state forest management would have done.

I attended a two day conference held by the Royal Society of Victoria.

In the two days of scientific papers the most compelling argument in favour of state forests becoming national parks was that the Government provides more money per hectare for national parks than it does for state forests.

VEAC's National Park draft recommendations include that ``ecological thinning may be permitted where required''.

State forests don't have to be logged, but they can be. The product from a felled tree in state forest can be sold. An ecologically thinned tree in a national park cannot be sold so it must be left to provide fuel for the next forest fire.

State forest management can be as passive or active as circumstances dictate. It can also include indigenous involvement without the need for VEAC's recommendation.

No living person knows just how these red gum forests were cared for 200 years ago. We do know that their management and water supply have changed. How do we manage them best for the future?

I somehow doubt that park management really has the desire to find out. It is so much easier to lock it up and let nature take its course. Then nature can take any blame.

Victor Eddy, Mildura

urn:contentItem:3X3H-S990-0048-T3WX-00000-00<published>1999-08-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: Fears of poisonous smog as land clearing begins</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Karen Polglaze, South East Asia Correspondent</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>INDON HAZE</p><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, Aug 4 AAP - There were fears today that a poisonous smog would again blanket some South East Asian countries as hundreds of fires ignited in Indonesian forests with the start of illegal land-clearing.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Indonesian environmental group Wahli today warned the situation now was worse than at the same time in 1997 when out-of-control fires burned across more than ten million hectares, creating thick smoke that polluted parts of Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore and the Philippines.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Indonesia's Environmental Impact Office (Bappedal) in Sumatra said the smoke had already caused air pollution indexes to break through the danger level on at least three occasions in the past week, including one day where it was 978 compared to the normal level of 0 to 50 and the danger level of 300.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> One commercial flight was prevented by the haze from landing at Pekanbaru in central Sumatra island on yesterday Agence France Presse reported.</p><p>Meanwhile Wahli forests advocation program coordinator Longgena Ginting said a law, which bans land-clearing by fire, remained ineffective and the cronyism that prevented prosecution in the 1997 fires had increased under new President BJ Habibie.</p><p> "The tragedy of the forest fire and haze will soon begin," Longgena told a media conference.</p><p> "Already, in a short time, hundreds of hotspots in Sumatra and Kalimantan have been found.</p><p> "On August 1, there were only ten hotspots in all of Sumatra. But in two days it rose to 341.</p><p> "In Kalimantan, on August 1, there were only three hotspots. That has risen to 100.</p><p> "The situation this year is worse than it was at the same time in 1997."</p><p> Neighbouring countries could once again face a choking smog if the Indonesian government failed to act now that the dry season had begun.</p><p> "If there are no further efforts by the government  the<br/> situation will be worse than two years ago," he said.</p><p> In 1997, most of the smoke pollution was caused by illegal land-clearing by fire on the large industrial plantations which went out of control because the season was drier than usual due to the effect of the El Nino weather phenomenon, according to official explanations.</p><p> But Wahli doubts that.</p><p> "El Nino was only a scapegoat," Longgena said.</p><p> "We urge the government to stop exploitation of the forests and return them to the people."</p><p> Land clearing for plantations on a large-scale should also be stopped.</p><p> Wahli had tried to press its point through the enforcement of existing laws banning land-clearing by fire.</p><p> They took eleven cases to court, but were successful in just two of them.</p><p> Longgena said that the results showed how ineffective legal action was in dealing with the problem.</p><p> In one of the successful cases Wahli had demanded two companies operating near Palembang, Sumatra, pay Rp140 billion in compensation for the damage their burning had caused.</p><p> Although the case was won, the court imposed a sanction of only Rp150 million.</p><p> "Businessman should be given concrete punishment, not only lip-service," Longgena said</p><p> Despite the government's ban on land clearing by fire, Longgena said it was still easy to get permission to do it.</p><p> Big business with connections to the former president Suharto was still operating with impunity in the forest and plantation industry.</p><p> "In addition to the old players there are newcomers - cronies of Habibie," Longgena said.</p><p> "It's just like escaping from the tiger's mouth only to be caught in a crocodile's teeth."</p><p> Many of the newcomers had been in other business before the economic crisis.</p><p> "Government policy sponsored by the International Monetary Fund that emphasises opening of investment in agribusiness also worsened the situation after the monetary crisis," he said.</p><p> AAP kjp/arb</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1999</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3X3H-S990-0048-T3WX-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-26</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="637"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1999 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:3WCP-F890-0048-T4SJ-00000-00<published>1999-05-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>World News In Brief</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>WORLD DATELINES    PHIL DROWNING<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">MANILA, May 2 AP - Nine people, including children, drowned during a picnic on a northern Philippine beach, police said today.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The victims, aged 11 to 23, were swimming at a beach resort in Currimao town in Ilocos Norte province when they were overwhelmed by strong undercurrents.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The bodies of eight victims have been recovered by the Coast Guard and local fishermen.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The victims were part of a large religious fellowship group from Bulacan province north of Manila, which had gone on a summer outing.</p><p>AP</p><p>COLOMBIA FIGHTING</p><p> BOGOTA, May 2 Reuters - Three clashes across Colombia had killed nine soldiers, a police officer and four rebels, Colombian media reported today.</p><p> The worst fighting took place in and around the town of Dabeiba on the edge of the violent northwest banana-growing region of Uraba late yesterday.</p><p> A 150-strong column of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) rebels stormed the town and destroyed a number of buildings using gas cylinders packed with explosives, local media reported citing army sources.</p><p> The rebels then ambushed an army unit sent in to reinforce the town, killing six soldiers.</p><p> In a separate incident, FARC fighters raided the town of La Uvita, in central Boyaca province, killing one policeman late yesterday, a municipal spokeswoman said.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>FINLAND STABBINGS</p><p> HELSINKI, May 2 Reuters - A gang of teenagers stabbed 13 people in a rampage through the West Finland town of Turku last night, Finnish television news reported today.</p><p> It said the victims were treated in hospital, where one was in a critical condition.</p><p> The apparently random attacks took place in central Turku where the youths, aged from 14 to 18, were celebrating May Day, typically an occasion for heavy drinking in Finland.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>VENEZUELA VIOLENCE</p><p> CARACAS, May 2 AFP - Four police officers and three robbers were killed and seven officers were injured during a shootout after a bank holdup in the western town of Bocono, police said today.</p><p> The shooting took place after a robbery bank in which the robbers made off with 100 million bolivars ($ A2.44 million) using guns and grenades, said police spokeswoman Odalis Cadera.</p><p> The muggers fled the bank in Bocono, a town in the Andean state of Trujillo, about 300 km west of here.</p><p> Later police confronted the robbers, but four officers and three robbers, two of which have not been identified, were killed in the ensuing shootout.</p><p> All of the money was recovered, officials said.</p><p>AFP</p><p>IRAN WOMEN</p><p> TEHRAN, May 2 Reuters - Iran has outlawed women cyclists at northern seaside resort as an affront to Islamic morality, a newspaper reported today.</p><p> The district governor in charge of Ramsar, formerly a plush holiday resort on Iran's northern Caspian coast, said women cyclists would be prosecuted even if they were covered from head to toe as required by Iran's Islamic laws, Kayhan newspaper said.</p><p> "Women cyclists cannot protect their chastity even if they are fully covered, so they should avoid this altogether or they will be dealt with," the governor said.</p><p> Female cycling is a controversial issue in Iran. Moderate politicians such as MP Faezeh Hashemi, daughter of former president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, have urged women to go out and play sports, including cycling. This has aroused the ire of conservatives who feel this might lead to uncontrolled freedom and promiscuity.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p> CANADA FIRE</p><p> WINNIPEG, Canada, May 2 AFP - About 600 residents of several small communities in Manitoba were forced to leave their homes today because of a nearby forest fire, officials said.</p><p> Unseasonably high temperatures and winds of up to 70km per hour fanned the fire, which began yesterday.</p><p> By today the flames had covered an area of 26km long and 2km wide, close to houses in the region 150km northeast of Winnipeg.</p><p>AFP</p><p> ENDS WORLD DATELINES    AAP/pa<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1999</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3WCP-F890-0048-T4SJ-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-26</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="665"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1999 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P7G-YG90-TXN5-R30K-00000-00CHINESE MINISTER SACKED OVER FIRE1987-06-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 5CHINESE MINISTER SACKED OVER FIREROBERT THOMSON

BEIJING, Sunday: The spread of China's worst forest fire has been blamed on bureaucratic bungling, and the Minister for Forestry, Mr Yang Zhong, has been sacked for dereliction of duty.

Northern China has been hit in recent weeks, by a series of fires, the worst of which killed at least 200 people, razed four towns, made 50,000 people homeless, and burned 700,000 hectares of forest.

A meeting of the ruling state council yesterday held Mr Yang and his ministry responsible for the fire and strongly criticised him for having not written a self-criticism - the Chinese way of admitting fault and seeking the party's forgiveness - until after he was prompted by senior officials.

The acting Premier, Mr Wan Li, said the fire "fully revealed the bureaucratic mismanagement" in the ministry, and quoted the former Chinese leader, Mr Mao Zedong, as saying: "Bureaucratic inertia runs counter to the party's purpose of serving the people with heart and soul."

Mr Yang, 52, who had his character assassinated today by the Chinese media, was also criticised for not having gone to the scene of the fire, in Heilongjiang province, near the Soviet border.

Other sackings could follow, as the State Council has announced an investigation into the ministry and the fire-fighting command.

Diplomats suggested that Mr Yang might be a victim of military dissatisfaction with the government handling of the fire.

Many of the 42,000 fire-fighters were soldiers and the army has been loudly praised for its gallantry.

Forestry officials have already confessed that fire-fighters were hindered by primitive equipment, often nothing more than a branch or water-soaked clothes, and that the building of fire-breaks was badly handled.

But the Government has yet to admit that it made a mistake by refusing on-the-ground assistance from other countries.

Five men have been arrested for accidentally starting fires in Heilongjiang.

Three have been accused of carelessly discarding cigarette butts, while another two men are said to have started blazes through recklessly handling chain-saws.

The Government has not revealed what will be done with them but, given China's record of severe punishment in negligence cases and the damage caused by the fires, they could well be shot.

The official news agency, Xinhua, said the sacking of Yang Zhong showed the"firm determination" of the fight against bureaucracy, and "anything less severe would not be warning enough".

Other than his failure to write a self-criticism and to visit the fire zone, Mr Yang's bureaucratic crimes have not been explained.

The fire appears to have become a sensitive political issue, as the acting Premier stressed the need to stop officials shielding each other from criticism and to stop them working for personal gain - both are much debated matters in a Communist Party stricken by faction-fighting.

Port: Mr Yang ... prompted to write self-criticism.

urn:contentItem:3W7H-4RT0-0048-T3WC-00000-00<published>1999-04-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>World News In Brief</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BANGLADESH CLASH</p><p nitf:lede="true"> DHAKA, April 13 Reuters - Workers at Bangladesh's biggest jute mill clashed with makeshift bombs, guns, knives and hockey sticks today killing one person and wounding more than 100, police said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The battle erupted over recent union elections at the Adamjee mill outside Dhaka which employs 40,000 workers, one officer said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Police fired teargas and blanks to disperse the workers.</p><p nitf:lede="true">REUTERS</p><p nitf:lede="true">TURKEY HEROIN</p><p nitf:lede="true">ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 13 AP - Police have seized 73 kilograms of heroin bound for Europe and detained five people on charges of drug smuggling, officials said today.</p><p>The heroin, which has an estimated street value of $ US8 million, ($ A12.66 million) was from Iran and was on its way to Belgium, police said. The drugs were hidden in two vans.</p><p> Police said one of the detained men was a suspected militant of the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party or PKK. Authorities have in the past accused the group of drug smuggling.</p><p> In a separate drug haul today, police in the southern city of Adana seized another 24 kilograms of heroin and arrested seven suspects, the Anatolia news agency reported. The drugs, worth some $ US400,000, ($ A633,200) were bound for Germany.</p><p>AP</p><p>CUBA FIRE</p><p> HAVANA, April 13 Reuters - Cuban firefighters said today they had brought under control, but not yet extinguished, a large forest fire which has ravaged pine and eucalyptus woods for more than four days in western Cuba.</p><p> The blaze, which began last Thursday in the municipality of Guane, was one of the biggest reported in western Pinar del Rio province, which contains Cuba's largest forest reserves.</p><p> blaze have used bulldozers to cut firebreaks to stop the flames from spreading. Planes have also flown daily sorties to bombard parts of the fire with water and chemicals.</p><p> State media said the blaze had affected an area of between 7,000 and 8,000 hectares.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>CUBA SEX</p><p> HAVANA, April 13 Reuters - A court in eastern Cuba has sentenced five Cuban men and two women to jail terms of between three and 30 years for sex offences involving schoolgirls, an official Cuban newspaper said today.</p><p> The Communist Party daily Granma said the seven were convicted by the court in Camaguey province of repeated crimes of "corruption of minors" and procuring. They were accused of forcing a group of secondary school girls to perform sex acts, using promises of money, and in some cases, threats of physical force.</p><p> Of the five men convicted, three received jail terms of 30 years, one was sentenced to 27 years and another to 10. The two women were given jail terms of 12 and three years respectively.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>BRAZIL SNAKES</p><p> BRASILIA, April 13 Reuters - Firefighters were called in today to evict a family of rattlesnakes which has slithered across the ceilings and walls of Brazil's Justice Ministry for two weeks, fraying the nerves of anxious civil servants.</p><p> "You don't know what it's like to work in a place with snakes moving around over your head. They can fall down any time through holes" in the ceiling, one secretary complained.</p><p> An electrician working on the fourth floor noticed a large rattlesnake and five offspring two weeks ago, speculating that the venomous creatures entered the building through air-conditioning vents.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>GERMANY HELICOPTER</p><p> BERLIN, April 13 DPA - Four German air force personnel were killed when their Bundeswehr Bell UH 1-D military helicopter crashed at the military section of Berlin's Tegel Airport today, the defence ministry said.</p><p> The helicopter was on a training flight and was preparing to land when it crashed, a ministry spokesman he said.</p><p> The cause of the crash was not immediately clear, he said.</p><p> DPA</p><p> ENDS WORLD DATELINES    <br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1999</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3W7H-4RT0-0048-T3WC-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-26</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="630"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1999 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P7G-YGC0-TXN5-R38G-00000-00REGULAR SHORTS1987-05-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:56:00ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESBriefsPg. 23REGULAR SHORTSJohn Stevens for Prince Charles story and Robert Thompson for China story

PRINCE SAMPLES DAILY TOIL

LONDON, Friday: Prince Charles is back from another unannounced private holiday, this time sampling the life and daily toil of a crofter on a remote Scottish island. Dressed in dungarees and gumboots he planted potatoes, helped to build drystone walls and tended sheep during three days this week on the tiny island of Berneray, population 120, in the Outer Hebrides. - JOHN STEVEN

GANDHI CALLS FOR SUPPORT

NEW DELHI, Friday: India's Prime Minister, Mr Rajiv Gandhi, has called for a public rally here tomorrow against subversive forces the Government says are trying to bring it down. Organisers of the ruling Congress (I) Party expect about a million people to fill the capital's Boat Club grounds, near the parliament building, to hear Mr Gandhi at his first public appearance since allegations of government corruption began flying last month. - AFP

POLICE WARNING TO SIKHS

LONDON, Friday: British police said they would be prepared to break into a London Sikh temple again if clashes, which left four injured last weekend, recurred this week. Sixty policemen intervened last Sunday to quell fighting inside Crabtree Manorway temple in Belvedere, South London, after a man had his throat cut with a sword and three others were stabbed in fights over the re-election of officials to the temple committee. Police arrested 49 people. - Reuter

LIFE FOR DRUGS KILLING

NEW YORK, Friday: Three Colombians convicted of the 1986 machine gun killing of a federal drug informant have been sentenced to life in prison. The men, Bernardo Vasquez, Miguel Velez and Luis Carlos Quintero-Cruz, appeared relieved when the jury's verdict was returned, according to witnesses in the courtroom. Prosecutors had pushed for the death penalty, saying the men accepted a $US500,000 ($A703,250) contract to kill the informant. - Reuter China-India clashes denied

CHINA_INDIA CLASHES DENIED

BEIJING, Friday: China and India have denied that fighting has broken out along their shared border, though both countries have been moving a large number of troops to the border area. The Chinese Foreign Ministry described as"sheer fabrication" a report in a Finnish newspaper that many wounded Chinese soldiers were being treated in the Tibetan capital, Lhasa, and that Chinese transport planes had moved further troops to the border. - ROBERT THOMSON

PLAN TO QUELL FIRE FAILS

BEIJING, Friday: A plan to trigger artificial rain over a nine-day-old forest fire in north-east China which has killed at least 162 people and made 50,000 homeless has failed so far, the official New China News Agency said. Three aircraft have been "seeding" clouds over burning Mohe County and neighbouring areas close to the Soviet border since yesterday, the agency said. - Reuter
