urn:contentItem:3W6C-5SC0-0048-T50Y-00000-00<published>1999-04-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>World News In Brief</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">UK ABSCOND</p><p nitf:lede="true"> LONDON, April 8 AFP - British police were today hunting for 12 rugby players from Cote d'Ivoire believed to have absconded in an attempt to avoid flying home.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The men, all aged 18, had been competing in an Under-19 tournament for the past 10 days in Wales, and were due to fly back home later today.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> South Wales police believe they were heading for London.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Six of the players, who all speak French, but little English, went missing after a meal in Cardiff on Sunday. Their colleagues disappeared from lodgings at a college in mid-Wales the following day.</p><p>AFP</p><p> ROYALS WEDGEWOOD</p><p> LONDON, April 8 AFP - Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, was to be the United States spokeswoman for the Wedgwood pottery and china firm, the Sun tabloid daily reported today.</p><p> The daily, which has strong royal contacts, said she had already made a pilot film for Wedgwood to show how she could help boost its image.</p><p> She has insisted she will only represent the firm in the United States and not in Britain because she does not want to upset the royal family.</p><p> Wedgwood, which is based in Stoke in central England, has a royal warrant from Queen Elizabeth.</p><p>AFP</p><p>VIETNAM ARAFAT</p><p> HANOI, April 8 AFP - Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat would make a two day official visit to Vietnam this week, officials said today.</p><p> Arafat would arrive Friday at the invitation of President Tran Duc Luong, the foreign ministry said.</p><p> Diplomatic sources said Arafat would discuss the Middle East peace process with Vietnamese leaders.</p><p> Hanoi has been a staunch supporter of the Palestinian cause while also seeking to develop economic ties with Israel.</p><p>AFP</p><p> CHINA FIRES</p><p> BEIJING, April 8 AFP - Water-carrying planes have been brought in to help thousands of soldiers and civilians fighting forest fires which have raged for six days in northern China claiming 23 lives, officials said today.</p><p> Artificial cloud bursts over Fenyang county helped bring one blaze under control late yesterday, an official with the Shanxi at the provincial forest fire headquarters told AFP.</p><p> But a fire in neighbouring Wenshui county was still only partially under control and a plane was due to induce cloud bursts over the area later this morning, he said.</p><p> The charred bodies of 23 villagers who died in the first days of the fire were recovered yesterday, the official Xinhua news agency said.</p><p>AFP</p><p> HK SMUGGLE</p><p>HONG KONG, April 8 AFP - China has arrested 16 people for four separate incidents of trying to smuggle human cargo into Hong Kong and Macau over the past two weeks, it was reported today.</p><p> since March 24, the China-backed Ta Kung Pao said in report.</p><p> In the most recent incident, 12 women and two men were detained as they prepared to board wooden boats to take them from Zhuhai to Macau, it said.</p><p> Chinese authorities have in recent months stepped up measures to stem increasing numbers of illegal immigrants heading to Hong Kong and Macau, the report said.</p><p>AFP</p><p>MALAYSIA SUGAR</p><p>KUALA LUMPUR, April 8 DPA - Malaysia was set to slash the amount of sugar allowed in manufactured soft drinks following concern over the rising number of obese and diabetic Malaysians, reports said today.</p><p> The move has met some resistance in the bottled drinks industry, especially from foreign manufacturers worried the change in sugar levels would affect the taste of their drinks.</p><p> Deputy Health Minister Mohamed Ali Rustam said some firms have threatened to close down their operations.</p><p> Under the proposed amendments to the Food Regulations Act, sugar content in soft drinks would be reduced by about half. A limit of six grams of sugar per 100 millilitres will be imposed.</p><p> A can of soft drink now contains about seven teaspoons of sugar.</p><p> DPA</p><p> ENDS WORLD DATELINES    AAP pa<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1999</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3W6C-5SC0-0048-T50Y-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-26</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="644"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1999 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:57TS-77M1-JD34-V310-00000-00LETTERS2013-02-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisNEWSLettersPg. 12LETTERS

Depriving children for political gain

I AM appalled that Ted Baillieu is prepared to deny Victorian schoolchildren the right to fair and equitable funding for a quality education under the federal Gonski reforms ("Baillieu's school plan spoiler", 23/2). How dare he and his parochial Education Minister put wealthy private schools and the political support of the Abbott-led Coalition ahead of our children. It is clear, with the recent hypocritical behaviour over hospital funding, that the Victorian government is making our people suffer in order to prevent the Gillard government from achieving policy success.

So what if some wealthy schools lose some of their funding. Schools that can pay $500,000 a year for a principal and can spend $20 million buying a property next door do not need funding from the scarce education funds. The current funding model gives too much to private schools and not enough to public schools. This must change. Mr Baillieu must be told that he cannot deprive our children just so that he can support Tony Abbott.

Margaret Ludowyk, Brunswick

Not so good advice

YOUR editorial "Danger lurks where city meets the bush" (21/2) expressed concerns about the danger to hundreds of residents trapped in a traffic gridlock as they tried to obey orders to evacuate from a grass fire threat near Epping North.

The problem is not so much ineffective road infrastructure hindering "escape" as the ineffective and erroneous official post-2009 advice that promotes evacuation.

Whether leaving is the safest option depends on a great many factors. Mass evacuation from grass or forest fire is inherently dangerous, usually far more so than is home defence. It was especially unnecessary from the "neatly manicured", almost bare-of-vegetation Epping North and Wollert housing estate.

Even the pro-"escape" official line urges it only on code-red days for residents of high-risk areas. This was neither such a day nor such an area.

The best advice to have given those residents was not to evacuate, but to mow grass alongside timber fences, close windows and doors, put on cover-all clothing and stand by with hoses, and mops in buckets of water, to douse any sparks. Time wasted in getting out is better spent preventing sparks and embers from getting in.

Joan Webster, Castlemaine

Clearly affordable

I AGREE with Greens leader Christine Milne that if BHP can afford to pay Marius Kloppers $75 million for a mediocre performance, then BHP can afford to pay a more realistic mining tax to the Australian people ("Kloppers payout obscene: Greens", 23/2). Ditto for other corporations who overpay their chief executives. Where are the other parties on this issue? Are they afraid of losing the donations from vested interests with an election coming up?

Barry Lizmore, East Geelong

Wasting our money

I WAS outraged to see the full-page advertisement for the federal government's health funding (The Saturday Age, 23/2). The ad served no public purpose. An election has been called, and the government is using public money to support its own re-election campaign. Victorians would be better off if the government spent more money providing health services and less trying to save its political skin.

Stewart Maiden, Camberwell

New party time

LIKE Mary Lane (Letters, 22/2), I, too, find the current Australian political landscape utterly desolate. I suggest we form a new political party, the VIP - Vote Informal Party.

If you find the idea of voting for the Labor Party in its current incarnation impossible, or believe that the Greens have lost all credibility, or know that voting for Tony Abbott is simply too awful to contemplate, then the Vote Informal Party is the one for you. Do I have your vote?

Monica Clarke, Port Melbourne

Equality in care

ELDERLY lesbian, gay, bisexual transgender and intersex people are so afraid of prejudice and discrimination in aged care that they are not accessing the services they desperately need. Many aged-care service providers are faith-based organisations, and especially in some rural and regional areas, there is no choice - it's a faith-based provider or nothing.

The bottom line: our taxes should not be funding organisations that discriminate against us.

Surely that's only fair. That's one reason why the new anti-discrimination legislation should be passed.

Sujay Kentlyn, Stanmore, NSW

Keep out all bigots

CORY Bernardi complains of a "double standard" on free speech ("Senator backs Wilders tour", 21/2). His notion of fairness entails that if a bigot of one kind is allowed into Australia, then we must balance this by admitting a bigot of a different kind. My view is we don't need bigots of any kind - especially not of the Geert Wilders type. His intemperate outbursts against Muslims are cringeworthy.

Bigots are bigots. It doesn't matter what they're for or against, we must not give them air. Words are acts and they hurt. They damage relations. We have enough bigots of our own. We do not need to import them.

Marietta Elliott-Kleerkoper, Fairfield

Proper ratings

THOMAS Baker's assertion (Letters, 22/2) that the R18+ classification for video games is damaging to society is specious. While many minors can access MA15+ games with ease, some MA15+ games released, unedited, in Australia are actually classified R18+ overseas, including titles in the popular Fallout and Grand Theft Auto series. The R18+ rating will allow proper classification of the games released in Australia, nothing more.

In addition, while some people in the US may "attribute" gun-related violence to video games, no link has been scientifically demonstrated. Besides, with the lack of guns in this country, how are people supposed to enact gun violence? Petty scaremongering achieves little of substance.

Eddie La Marca, Heidelberg

Easy as 1, 2, 3

THE chief of the Australian Grand Prix Corporation, running the most finely tuned and intricately engineered vehicles outside Cape Canaveral, reckons that, "due to the size and temporary nature of the Albert Park circuit, we use a methodology that includes a variety of inputs, including ticket sales, to calculate estimated attendances for each day of the event" ("Government blocks move for grand prix headcount", 23/2). Hand-held scanners, barcoded tickets and (temporary) turnstiles are beyond Bernie and the boys? Must be all those fumes.

Leonard Colquhoun, Invermay, Tasmania

Malodorous

LAST week, while on my way to the booking office at the Arts Centre, I had occasion to pass Flinders Street Station. No sooner had I set foot on the kerb outside the station than I was assailed by the stench of urine. This olfactory assault continued for the length of the facade of the station.

During the course of this perambulation, I espied a young busker, plying his trade amid the pong. When I returned that evening (on my way to War Horse), he was still there. It must surely be injurious to his health to spend all day (and half the night) imbibing these noxious exhalations. I call upon the lord mayor and councillors to immediately rectify this deplorable situation. What must visitors to Melbourne think to find that this iconic building is little better than a stinking public lavatory?

Allan Wade, Preston

Getting of wisdom

ONE of the many wise and discerning proverbs of Solomon is, "The fool says in his heart 'there is no God"'. The arrogance and megalomania we humans sometimes display, especially in our youth (no offence to youth) is an understandable defence, when facing adulthood, against not knowing much in a big, scary world. But I think it sad if, in more than 50 years since becoming a university student, Germaine Greer has not relinquished either arrogance or foolishness ("Greer can't protest enough", 21/2), both in extolling a goal to lose one's virginity per se, and also in a declaration that God does not exist.

Rosemary Steer, Croydon

Into the fold

I HAVE been a loyal Age reader for more than 30 years, and in that time I have learnt to fold The Age in any conditions, small toilets and on windy days. Now that you are going to a "compact" size, can you include in the next few weeks' issues instructions on how to fold a little paper?

Gary Florence, Hampton Park

CARTOON: BRUCE PETTY

urn:contentItem:4P7G-YGB0-TXN5-R3F0-00000-00THOUSANDS EVACUATED AS HUGE FIRE NEARS FOREST1987-05-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 12THOUSANDS EVACUATED AS HUGE FIRE NEARS FORESTJOHN NGAI

BEIJING, Monday: A huge forest fire raging in China is only one kilometre from a vast virgin forest in the north-east province of Inner Mongolia and thousands of people are being evacuated from its path. About 20,000 people are fighting the blaze.

The New China News Agency said the fire's eastern wing had been contained with firebreaks 300 km long hacked out of the forest by soldiers over the past two weeks.

Fire fighters are using artillery shells to seed clouds with rain-making chemicals in an effort to stop the blaze, the biggest in China for 40 years.

Provincial officials in Harbin, capital of Heilongjiang province, said demolition experts had been flown in from Beijing to meet engineers here and examine the possibility of containing the blaze by using explosives.

A relief official in Harbin said the battle against the western wing of the flames was being lost. He said the fire had crossed into Inner Mongolia and the authorities had begun evacuating the towns of Fuzhun and Mangui, each with a population of more than 20,000.

The fire has killed more than 200 people and destroyed the homes of 50,000 since May 6.

A railway official said more than 6,000 refugees had arrived in Harbin in the past two days. Reporters saw trains coming in packed with people, some with household goods hanging out of the windows.

One relief official said the refugees were being given free train tickets to travel to any place in China to join relatives.

Refugees said light drizzle fell on parts of Heilongjiang today, stemming the fire for the time being.

"This is help from the God of Heaven," said Mr Sung Rongji, 64, a peasant just evacuated from the threatened town of Tahe. "Now there is hope of putting out the fire soon."

Mr Sung said firefighters, including troops, had managed to contain the flames by hacking out a firebreak two kilometres north of Tahe last week but the town of 30,000 people was again threatened when the wind changed direction over the weekend.

"My sons were still there with the soldiers. Some of the troops were injured and had to be evacuated to the rear like us," he said.

Heilongjiang is China's major timber-producing area. The blaze has already destroyed 600,000 hectares of forest, estimated by one official to be worth more than 400 million yuan (about $A180 million).

At least 92 people have been killed and over 400 injured in floods in southern China over the past few days, the official Guangdong Radio station said yesterday. The station also said 20,000 houses had collapsed.

It said 1.1 million people had been affected by the floods, but said the rainstorms had stopped and river levels were now receding

urn:contentItem:4DB4-JMG0-0045-51K7-00000-00<published>2004-09-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>A;</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Fire expert agrees it could not be stopped</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Megan Doherty</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">It wouldn't have mattered "two hoots" what the fuel levels were in the Stromlo pine forest once the fire reached it on January 18 last year because the blaze was unstoppable, the ACT Coroners Court heard yesterday.Bushfire behaviour expert Phil Cheney agreed with that propositionput to him under cross-examination by John Watts, counsel for various individuals involved in the January 2003 bushfires, includingACT Forests staff."Certainly unstoppable, yes," Mr Cheney said of the fire at Stromlo.The first day of cross-examination of Mr Cheney, a key witness to the inquiry into the bushfires, focused on the response by the NSW authorities after fires broke out on January8 last year; fuel managementin the pine and native forests and the ability to predict the spread of the fire.Mr Cheney, under questioning by Mr Watts, also reiterated his belief that fire was a "chaotic chemical reaction" and that the prediction of fire behaviour at any point in time had a "wide error margin".However, Mr Cheney told the court bushfire planners should still try to predict as much as possible what could happen if the fire escaped control.He did agree with Mr Watts it was a "pretty good piece of planning" by ACT Forests officer Hilton Taylor, who was working in the planning unit of the Emergency Services Bureau during the bushfires and who by 9am on January18 had predicted the fire could impact on Weston Creek by 3pm.He also agreed under cross-examination that before the fire hit the pines, it travelled through eucalyptforests with fuel loads of 20-30 tonnes per hectare when the level should be kept at no more than eight tonnes per hectare.</p><p>Mr Cheney recommended more extensive pruning of pine trees near urban areas to 8m above the ground and 500m into the forest.He said fuel management could not prevent fires but there was evidence from 2003 that efforts to reduce fuels and create "crownfire-free zones" in some areas of the pines had reduced the intensity of the fires.Mr Watts suggested pruning pine trees was expensive and Mr Cheney had not costed his recommend-ations.Mr Cheney said he believed it was a cost that should be worn if plantations were put close to urban areas or else the pines should be put elsewhere. Under cross-examination by counsel for the NSW Rural Fire Service Christopher Erskine, Mr Cheney suggested NSW authorities might have shown a lack of experience in fighting forest fires in one of their decisions not to start backburning from a particular trail in the Brindabellas during benign weather early in last year's emergency.Earlierevidence from a NSW incident controller, Bruce Arthur, has suggested he did not want to start the backburning without the support of aerial resources because of the steep, serpentine nature of the trail and that any fire above or below personnel on the trail was "tantamount to a death sentence".Mr Cheney said he believed while the trail was winding, there were "ample places to seek refuge" in cleared areas along it."So you wouldn't describe it as a death trap in sensible fire fighting terms. Perhaps that reflects a lack of experience in forest fire fighting," he said.Mr Erskine quoted extensively from logs which were part of the NSWRFS and NSW National Parks and Wildlife submission to last year's NSW coronial inquiry into the fires.He said the logs showed on January8 that the Mount Coree tower spotted smoke in the Brindabellas just before 3.30pm. By 5.40pm, an air observer estimated the McIntyre's Hut fire was 200 hectares in size, and by 5.52pm there was a report of embers being driven to as far as Fairlight, 10-12km away.Mr Cheney agreed with Mr Erskinethat the fire had become an impressive one in a short period of time and that NSW authorities were confronted with eight fires (includingthree in the ACT) on January 8.However, Mr Cheney still believed NSW should have sent crews to the fires on January 8 for a proper on-ground assessment because "they should have known they were going into a falling fire danger period, that the fire behaviourwould decrease in that country at night".Counsel for the ACT is expected to cross-examine Mr Cheney today.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata THE SIXTH PARTITAby Juliet Hoey

Zeus Publications

rrp $23.95An exciting suspenseful thriller from a Brisbane author follows the

trials of gifted pianist Helen O'Donnell, who

is plagued by a career-threatening bout of stage fright and is

being stalked by a

crim with a musical bent. When the

baddie latches on to Bach's Sixth Partita,

which Helen is studying, things become decidedly eerie.IN A WORD: Melodic

WHAT GOES UP: BEHIND THE

2007 ELECTIONby Nicholas Stuart

Scribe

rrp $32.95 Nicholas Stuart examines the issues

that helped place Kevin07 in power.

For instance, why did the Libs stick with a jaded John Howard? How did Labor overcome such large margins in so many seats? Stuart analyses the backroom plotting, the campaign trail and the key figures.IN A WORD: Political

rrp $29.95Much-loved Maggie tackles post-40 womanhood with typical wit and wisdom. Determined to learn the rules for older women, she asks the big questions: Is it OK to wear a bikini after 40? Macmillan

rrp $32.95When her elderly neighbour Gus is injured and needs a nurse, Kinsey is unconvinced by the background check on applicant Solana. Her suspicions grow as Gus's condition worsens. What follows is a story filled with courage, beauty, grace . . . and surgery.IN A WORD: Snip

Century

rrp $32.951The drama unfolds as Robbie Fraser enters a Scottish village to find the father he never knew. Only Heather offers him friendship and through her Robbie learns of the bitter feud between their dads. Heather is sure her old man is behind the disappearance of Hamish Fraser and

a baffling mystery

is uncovered. IN A WORD: Compelling

Century

It comprises three novellas, Lord John and the Hellfire Club, Lord John and the Succubus and Lord John and the Haunted Soldier. rrp $59.953Stunning images and the latest scientific data show how our planet operates. Chapters explores how important forces, from meteor impacts, plate tectonics, the ocean, atmosphere and ice, play a role in keeping us alive. The authors discuss the big events in the planet's past and insight into where it's going. A beautiful book.IN A WORD: Global

BORN STANDING UPby Steve Martin

Simon & Schuster

rrp $34.95A fine and whimsical writer, Steve Martin tells of his rise as a stand-up comedian and explains why he quit at the height of his fame to go into the movies. The person revealed is a man dedicated to his craft and firm in his ambitions. The pages devoted to family affairs are particularly moving, while elsewhere he captures the spirit of the '60s and '70s.IN A WORD: Rewarding

0THE BOOK OF

ANIMAL IGNORANCEby John Lloyd & John Mitchinson

Faber & Faber

rrp $29.95Water bears that can live in suspension for centuries. Cat parasites that make men grumpy and women randy. A woodlouse that drinks through its bum. Pigs that glow in the dark and elephants walking on tiptoe. Here's an entertaining safari to find 120 of the most bizarre members of the animal kingdom.IN A WORD: Zoological

1THE TOYBOY DIARIESby Wendy Salisbury

Developing an unquenchable desire, for the next 20 years Wendy bonks as many younger men as she can and is unashamed about it. ``I like older men, but I couldn't eat a whole one. A younger man? That's another story,'' she says.IN A WORD: Brazen

2CITY OF FIREby Robert Ellis

Macmillan

rrp $32.95A deft thriller. LA detective Lena Gamble's first major case is a doozy as she finds herself on the trail of a brutal serial killer. It's not the first time Lena's been in the public eye. Five years ago her rock star brother was murdered and the crime remains unsolved. As a forest fire threatens the city, Lena's probing becomes very personal and very dangerous.IN A WORD: Gripping

urn:contentItem:4P8H-NV60-TXN5-S0CW-00000-00(Earthweek - Diary of a Planet)1994-02-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisNEWSEarthweek - Diary of a PlanetPg. 6(Earthweek - Diary of a Planet)Environment WatchSteve Newman

Earthquake fever.

As aftershocks continued to rumble beneath the Los Angeles Basin, scientists have discovered that the disastrous 17 January tremor is responsible for an outbeak of a flu-like illness called Valley Fever.

Tonnes of dust in the mountainous areas east of the city were scattered into the atmosphere, carrying spores of the fungus into victims' lungs. At least 35 people in the San Fernando Valley suffered fever, respiratory ailments, sore muscles and fatigue.

A series of powerful earthquakes killed at least six people and destroyed 300 houses in north-eastern Iran. Earth movements were also felt in southern Iran, south-eastern Romania, the central Philippines, Costa Rica, Japan's Hokkaido Island, Vanuatu and eastern Idaho.

Atlantic tragedy.

The gaunt carcasses of as many as 50,000 sea birds, possibly starved to death while battling gales, have washed ashore around Britain. Most of the dead birds are common guillemots, a medium-sized diving bird with a pointed and narrow beak. "They're all thin, there's no fat on them," said Mr Martin Heubeck, an Aberdeen University ornithologist based in the Shetland Islands, the worst-affected area. Mr Heubeck speculated that the seabirds might have been exhausted by persistent strong south-easterly winds that have blown during the past few weeks.

Wild winds.

Blizzards and strong winds killed at least one person and injured seven others as tempests lashed northern Japan. A motorist was killed in a 20-car pile-up in Nagano. In Iwate, strong winds derailed a train, injuring seven passengers.

Mud slides.

Thirteen people are confirmed dead and 34 people missing in South Africa after a wall of sludge engulfed homes after heavy rain burst a gold mine storage dam in the town of Virginia in the Orange Free State.

Rivers of mud poured down coastal canyons of southern California denuded by last year's fires. A handful of Malibu residents were trapped briefly inside their homes.

Winter twisters.

Powerful tornadoes tore through a wide area of south-eastern Texas, destroying an airport hangar and several homes in Bee County.

Snake invasion.

Battered by a violent volcanic eruption in 1991 and plagued recently by typhoons and locusts, Filipinos living near Mount Pinatubo are facing a new menace _ poisonous snakes. The deadly reptiles, including cobras, have been lured to the area by an infestation of locusts that have destroyed rice, vegetable and banana crops. Farmers have been reluctant to catch the locusts in nets or to spray for them out of fear of being bitten by the snakes.

Fires threaten wildlife.

A forest fire devastated one of Panama's most important wildlife reserves and threatened to spread into nearby communities. The blaze broke out on the slopes of Baru Volcano, in the western highlands, and has destroyed nearly 200 hectares of woodland harboring numerous rare species.

Feline odyssey.

A wayward cat made headlines throughout Italy by finding its way home over 200 kilometres of mountainous terrain during a 20-month ordeal.

Little three-year-old Briciola (Crumbs) showed up at its owners' home in Savone, emaciated, with bloodied legs and missing all its claws.

The owners, Pinuccia and Pierluigi Vigliano, said the animal had jumped aboard a moving van bound for the city of Cuneo in the summer of 1992. But the odyssey came to a tragic end when, after a vet's examination, the prodigal feline dropped dead from exhaustion.

urn:contentItem:59NK-3JW1-F0JP-W3JC-00000-00Bushfires raise temperature of climate row2013-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 16Bushfires raise temperature of climate rowJAMIE WALKER, ASSOCIATE EDITOR

Attempts to pin recent losses on global warming have met fierce resistance

PHILIP Gibbons has vivid memories of the one that nearly got away in Bemm River. It was a bushfire, not a fish, and he had been called out to protect the sleepy Victorian township after the surrounding forest went up on a hot, windy October day in 1988.

``It was a killer day,'' says Gibbons, who is now a land management expert at the Australian National University.

``There were fires everywhere. The whole thing just took off.''

Despite suggestions to the contrary, there is nothing new about the landscape of southern Australia burning ahead of the acknowledged summer bushfire season.

This will be of limited consolation to the families of the two men who died fighting blazes in the Blue Mountains and southern NSW, not to mention the owners of the 200-plus homes that have been destroyed in the ongoing emergency. But it is central to the debate on whether the incidence and severity of bushfires in Australia can be blamed on climate change and, if so, what can be done to abate the risk.

Arguably, that discussion descended to a new low when Greens deputy leader Adam Bandt tweeted: ``Why Tony Abbott's plan means more bushfires for Australia and more pics like this of Sydney,'' alongside an image of the NSW capital wreathed in smoke.

After Environment Minister Greg Hunt accused Bandt of politicising a tragedy, the UN's point woman on climate change, Christiana Figueres, declared that bushfires were ``absolutely'' linked to global warming and the flames ringing Sydney were a harbinger of what was to come if emission levels didn't fall. The Prime Minister hit back, describing bushfires as part of the Australian experience and accusing her of ``talking out of her hat'' -- earning a rebuke from former US vice-president and climate change activist Al Gore.

Abbott then ramped up the rhetoric in an interview with syndicated News group columnist Andrew Bolt, published yesterday, dismissing any link between climate change and the NSW bushfires as ``complete hogwash''.

Gibbons, a senior lecturer with the Fennes School of Environment and Society at ANU, shakes his head. ``We know that bushfires have happened before in October, we know they have sometimes been very severe. That's not the issue. The question is: are we going to get more of these?''

In its recent fifth report, the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change said bushfires were set to increase in hotter and drier parts of the world.

That was an ominous portent for Australia's fire-prone southeast. But the trouble with bushfires is they don't fit into neat categories. Disasters such as the Black Saturday fires that killed 173 people in Victoria on February 7, 2009, are the deadly product of a chain reaction involving high temperatures, fuel loads, the dryness of the bush, humidity, wind and population demographics.

And as we saw this week when the army was pinged for starting the State Mine blaze at the centre of the Blue Mountains emergency during a live-firing exercise, there must be an ignition source, which can as readily be human as an act of nature.

Climate scientists, firefighters, experts in fire behaviour and ecologists argue about which factor is more important, and how bushfires slot into the threat matrix of global warming.

Still, Richard Thorton, chief executive of the government-backed Bushfire and Natural Hazards Co-operative Research Centre, says one point can be made with confidence: ``You can't attribute any particular fire to global warming or climate change in any sense.''

The CSIRO's Kevin Hennessy concurs. A principal research scientist on climate impacts, he has helped model how the bushfire risk in Australia will be affected by climate change under the scenarios used by the IPCC to predict warming. The study found the number of extreme fire danger days in southeast Australia generally increases 5-25 per cent by 2020 for a low-emission scenario and 15-65 per cent for a high scenario. By 2050, the increases are 10-50 per cent for a low scenario and 100-300 per cent for a high scenario. That means more days with total fire bans.

While it's almost impossible to attribute an individual extreme weather event to climate change, he says the general risk of fire has increased due to a warming and drying trend that is partly due to rising greenhouse gas levels.

As Tasmanian fire scientist David Bowman says, our wide brown land is configured to ``burn and burn and . . . burn again''. The fiery cycle starts in the Top End in the dry season, with the bushfire seasons tracking south in tandem with rising temperatures.

Grass fires erupt in central and southeast Queensland in early spring while humidity is relatively low. For central and southern NSW the danger peaks in December and January; in Victoria and Tasmania it tends to be in February and March.

Again, there are exceptions. In 1994 Canberra's bushfire season opened in August, in the depths of its frosty winter. This year's new year celebrations were barely over when Tasmania's Tasman Peninsula was engulfed by fires that claimed 126 homes but, near miraculously, not a single life.

This could be seen to bear out a recent study by researchers Hamish Clarke, Christopher Lucas and Peter Smith, published in the International Journal of Climatology, that suggests fire seasons were becoming longer and the conflagrations more intense. Yet there was an important caveat to their findings: ``Although these trends are consistent with projected impacts of climate change . . . this study cannot separate the influence of climate change, if any, with that of natural variability,'' they reported.

The issue of fuel-load management generates intense heat. Sydneysider Christine Findlay, who earned a PhD in bushfire management from the University of NSW and styles herself as a whistleblower, argues that firestorms give the appearance of being caused by global warming, when the problem is actually the build-up of fuel on the forest floor.

John Handmer, a lead author of last year's special report for the IPCC on managing the risk of climate-related extremes and disasters, says people tend to focus on fuel loads because they can be tackled, albeit with limited success. ``We can't do much about the weather,'' he says, ``but we think we can do something about the fuel loads.''

The royal commission into the 2009 Black Saturday bushfires recommended preventive burning be doubled in Victoria to reduce fuel loads, a target the state has struggled to meet.

While fuel loads are crucial, Handmer, the director of Centre for Risk and Community Safety at Melbourne's RMIT University, says their relative importance declines as fire conditions deteriorate.

Take Black Saturday. The bush north and east of Melbourne was primed to burn by heatwave conditions that culminated in a 45C day, turning leaves and undergrowth to tinder. The Forest Fire Danger Index was off the scale. Investigators would identify multiple ignition points, some deliberately lit. The landscape was hilly and homes dotted the ridgelines, allowing the flames to rush on to them after crowning in the thick eucalypt forests.

But the killer factor was the wind, in Handmer's assessment. ``It's true that fire intensity is partly a factor of how dry and hot it is . . . but if there is no wind you have got a good chance of containing that fire, no matter what the other circumstances,'' he says. ``If there is very strong wind . . . the ability to control that fire really goes down.''

Yesterday, Will Steffen of the Climate Council -- the successor of the Climate Commission abolished by Abbott -- insisted it was a ``no brainer'' that rising temperatures made fires more likely, but that did not mean those still raging in NSW could be attributed directly to climate change.

Echoing what Gibbons tells Inquirer, he said: ``The issue is not whether they are caused by climate change,'' he said. ``The question is, is there an influence? Is the nature of these extreme events shifting because the climate is shifting? And the answer is unequivocally they are.''

Climatic records have continued to tumble. Australia experienced its hottest month on record in January, and the monthly average for September was the warmest to be logged. On top of that, August and September were especially dry in the Sydney region.

Gibbons finds another set of statistics just as compelling: Australia's population is set to increase by 65 per cent by 2050, to 36 million. ``The same fire occurring in the Blue Mountains in 2050 would destroy 300 homes, not 200,'' he warns.

By analysing weather data dating back to 1973, Hennessy and his team predicted that extreme fire weather days in the Blue Mountains area would increase from 1.5 days a year to four by 2050 under the worst of the IPCC's emission scenarios.

That is consistent with what could be expected from climate change as currently forecast, but with the ``large variation in fire danger from year to year'', he says much more research is needed.

urn:contentItem:4JYT-DCN0-TX4S-M31R-00000-00Sorry to bother you but the poor are still dying in their thousands2006-05-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisAPg. 13Sorry to bother you but the poor are still dying in their thousandsBono

MAY I say without guile, I am as sick of messianic rock stars as the next man, woman and child. I am also tired of average work being given extra weight because it's attached to something with real gravitas, like the AIDS emergency. So I truly try to tread carefully as I walk over the dreams of dignity under my feet in our work for the terrible beauty that is the continent of Africa.

I'm used to the custard pies.

I've even learnt to like the taste of them. But before you are tempted to let fly with your understandable invective, allow me to contextualise.

Not for the sake of my vanity, but for the sake of people who are depending on you - the reader - to respond to the precariousness of their lives.

Picture this: a village where the disappearance of a whole generation has left children to bring up children..

I'm a witness to this. What can I do?

Or this: my new friend Prudence, who even if she had access to anti-retroviral therapies would not have shared them with her now dead sister or best friend Janny, because her fellow activists were more important to keep alive.

Why? Because picture this: most activists and trained nurses cannot afford the drugs available to us in any corner chemist.

I am a witness to this. I have watched these brave and beautiful souls who are fighting a forest fire of a pandemic with watering cans, knowing they will not see the light of a day when their work will be honoured. I have been a witness to their conversations around canteen tables, deciding who will live or die, because they do not have enough pills to go round. I've seen Zackie Achmat refuse his medications until he won his action against the South African Government, forcing their hand on universal access. What a witness he was. And so I testify.

These firefighters deserve fire engines with sirens and low-flying aircraft with bellies full of rain. At the very least, they deserve their situation to merit the classification of an emergency. Code Red, like Hurricane Katrina or the tsunami in south Asia, which swept away 150,000 lives. These were natural catastrophes. Africa loses 150,000 men, women, and children every month to AIDS, a wholly avoidable disaster, a preventable, treatable disease.

Colin Powell describes the tiny little virus HIV as the most lethal weapon of mass destruction on the planet. So forgive us if we expand our strategy to reach the high street, where so many of you live and work.

We need to meet you where you are as you shop, as you phone, as you lead your busy, businessy lives. Those of us who campaign on these issues feel we have made a dent on the pop consciousness with Live Aid and 8, Red Nose Day, Comic Relief and Make Poverty History. But we are still losing the battle: 9000 new infections every day across the developing world.

There will be those that think that RED is the worst idea they've ever heard.

On the far right, we will hear the usual carping about it being Africa's own fault. This despite the fact that the largest increasing group of HIV-positive people are monogamous married women. We'll hear, the "Africans can't take pills because they don't have watches to tell the time" line. Even though Africans have the best record of us all at sticking to their drug regimens.

On the far left, we will meet "better dead than RED", a reaction to big business that is not wholly unjustified. But given the emergency that is AIDS, I don't see this as selling out. I see this as ganging up on the problem.

Product RED cannot replace activism. For anyone who thinks this means I'm going to retire to the boardroom and stop banging my fist on the door of No 10, I'm sorry to disappoint you. We have to keep our marching boots on and hold our leaders to account for the promises they have made to Africa - and get them to promise more. The incredible movement we saw gathering around last year's G8 is what will, in the end, win the day. But for too many people, that day will be too late. Right now, people you will never meet, who will never be able to thank you, are depending on you for the life-saving drugs which buying this paper will buy. For those people, my motivation, or our (RED) motivation, is irrelevant.

U2 frontman and activist Bono, along with leading American philanthropist Bobby Shriver, has set up the product RED partnership, designed to throw the weight of the corporate world behind the battle against AIDS in Africa and which is backed by the Independent newspaper.

(IRAQ ATTACKS Nightlead sent at 19:51, 511 words, IRAQ NIGHTLEAD to come.)<br/><br/>MID: Iran frees eight British troops, Foreign Office says</p><p nitf:lede="true">LONDON, June 24 AP - Eight British troops held by Iran have been freed after three days of detention and are in the custody of British diplomats, Foreign Secretary Jack Straw said today. (IRAN UK Second Nightlead sent at 18:44, 550 words, IRAN UK 3RD N/L to come)<br/><br/>EUR: Two injured in bomb blast near Bush hotel in Ankara</p><p nitf:lede="true">ANKARA, June 24 AFP - Two people have been injured in a bomb blast near the Ankara hotel where US President George W Bush is expected to stay on Saturday. (TURKEY BOMB Nightlead sent at 19:40, 261 words.)</p><p>US: Australia trade pact hits snag in Congress</p><p>WASHINGTON, June 23 Reuters - US administration efforts to win swift approval of a free trade pact with Australia have stumbled as the Democrats demand more congressional control over the pact's beef import provisions. (TRADE US CONGRESS Nightlead sent at 19:35, 457 words.)<br/><br/>ASIA: Aust fires expert warns worst smoke haze yet to come</p><p>JAKARTA, June 24 AAP - Smoke haze from forest fires spreading across Asia from Sumatra was likely to worsen in coming months as illegal burning spread to other parts of Indonesia, an Australian forest fire expert working in the country warned today. (INDON HAZE AUST sent at 17:51, 480 words.)<br/><br/>ASIA: Susilo extends lead over rivals</p><p>JAKARTA, June 24 AAP - There is an adage that one should 'walk softly, but carry a big stick' in case of trouble. (INDON VOTE Nightlead sent at 16:44, 567 words.)<br/><br/>ASIA: Indon judges amass fortunes despite poor pay</p><p>JAKARTA, June 24 AAP - Senior judges in Indonesia's notoriously corrupt legal system have been revealed to be massively wealthy, despite their meagre monthly incomes. (INDON JUDGES sent at 15:37, 371 words.)<br/><br/>MID: Israeli forces carry out broad arrest operation in Nablus</p><p>NABLUS, West Bank, June 24 AP - Dozens of Israeli soldiers have sealed off the old city of Nablus with barbed wire and cement blocks, while troops conduct house-to-house searches for militants. (MIDEAST Nightlead sent at 19:17, 513 words.)<br/><br/>US: Memos show confusion, dissent as Washington made policy</p><p>WASHINGTON, June 23 AP - Dissension and confusion plagued US President George W Bush's administration as officials considered how far to go legally and morally in interrogating prisoners captured in the war on terror. (US PRISONERS (Backgrounder) sent at 17:20, 832 words.)<br/><br/>JAP: Japanese automaker Mitsubishi Motors admits injuries</p><p>TOKYO, June 24 AP - In another blow to its tarnished image, Mitsubishi Motors Corp acknowledged that 11 people were injured in vehicles recalled recently for defects that the Japanese automaker previously denied had hurt anyone. (JAPAN MITSUBISHI sent at 17:48, 515 words.)<br/><br/>ASIA: Malaysia urges Indonesia to tackle fires that send smog</p><p>KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 24 AP - Malaysia wants neighbouring Indonesia to crack down on farmers who set land-clearing fires that are sending thick smoke over parts of South-East Asia, threatening health and fouling the skies of tourist resorts. (INDON HAZE Nightlead sent at 16:58, 475 words.)<br/><br/>PAC: Tongan MP warns of violence if Canberra, NZ don't help</p><p>WELLINGTON, June 24 NZPA/AAP - A Tongan MP today warned of "violence in the streets" if the New Zealand and Australian governments do not help the Pacific monarchy establish democratic processes. (TONGA sent at 15:17, 480 words.)<br/><br/>ASIA: S Korea's Roh orders full probe into Iraq death</p><p>SEOUL, June 24 Reuters - President Roh Moo-hyun ordered a full investigation today into the kidnapping and beheading of a South Korean hostage by militants in Iraq after it emerged the man was abducted three weeks before Seoul found out. (IRAQKOREA REVIEW Nightlead sent at 14:24, 508 words.)<br/><br/>UN: US drops resolution seeking to protect American peacekeepers</p><p>UNITED NATIONS, June 23 AP - Facing global opposition fuelled by the Iraqi prisoner abuse scandal, the United States dropped a contentious UN resolution that sought to renew an exemption shielding American troops from international prosecution for war crimes. (UN COURT Nightlead sent at 14:14, 821 words.)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2004</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4CPJ-BDM0-00VK-234V-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-29</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="759"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2004 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:57H0-19T1-F031-X1B1-00000-00From a lightning strike to a city ablaze2013-01-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisFrom a lightning strike to a city ablazeBy Craig Allen

It is considered Canberra's worst natural disaster, one that tragically reshaped the look and attitude of the bush capital.

On January 18, 2003, four bushfires that had been burning in Brindabella mountains for more than a week combined and roared into Canberra's south-western suburbs, destroying 500 homes and claiming four lives.

Most knew the fires were coming but almost all underestimated the scale of the firestorm and overestimated the capacity of the authorities to stop it.

It was a massive bushfire that created its own weather, with cyclone-strength winds and fire tornados. In every sense, a firestorm.

When the fires hit the suburbs, they took the public - and the authorities - almost entirely by surprise.

Four residents died in a hopeless battle to protect their homes or escape the flames.

Hundreds more people were injured - some critically. They suffered horrendous burns, smoke inhalation, broken limbs, and exhaustion.

There had been no official order to evacuate their homes.

It was, in essence, every man and woman for themselves.

Bushland tinderbox

The fires began on January 8, 2003, when a series of dry lightning storms swept over the vast expanse of Namadgi National Park, which makes up nearly two-thirds of south-west ACT.

When authorities detected the fires, they dispatched small crews into some of the most remote sections of the bush.

But the fires were hard to access and there was no real sense of official urgency.

They were subsequently criticised in an ACT Government inquiry and a long-running coronial inquest, for doing too little, too slowly.

The McLeod Inquiry concluded the fires "might have been contained had they been attacked more aggressively in the 24 or so hours after they broke out."

But the eucalypt forests had been desiccated by years of drought and once the fires took hold, they were impossible to contain.

For more than a week emergency services officials provided community and press briefings on the growing scale of the fires, but little was said publicly to suggest Canberra's suburbs might be at risk.

Key officials dared not to even think it was a possibility, until it was too late.

In the blame game that followed, NSW fire authorities claimed they had issued their ACT counterparts with clear warnings that Canberra's suburbs had been under threat.

Those warnings had never been passed on to the public.

Fires reach Canberra

On the morning of January 18, 2003, there were ominous signs in the sky.

Residents woke to the news that the fires had broken containment lines overnight and were now being fanned towards Canberra's suburbs.

In the city's western suburbs, the sight of ash and burnt leaves falling from the sky - carried tens of kilometres from the fire front to the west - was considered a novelty but little more.

Still, the official firefighting effort was centred around protecting isolated rural settlements and Canberra residents planned their Saturdays in blissful ignorance.

Many headed to the New South Wales south coast to cool down, while others prepared to enjoy another hot summer's day in the capital.

Fire authorities had hoped to stop the fires from crossing the Murrumbidgee River corridor, less than four kilometres west of the Weston Creek suburbs of Duffy, Rivett and Chapman.

As it turned out, even their worst case scenario was to prove dramatically optimistic.

The fire had blown out to a 30-kilometre front, with destructive fire weather forecast, temperatures above 40 degrees Celsius and gusty winds.

What had started as four discrete fires combined into one unstoppable blaze that roared into the suburbs.

Burning suburbs

Between 1pm and 1:30pm the fires crossed the Murrumbidgee River and only then did ACT emergency authorities seriously consider the suburbs were under threat.

From the river it was all uphill to Canberra, the conditions under which fire spreads fastest.

Fire experts later estimated the pace at 20 kilometres per hour, believed to be the fastest documented rate of spread of a forest fire.

The first public emergency warning was finally issued just after 2pm, listing Duffy, Chapman, Rivett, and Holder as areas most at risk.

Instead of urging residents to leave the area, it asked them to return to their homes and prepare for the coming fire front.

At first, a senior emergency services official resisted police efforts to declare a state of emergency, which would allow police to forcibly evacuate residents.

By 2:45pm, the fire began burning extensive pine plantations around Mount Stromlo and eventually destroyed the historic observatory telescope complex that sat at the crest of the hill.

Pine forests also surrounded the suburb of Duffy on two sides, and firefighters dispatched to Eucumbene drive on the the suburban fringe were quickly forced to retreat.

Between 3pm and 3:30pm, the first houses were lost in Duffy.

Almost simultaneously, fire ignited homes in Rivett, Holder, Chapman and Kambah.

The flow of information from fire authorities to the public came in for scathing criticism in subsequent inquiries.

Even as the fire bore down on homes and residents were fleeing for their lives, then chief minister Jon Stanhope was telling the media that people should not be "unduly alarmed".

Clearly no-one knew just how bad the situation was, except those facing the flames.

Nightmare inferno

What followed over the course of the next few hours still haunts many residents of Canberra's western suburbs, even 10 years on.

Firefighters dressed in protective clothing, with modern hoses and firefighting gear were simply overwhelmed.

It was far worse for residents, many of whom were caught out in shorts, singlets and thongs.

It had been normal operating procedure to send at least two fire trucks to a single house fire, and now about 20 firefighting crews were faced with hundreds of homes alight.

In the chaos of that afternoon, three fire trucks broke down after ingesting superheated gases and burning their air filters.

One of those trucks was totally destroyed and its crew only just made it to the safety of a second vehicle. A second crew was also forced out into the flames on foot.

A senior firefighter standing on the roof of his own home in Duffy described the scene before him as "Armageddon".

Many thousands of residents joined an evacuation convoy out of the suburbs - amazingly without serious incident.

But others stayed, battling houses fully ablaze with feebly inadequate resources.

In the end, police road blocks stopped other residents from returning to join the effort.

Those road blocks remained in place many hours after the fire front had passed, but houses were still catching alight from their neighbours.

Some saw it as a case of appalling judgement to block people from the streets, and in hindsight, perhaps some of those homes could have been saved.

Dreadful toll

That afternoon, some 500 homes were destroyed across half a dozen suburbs and rural communities.

Most house losses were in the streets closest to the pine forests but it was a random game of chance.

Some homes were ignited by spot fires kilometres away, while others remained intact surrounded by scenes of utter devastation.

Thousands of residents were displaced and had to be housed at emergency evacuation centres until they could find alternative accommodation.

The four people who died in and near Duffy had been battling the fire front in vain.

One fell from the roof of his house, garden hose still in hand.

Another died lying in her bathtub surrounded by wet towels.

She had apparently misunderstood official advice to fill a bathtub to act as a water source, with tragic consequences.

The Canberra Hospital was over-run with the walking wounded, many suffering burns and smoke inhalation. The emergency department just could not cope and the worst injured were flown to Sydney for specialist treatment.

At 7pm a cool wind change saw an end to the fire emergency and the epic fight to save homes turned to one of rebuilding a shattered community.

urn:contentItem:49MB-WDH0-01S8-D0HX-00000-00<published>1990-08-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BRIEFLY</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Jets deaths LONDON: Three crew members were killed today in a mid-air collision between two RAF Tornado jets over the North Sea. A fourth crewman was "seriously ill" in hospital. The planes were on routine training unconnected with the Gulf crisis.</p><p>India bomb NEW DELHI: A bomb killed at least four people in Delhi on the eve of India's independence day celebrations. It exploded in a park where people were celebrating today's birthday of Lord Krishna, one of the major gods in the Hindu pantheon.</p><p> Palace attack LIMA: Suspected Leftists rammed a car loaded with dynamite into Peru's presidential palace while President Alberto Fujimori was in the compound, causing a large explosion but injuring no one.</p><p> 21 lost TAIPEI: A fishing boat carrying 50 illegal migrants back to China collided with a Taiwanesepatrol ship and 21 Chinese were missing, believed dead.</p><p> Blacks clash JOHANNESBURG: Nine people were killed and 35 injured in overnight clashes between between Zulus and Xhosas near Johannesburg.</p><p> Plunge pipped NIAGARA FALLS: A Canadian daredevil was prevented from making the first known plunge over the 53-metre American Falls when police became suspicious about a big foam sphere in his truck. Nine people in barrels or similar devices have survived the plunge over the Canadian Horseshoe Falls since 1901, but huge rocks at the base of the American Falls have discouraged anyone from that plunge.</p><p> No. 160 NEW YORK: The Security Council today unanimously endorsed the Principality of Liechtenstein's application to become the 160th member of the UN.The General Assembly was expected to unanimously approve it in September.</p><p> Crime soars LONDON: Sex attacks in London have increased by 21 per cent, Scotland Yard said today.Overall crime in London rose by 10 per cent in the 12 months up to the end of June, and police the upward trend was likely to continue.</p><p> Fire threat LOS ANGELES: A fast-moving forest fire threatened up to 1600 homes in northern California, and a state of emergency was declared for the county where fires have blackened parts of Yosemite National Park.Flames were within three kilometres of Yosemite's Merced Grove of giant sequoia trees. Fires have burned 85,000 hectares of California during the past week.Fires also blackened parts of Idaho, Utah, Oregon, Washington and Alaska.</p><p> Population down TOKYO: Japan's population was 122.74 million at the end of March after recording the lowest annual growth rate since surveys began in 1968.</p><p> Drug arrests KUALA LUMPUR: Malaysian customs officers have detained six Nigerians, including a woman, on suspicion of smuggling about one kilogram of high-grade heroin. Malaysia's drug laws calls for mandatory death sentences for anyone caught with 15 grams or more of heroin.</p><p> Jazz star dies PARIS: Jazz bassist Louis Vola, a founding member of the legendary Hot Club Quintet in the 1930s, has died after a long illness. He was 88.</p><p> And finally . . .</p><p> LONDON: The Australian-made TV soap opera Neighbours and England's EastEnders are facing an increasingly strong challenge from Emmerdale Farm, an environmentally friendly soap which is growing greener and stronger in health-conscious southern England.</p><p> HERALD BUREAU, AGENCIES</p><p> END OF urn:contentItem:5154-DJ61-JCVT-J1FH-00000-00What India knows about failure2010-10-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisEXTRAPg. 4What India knows about failureThe Fitz FilesPETER FITZSIMONS

FOR those on your way to Homebush today to see the NRL grand final, you might enjoy the following excerpt of a piece that ran in The Times of India last month called "The 10 most disastrous games". Under the sub-heading "Painful legacy", it said: "If the 1936 Olympics was one of the most politicised, the Sydney Games of 2000 best personifies the negative economic impact that mega events can have on host cities. The Sydney Olympic Park which housed the athletes, now stands derelict. Getting there, some 25 kilometres from the business district, is an ordeal involving driving down Paramatta Road for an hour. The link between Darwin Harbour was not accomplished and the taxpayers continue to bear the brunt of this investment.

Even as a tourist attraction, the Sydney Olympic Park has little currency. It remains an example of how things can go wrong while trying to use sport as a module for urban regeneration." Built to last AN INTERESTING rant on The Sydney Morning Herald's website last week, by Jonno Seidler, took aim at an Australian music culture that continues to embrace stars from the '60s, '70s and '80s, while ignoring artists from the past 20 years. We listen to the oldies on radio and go to see the likes of Bob Dylan, John Farnham, AC/DC, Simon and Garfunkel, and Billy Joel in huge numbers in concerts. (Don't forget, just 37 days to go till Leonard Cohen sings again in Sydney.) "In an already crowded arena," Seidler wrote, "the juggernauts of yesteryear hang over our heads even when they're no longer recording. There's no space for new music in this country, because we're still clinging to the old." All good, Jonno, and perhaps a fair point. Your generation has produced some great artists including Michael Franti, the Cat Empire and Green Day - and I have been to their concerts - but pound for pound, hit for hit, it seems to me the talent gets very thin thereafter, and few bands and singers seem to stay around long enough to earn the iconic status that will see people still wanting to see them play 40 and 50 years on. That's a problem for your generation. My generation will still pay to see Dylan sing Desolation Row 10 years from now. Whose life is it? AS FAR as I know, I am as healthy as a trout, at least healthy enough to play some rugby with the Golden Oldies Festival of the Cauliflower Ears, which has brought 5000 visitors to our town. But let's say I was not. Let's say I was suffering a terminal illness and was facing an agonising end lasting many months. Let's say that, instead of going down that path, I chose to be euthanased at the point where I judged my meaningful life was over, even if my heart was still beating. Here is my question: what right would you have to stop me, to assert that your desire to have me to stay living outweighed my own right to die? Because your religion says so? I don't share your religion. Because you know better than me? Please. Because you think life is precious and must be preserved, no matter the cost to the state and pain to the person? Palpable nonsense. I assert that my own right to die in a manner of my choosing far outweighs all other factors. Australia will have to weigh up just such issues in coming weeks, as Bob Brown's euthanasia bill is put before Federal Parliament. The country is likely to be tightly divided on the issue - a state familiar to us lately - and on the side of euthanasia I suspect you will find most of us who have nursed a dying parent to the bitter end. Joke of the week A PARAPROSDOKIAN is a figure of speech in which the latter part of a sentence or phrase is surprising or unexpected in a way that causes the reader or listener to reframe or reinterpret the first part. I asked God for a bike, but I know God doesn't work that way. So I stole a bike and asked for forgiveness. The last thing I want to do is hurt you. But it's still on the list. Knowledge is knowing a tomato is a fruit. Wisdom is not putting it in a fruit salad. How is it one careless match can start a forest fire, but it takes a whole box to start a campfire? A bank is a place that will lend you money you can if prove that you don't need it. Women will never be equal to men until they can walk down the street with a bald head and a beer gut, and still think they are sexy. You do not need a parachute to skydive. You only need a parachute to skydive twice. I always take life with a grain of salt, plus a slice of lemon, and a shot of tequila. Model muck-up IN AUCKLAND on Wednesday night, I was fascinated to see the Kiwis' principal television station TV ONE include, high in their evening news bulletin, the Sarah Murdoch Australia's Next Top Model imbroglio, in which the host announced the wrong winner then had to recant halfway through the celebrations. But wouldn't you know it? The Kiwis did it first. The station ran footage of host Peter Sinclair at the 1984 Miss New Zealand contest reading out the runners-up as he built to the climactic announcement of the winner before suddenly stopping and saying: "And now, ladies and gentlemen, I have a most embarrassing task to perform ... I have just read the list from the top down, instead of the bottom up ... In fact, this is the correct order." You can watch the whole excruciating episode by Googling the details above. It is priceless! They said ... GENE SIMMONS, the legendary bass player from KISS, on having a prostate check: "You know what's going to happen when the doctor goes through the gateway to hell, so let him at least kiss you and take you out to dinner first." Independent MP Rob Oakeshott, on the opening day of Federal Parliament: "I'll be brief." pfitzsimons@sunherald.com.au

urn:contentItem:4JMV-JRX0-TX5J-81WT-00000-00In praise of Howard, Costello, Downer and the cabinet2006-04-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisFEATURESCut & PastePg. 15

MATP

In praise of Howard, Costello, Downer and the cabinetMark Steyn

CUT & PASTE

Mark Steyn in the Chicago Sun-Times, on why Australians are role models in the war on Islamist terrorism

IF I had to propose a model for Western rhetoric, it would be the Australians. In the days after September 11, the French got all the attention for that Le Monde headline: ''Nous sommes tous Americains'' -- ''We are all Americans,'' though they didn't mean it, even then. But John Howard, the Aussie Prime Minister, put it better and kept his word: ''This is no time to be an 80 per cent ally.''

Marvellous. More recently, the Prime Minister offered some thoughts on the difference between Muslims and other immigrant groups. ''You can't find any equivalent in Italian or Greek or Lebanese or Chinese or Baltic immigration to Australia. There is no equivalent of raving on about jihad,'' he said, stating the obvious in a way most political leaders can't quite bring themselves to do. ''There is really not much point in pretending it doesn't exist.''

Unfortunately, too many of his counterparts insist on pretending (at least to their citizenry) that it doesn't exist. What proportion of Western Muslims is hot for jihad? Five per cent? Ten, 12 per cent? Given that understanding this pan-Islamist identity is critical to defeating it, why can't we acknowledge it honestly?

''Raving on about jihad'' is a line that meets what the law used to regard as the reasonable-man test: If you're watching news footage of a Muslim march promising to bring on the new Holocaust, Howard's line fits.

Is it something in the water down there? Listen to Howard's cabinet colleagues. Here's the Australian Treasurer, Peter Costello, with advice for Western Muslims who want to live under Islamic law: ''There are countries that apply religious or sharia law -- Saudi Arabia and Iran come to mind. If a person wants to live under sharia law these are countries where they might feel at ease. But not Australia.''

You don't say. Which is the point: Most Western government leaders don't say, and their silence is correctly read by a resurgent Islam as timidity.

I also appreciated this pithy summation by my favourite Foreign Minister, Alexander Downer: ''Multilateralism is a synonym for an ineffective and unfocused policy involving internationalism of the lowest common denominator.'' See Sudanese slaughter, Iranian nukes, the UN's flop response to the tsunami, etc. It's a good thing being an Aussie cabinet minister doesn't require confirmation by [liberal US Democrat senators] John Kerry and Joe Biden.

The Sydney Morning Herald takes issue with Bill Leak and The Weekend Australian:

[LEAK'S] cartoon could hardly be calculated to offend more. The Rakyat Merdeka drawing [of John Howard and Alexander Downer as humping dingoes, somehow related to an alleged Australian wish to take over Papua] was not particularly funny or on target, aside from being tasteless, so was easy for its targets to shrug off. The Murdoch newspaper's cartoon is consciously more offensive, since the dog is regarded as a particularly unclean animal by Indonesia's Muslims. It is hard to think of any other world leader being depicted the same way as the cartoon did Yudhoyono. Indeed, by sharp contrast, the same newspaper had just set what may be record levels of sycophancy in its coverage of visits by Condoleezza Rice, Tony Blair and Wen Jiabao. When another of its cartoonists depicted the former president Suharto as an orang-outang swinging nonchalantly through the jungles, during the 1997 forest-fire haze and economic crisis, its editors were soon on a plane to grovel in Jakarta.

See-sawing between adulation and reckless offence hardly reflects well on editorial judgment. Sentiment in the Muslim world is inflamed enough. It's a time to do what you do with rutting dogs: bring out the hose.

Andrew Cornell, in The Weekend Australian Financial Review, on how Howard has turned our athletes into cheats:

AT the recent Big Day Out rock concert in Melbourne, some veteran rockers lamented younger fans draping themselves in the Australian flag. ''In our day they would have been burning the flag, given this Government and what it's done to ordinary people and refugees,'' said one particular rock beast.

He's right. This meanness of spirit and bodgy nationalism is a symptom of that same latent xenophobia and old-fashioned cultural cringe that John Howard has successfully parlayed in his 10 years in office.

It was most graphically on display in the [Melbourne Commonwealth] Games context when 400m runner Tamsyn Lewis ensured a gold medal by knowingly allowing the English to break a technical rule and then protesting -- robbing the clearly superior English of the win when the infringement made absolutely no difference to the result ... This was a very ugly Australia.

urn:contentItem:4PT8-M680-TX52-K0JH-00000-00mercury rising2007-10-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:55:59ZLexisNexisOUR WEATHER - HOTPg. N22mercury risingFIONA MYERS

Climate change will have wide-ranging consequences as Victoria heats up

Opinions may be divided as to just how much hotter Victorians will be as a result of climate change. But it is the Great Dividing Range that will determine the scale of increases in temperature as a result of global warming.

Thanks to their proximity to the coast, those people living south of the divide won't see the temperature rises their northern cousins will experience.

CSIRO researchers have used 12 computer models to come to these conclusions, and the outcomes point to a warmer climate, although the rises depend on where you live.

By 2030, average daytime temperatures are expected to rise between 0.3C and 1.6C and by 2070 that rise is expected to be in the range of 0.8C-5C in northern Victoria and 0.6C-4C in the south of the state.

Northern Victoria is likely to get warm, and those long, hot summers are going to get longer.

For Mildura residents, the number of days that reach 35C or more could increase by four to 11 days by 2030 and by 2070, there could be nine to 41 more scorchers for the city.

They will also have more "hot spells", when there are three to five days where temperatures exceed 35C. By 2070, Mildura residents could have up to 10 more of these hot spells each year.

But that needs to be put into perspective, according to CSIRO Marine and Atmospheric Research stream leader Dr Penny Whetton.

She said Mildura's climate was already warm in summer, and any rise in temperature of 1C or 2C would not be too noticeable.

"It just means that a 34C day will be a 35C day, and so will contribute to a hot spell, rather than big jumps in temperatures," Dr Whetton said. "Every day of the year will be just that bit warmer."

Even Melbourne residents are going to get more chances to warm up, with up to 23 more days over 35C by 2070.

By then, Bendigo's climate will be more like Echuca's, Melbourne's like Adelaide's and Shepparton more like Condobolin, NSW - all about 2C warmer and 20 per cent drier.

While tongue-in-cheek references to more sun in Melbourne can be seen as a joke, there are obviously great implications for the broader community.

Already climatologists are warning of more cases of heat-related deaths. These are expected to double in Melbourne, from the current level of 289 a year, up to 604 by 2020 and 1318 by 2050.

While the ageing population also plays its part in these figures, the hotter climate has a major role in the rising death rates.

Agriculture, too, must prepare for the implications of hotter summers.

There are few dairy cattle around Condobolin in central western NSW, yet this is the kind of climate that Goulburn Valley diary farmers will face come 2070.

Hotter summers will mean cows eat less, lose weight, will produce less milk of lower quality and will be under greater pressure from parasites. Some experts also predict extreme conditions could lead to the collapse of cows, unless precautions are made such as extra shade and other means of cooling cows down.

"The climate is what has made Victoria such a centre for dairying, as the cows are more productive in cooler climates. These cows may well get more stressed if the temperature warms up," Dr Whetton said.

Grape growers might also need to make changes to stop their vines and winegrapes suffering heat damage.

"Obviously with increased temperatures, these things become more of an issue," she said.

The hotter, and drier, conditions will have an impact on fires too, with an expected increase in extreme fire days. There could be up to 70 per cent more very high and extreme forest fire days by 2050, and extreme grass fire days are also expected to rise by up to 40 per cent by 2050.

At Mildura, that could mean a jump from 79 extreme fire days to 107 days of tough conditions by 2050.

But Dr Whetton stressed that an increased number of risk days did not necessarily mean more fires.

"We can change the way we manage forests and grasslands, knowing that there is an increased chance of fires," she said.

The rebels could be seen this morning trying to battle their way over a bridge into the city centre, where a defiant President Samuel Doe remains barricaded in his mansion.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Deadlock SOFIA: Bulgaria's new parliament failed today for the third time to elect a state president.</p><p>Brando watch NEW YORK: Marlon Brando's daughter Cheyenne, who has been charged with plotting to kill her boyfriend, has been placed on "suicide watch" in a Tahitian mental hospital. Cheyenne, 20, faces life in prison if convicted of conspiring to murder her boyfriend, Dag Drollet, in Los Angeles in May.Her half-brother, Christian, has been ordered to stand trial for Drollet's murder.</p><p> Nuclear first BEIJING: China will attend talks on the nuclear non-proliferation treaty for the first time next month, indicating it may be willing to join the international accord, visiting British Foreign Office Minister Francis Maude said today.</p><p>Jakarta visit BEIJING: Chinese Premier Li Peng will visit Indonesia next month for the restoration of Sino-Indonesian ties after a 23-year break.</p><p> Landing rights LONDON: The British scheme to grant nationality to thousands of key Hong Kong residents before the territory returns to Chinese control received royal assent today after a stormy passage through the Parliament. About 225,000 Hong Kong residents will be allowed to settle in Britain after 1997.</p><p> KGB legal WARSAW: The Soviet KGB has come in from the cold in Poland, where it now has an officially registered mission after decades of secret influence on Poland's secret service.</p><p> Gorillas safe KIGALI: A forest fire which threatened Rwanda's rare mountain gorillas has been brought under control.</p><p> Hostage deal BRUSSELS: A convicted Palestinian terrorist, Sa'eed Nasser, becomes eligible for parole tomorrow, but Belgium insists he will not be released until four Belgian hostages are freed by Abu Nidal's Fatah-Revolutionary Council.</p><p> Rioter jailed LONDON: Simon O'Reilly, a 22-year-old laborer who kicked and punched a police van during the March 31 poll tax riot in Trafalgar Square, was jailed today for two years.</p><p>Albanian deaths BELGRADE: Yugoslav Deputy Interior Minister Jovan Vuckovic has disclosed that that 90 ethnic Albanians were killed in riots in Kosovo in January and February, more than three times the official toll of 28.</p><p> Ripper libel LONDON: Private Eye editor Ian Hislop and the publishers of the satirical magazine were today each ordered to pay a 10,000 fine for their "serious contempt" in publishing two articles about the Yorkshire Ripper's wife Sonia Sutcliffe while her libel action against them was pending.</p><p> And finally . . .</p><p> COPENHAGEN: More than 60 Santa Clauses, including delegates from the Soviet Union and half a dozen European nations attended an annual off-season get-together in Copenhagen. They lunched, swapped Christmas stories, elected an Elf of the Year, and stuck with their beards and red suits despite the heat of midsummer's day.</p><p> AGENCIES, HERALD BUREAU</p><p> END OF
