urn:contentItem:44M2-4J20-015G-T437-00000-00<published>2001-12-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:55:59Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 3</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>The fall of Kandahar</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE Taliban today announced the surrender of Kandahar, their spiritual home and last bastion.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Opposition fighters in the southern region immediately announced a ceasefire.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Hamid Karzai, the premier-in-waiting of Afghanistan's newly established interim administration, said he had offered a general amnesty to the "common Taliban".</p><p nitf:lede="true"> He said Taliban leader Mullah Mohammad would not be safe unless he renounced terrorism, but said he had no idea where Omar was.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AFP</p></bodyText></section><p>In Washington, US Defence Secretary Donald Rumsfeld ruled out any surrender deal that would let Omar live in dignity.</p><p> "We have, as our principal objectives, to see that we deal effectively with the senior al-Qaeda leadership and the Taliban leadership, and that the remaining al-Qaeda fighters do not leave the country," said Mr Rumsfeld.</p><p> "We want either to bring them to justice or bring justice to them."</p><p> Asked what Omar should face, White House spokesman Ari Fleischer said President George W Bush "believes very strongly that those who harbor terrorists need to be brought to justice".</p><p> Mr Karzai, who has been fighting the Taliban in the Kandahar area while repeatedly saying over the past weeks that he was also engaged in talks for their surrender, said Afghan footsoldiers of the Taliban could return home without any trouble.</p><p> But foreign fighters loyal to bin Laden, the so-called Arab Afghans, were criminals who would be brought to justice, he said. "They have committed unprecedented crimes against Afghanistan and the international community.</p><p> "They must leave my country and they must face justice," said Mr Karzai, a 44-year-old royalist Pashtun tribal leader.</p><p> Mr Karzai said the handover of Kandahar would begin tomorrow and take up to three days.</p><p> "Right now, the announcement from the Taliban cabinet is that they have agreed to transfer power," he said. "That is something which will be honoured from our side.</p><p> "We will respect their decision and we will allow them to take one or two days for the transfer of power," he said.</p><p> "This announcement has not been made by Mullah Omar but by the Taliban cabinet."</p><p> A senior Taliban official, former ambassador to Pakistan Abdul Salam Zaeef, told CNN the militia would begin surrendering the city, along with "the weapons, the ammunition, to (Pashtun tribal) elders" from tomorrow.</p><p> The arrangement, he said, was "that the Taliban should surrender Kandahar peacefully to the elders . . . not to Karzai and other persons," who, he said, "want to enter Kandahar with the support of America".</p><p> In Kandahar, the situation was tense as US fighter planes circled the city after nightfall.</p><p> "The jets are overhead. They are not bombing, but everyone is worried," said a resident by phone.</p><p> "During the day, armed Taliban were driving around the city," he said. "There are still civilians here but not as many as before, and they are quiet and anxious about what will happen next."</p><p> Kandahar has been under relentless US air attack since the start of the military campaign.</p><p> Officers with a US Marine force of more than 1000 men deployed southwest of the city also said they had joined the fray.</p><p>  Further north, US Air and anti-Taliban Afghan ground forces pursued their attacks on al-Qaeda's Tora Bora stronghold, in the forbidding White Mountains close to the Pakistani border.</p><p> Hundreds of al-Qaeda fighters in Tora Bora, a warren of caves where some believe bin Laden may also be hiding, came under heavy fire from US aircraft and tanks of the local militia.</p><p> An AFP correspondent watched as al-Qaeda mountain positions were pummelled by tank fire and hit by five bombs from a US war plane flying under heavy cloud cover.</p><p> The bombing triggered a huge forest fire in the mountains.</p><p> Provincial officials said an air strike on Monday devastated al-Qaeda leaders, killing at least 10 and wounding, perhaps killing Ayman al-Zawahri, bin Laden's top deputy.</p><p> But a London-based Islamist denied al-Zawahri was dead, but confirmed that his wife, son and two daughters had died in a US raid on Kandahar. -</p><p>ANCIENT city, Page 7</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata
